antireqs: Archaeology 201 or 205.

name: Ethnohistory of Africa
desc: Examples of African ethnohistory are explored using the techniques found in African historical archaeology including oral history and traditions, ethnoarchaeology, genetics, archaeology, historical records and art history.

name: Archaeology of the Near East
desc: Survey of the prehistory of the Near East, starting with the earliest traces of human activity up to the Bronze Age. Topics include adaptations to a varied environment, successive human migrations out of Africa, the nature of the Middle-Upper Palaeolithic transition, the agricultural revolution, and the world’s earliest cities and states.
prereqs: Archaeology 201 or 205.
antireqs: Archaeology 201 or 205.

name: Lithic Technology
desc: Study and analysis of tools and other artifacts, including their forms, methods of manufacture and use.
prereqs: Archaeology 201.
antireqs: Archaeology 201.

name: Zooarchaeology
desc: The study and analysis of osteological remains used in reconstructing the subsistence strategies of past peoples.
prereqs: Archaeology 201.
antireqs: Archaeology 201.

name: Tipi, Buffalo, and Vision: People of the Plains
desc: Explores traditional Plains cultures as recorded in ethnographic accounts and First Nations oral traditions.

name: Archaeology of the Arctic
desc: Prehistory/history of N. E. Asia, Alaska, Canada and Greenland. Emphasis will be placed on ecological and ethnographical data.
prereqs: 3 units from Archaeology 201, 205, 303.
antireqs: 3 units from Archaeology 201, 205, 303.

name: Paleolithic Archaeology in the Old World
desc: A global survey of Old World prehistoric hunter-gatherers with an emphasis on factual data, analytical techniques, and interpretive trends in the study of the Paleolithic era.
prereqs: Archaeology 201 or 203.
antireqs: Archaeology 201 or 203.

name: African Complex Societies
desc: Ancient African complex societies with an emphasis on state development south of the Sahara. Topics include why these states developed, their participation in internal and international systems of exchange, technological developments, belief systems that supported power structures, and the reasons for their collapse. Time period covered is from the rise of the ancient state of Egypt to the colonial period.

name: Hunter-Gatherer Archaeology
desc: An overview of the history of hunter-gatherer studies in anthropology and archaeology. Introduces current theoretical issues in hunter-gatherer research.
prereqs: Archaeology 201.
antireqs: Archaeology 201.

name: Method and Theory in Archaeology
desc: A survey of approaches to the study of the relationship between theory, method, and data in archaeological practice.
prereqs: Archaeology 201 and 60 units.
antireqs: Archaeology 201 and 60 units.

name: Fundamentals of Geoarchaeology
desc: Methods used in geoarchaeology to interpret site and regional context, provenance, stratigraphy, environmental and climatic changes, and principles applied in dating, chemical and isotopic analysis, and remote sensing. Basic principles of sedimentation and soil development explored in experiential learning modules.
prereqs: 3 units from Archaeology 201, Geography 211, 310, Geology 201, 209.
antireqs: 3 units from Archaeology 201, Geography 211, 310, Geology 201, 209.

name: Ceramic Analysis
desc: The production of pottery: raw materials and techniques. Form, function and decoration. Ceramic ecology. Field processing and sampling. Classification: a survey of approaches. Ceramics and archaeological inference. Practical exercises.
prereqs: Archaeology 201.
antireqs: Archaeology 201.

name: Current Topics in Archaeology
desc: Examination of current theoretical, methodological, or topical issues in archaeology.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Gender in Prehistory
desc: The theoretical background for feminist archaeology and some of the important advances in Old and New World gender studies. Topics include the relationship of gender hierarchy to the rise of the state; contrasts between the ideological representation of gender and culture practice; and an overarching theme of critical analysis relating the present to the past.
prereqs: Archaeology 451.
antireqs: Archaeology 451.

name: Advanced Archaeological Field Techniques
desc: Training in the more advanced aspects of field work.
prereqs: Archaeology 201 and 306.
antireqs: Archaeology 201 and 306.

name: Paleoethnobotany
desc: The study of ancient plants for food and other purposes through microbotanical remains and ethnobotanical research. Explores uses of microscopic markers such as phytogenic silica and starch granules to reconstruct human ecology, while using ethnobotanical information from traditional knowledge. The emphasis is on the Old World.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Archaeology
desc: Investigation of various theoretical, methodological, analytical, and/or topical issues in archaeology.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Human Osteology
desc: Identification and interpretation of human skeletal and dental remains. Emphasis is on functional anatomy and reconstruction of prehistoric lifeways.
prereqs: 3 units from Anthropology 309, 350, Archaeology 417.
antireqs: 3 units from Anthropology 309, 350, Archaeology 417.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Research project under the direction of a member of the Department.
prereqs: Admission to BA or BSc Archaeology Honours program and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to BA or BSc Archaeology Honours program and consent of the Department.

name: Landscape Archaeology
desc: Human perceptions and uses of the biophysical and cultural environment. The emphasis is on the act of humanizing the environment by naming places, identifying resources, establishing paths, and modifying the natural landscape thereby creating a tradition of land use that can be accessed archaeologically.
prereqs: Archaeology 451.
antireqs: Archaeology 451.

name: Household Archaeology
desc: Human perceptions and uses of the built environment, particularly residential architecture. The emphasis is on the structure and symbolism associated with the spatial arrangements of objects, activities, and social interactions.
prereqs: Archaeology 451.
antireqs: Archaeology 451.

name: Problems in Palaeopathology and Palaeonutrition
desc: Patterns of disease in prehistoric human populations with consideration to the interaction of health and nutrition. Techniques for determining disease and nutrition from prehistoric remains are covered.
prereqs: 9 units Anthropology 201, 350, Archaeology 555 and admission to the Archaeology or Anthropology major.
antireqs: 9 units Anthropology 201, 350, Archaeology 555 and admission to the Archaeology or Anthropology major.

name: Independent Study
desc: An independent study course for Archaeology majors under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Admission to the BA or BSc Archaeology and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the BA or BSc Archaeology and consent of the Department.

name: Theoretical Foundations
desc: The philosophy of science, the history of anthropological theory, and a survey of contemporary theoretical approaches in anthropology. Throughout, the relevance to and connections with the subdisciplines of archaeology and biological anthropology will be emphasized.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Seminar on Special Topics
desc: Intensive study of special problems of particular interest to Archaeology Department graduate students. Subject matter for any particular year to be left to the discretion of the Department.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Analysis of Human Skeletal Remains
desc: Methods of analyzing human remains from archaeological contexts with emphasis on identification and description. Lecture, lab and weekly seminar directed to Archaeology graduate students who have not had a previous course in human osteology.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Topics in Archaeological Theory and Method
desc: The history of archaeological theory and contemporary theoretical and methodological approaches used in archaeological research.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Theory and its Application in Biological Anthropology
desc: Basic issues in the study of human adaptation with a focus on principles of evolutionary biology as they apply to modern studies. Throughout, a bio-cultural approach will be emphasized.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Human Osteology
desc: Current developments in interpretation of human skeletal and dental remains. Topics include forensic anthropology, bone biology, and population reconstruction.
prereqs: Archaeology 555.
antireqs: Archaeology 555.

name: Problems in Ethnoarchaeology
desc: Seminar on selected topics relating to ethnoarchaeology.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Hunter-Gatherer Adaptations
desc: Intensive study of contemporary and prehistoric hunter-gatherer social and economic adaptations.

name: Origins of Agriculture
desc: Intensive study of the origins of agriculture throughout the world.

name: The Development of Complex Societies
desc: The rise, development, and collapse of complex societies throughout the world.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Specialized Analyses of Archaeological Materials
desc: Theory and practice for specialized analyses of the physical and chemical composition of archaeological materials, including microscopic traces of use. Topics will cover procedures used to prepare materials for such specialized analyses and to identify the relevant properties, as well as issues of quantification and interpretation.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Social Identity
desc: Social identity is a fundamental theoretical and practical concern for archaeologists, physical anthropologists, and paleoanthropologists. Explores how humans use material culture and material practices to interact in a world ordered by social identities. Students will explore how research in their area of interest has addressed social identities.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Mesoamerican Archaeology and History
desc: Ancient history of Mesoamerica, emphasizing a conjunctive approach based on hieroglyphic, historical and ethnohistorical sources as well as on archaeological evidence.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Stable Isotope Methods in Archaeology
desc: Methods and applications of stable isotope analysis to archaeological research. Topics to be covered include the use of light stable isotopes to determine past and present diet, the use of stable isotopes to document residence and migration, analysis of stable carbon isotopes in soils, stable isotope ecology for environmental reconstruction and paleoclimate studies.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Special Topics in World Archaeology
desc: Archaeology of particular geographical areas such as Circumpolar, North America, Mesoamerica, South America, Africa, Oceania, and Europe and Near East.

name: Advanced Seminar in Selected Topics
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Art Fundamentals: 2D
desc: Foundation course in two-dimensional art making. Creative exploration of pictorial space, composition and design will occur via learning fundamentals of perspective, colour, shape, balance and unity. Approaches may include wet and dry media, digital technologies, printmaking, and collage. These will be addressed in the context of research, problem solving, visual fluency and conceptual development.

name: Art Fundamentals: 3D
desc: Foundation course in three-dimensional art making. Creative exploration may include media such as plaster, clay, wood, and found objects. Technical approaches may include mold-making, casting, additive and subtractive processes. Form, mass, volume and materials will be addressed in the context of research, problem solving, visual fluency and conceptual development.

name: Introduction to Photography and Digital Imaging
desc: An introductory course in current photographic methods, including digital photography, digital image processing and the presentation of photographs.

name: Drawing I
desc: Introductory course in observational and representational drawing. Creative exploration includes mark-making, hand-eye co-ordination, proportions, perspective, line, texture, figure-ground relationships and pictorial composition. Approaches may include pencil, conté, charcoal, pastel, pen and ink. These will be addressed in the context of research, problem-solving, visual fluency and conceptual development.

name: Drawing II
desc: Developing observational and representational skills through figure drawing and exploration of the contemporary field. Approaches will include a more developed understanding of colour, research, problem solving, visual fluency and conceptual development.
prereqs: Art 241.
antireqs: Art 241.

name: Media Arts: Practice and Theory
desc: Technical instruction and creative opportunities in the media arts, in addition to examination of historical, theoretical and critical context.

name: Introduction to Printmaking
desc: An introduction to fine art printmaking. Technical approaches may include monotype, drypoint and relief.

name: Studies in Contemporary Canadian Art
desc: Study of recent Canadian art from a range of perspectives in art criticism.

name: Foundations of Art Education
desc: An introduction to the history, theory and philosophy of art education through participatory learning events.

name: Topics in Art
desc: Topics related to contemporary studio and curatorial practices such as spirituality, exhibitions, digital storytelling, new media, or public art.

name: Net Video Art
desc: Introduction to contemporary approaches to video art production and web dissemination. Students will gain experience and a working knowledge of concept development, video shooting and editing in the context of digital art and social media.
prereqs: Art 235.
antireqs: Art 235.

name: Video Art
desc: Focuses on concepts, issues, and techniques of video as an art medium. Students will gain experience and a working knowledge of concept development, video shooting and digital editing, in the context of contemporary art theory and practice.
prereqs: Art 235.
antireqs: Art 235.

name: Introduction to Indigenous Art
desc: An introduction to Indigenous art that explores historical and contemporary ways of making. Technical approaches may include beading, quilling, or hide.

name: Programming for Artists
desc: An introduction to computer programming techniques used to create interactive art projects.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Art.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Art.

name: Electronics for Artists
desc: Theoretical and practical applications of basic electronic principles and techniques involving the use of electronics in contemporary art practices. Will include applied experiences with hardware and visual programming environments.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Art.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Art.

name: Digital Illustration
desc: Introduces students to vector-based illustration techniques, their historical context, and terminology. The course provides a focus on the fundamentals of designing with imagery, and the relationship between verbal and visual communication.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Art.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Art.

name: Net Art: Theory and Practice
desc: Examination of the work of Net-based artists and investigation of the Internet as a vehicle to extend art and design practice.

name: Digital Sculpture
desc: Introduces students to 3D modelling by means of digital sculpting techniques, their historical context and terminology. Provides a focus on the fundamentals of working and designing in three-dimensional space.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Art.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Art.

name: Art Now I
desc: A series of presentations by visiting artists and scholars that introduces students to professional practices of contemporary visual artists.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art.

name: Art Now II
desc: A series of presentations by visiting artists and scholars that introduces students to professional practices of contemporary visual artists.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art.

name: 2D Digital Imaging
desc: Electronic visualization involving computer applications in artistic practice.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Art.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Art.

name: Topics in Photography
desc: Studio inquiry in photography developing students’ foundational, technical and conceptual skills. Exploration of topics in photography such as large format, projection, narrative and fine art printing processes will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice. Activities will include workshops, studio practice and critique.
prereqs: Art 336.
antireqs: Art 336.

name: Time-Based Art
desc: Exploration of time and duration as a component of artistic practice, that may include the use of frame-based media and camera-less animation.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Art.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Art.

name: Digital Photography
desc: Fundamental technical, aesthetic and conceptual considerations in digital photography, camera use and the use of desktop editing software in support of fine art photography. Introduction to digital printing for photographic artists. A portion of assigned course work will be output as inkjet prints.
prereqs: Art 235.
antireqs: Art 235.

name: Film Photography
desc: Further work in photography, using film and silver-based photographic materials including intensive use of the variables of exposure, film development and silver-based printing of photographic materials.
prereqs: Art 235.
antireqs: Art 235.

name: Panorama and 360 Virtual Reality Photography
desc: Students learn how to use software and hardware needed to create panoramas and virtual tours.
prereqs: Art 235.
antireqs: Art 235.

name: Drawing the Figure
desc: Theory and practice of drawing the human figure at a developing level involving an extended range of drawing media.
prereqs: Art 241.
antireqs: Art 241.

name: Art Education Across the Lifespan I
desc: An exploration of the cognitive, emotional, and social development of infants, children and adolescents learning art. Students will engage in experiential learning in formal and informal settings.

name: Drawing: Construction of Pictorial Space
desc: Extends the range of concepts and practices in drawing to include pictorial space.
prereqs: Art 241.
antireqs: Art 241.

name: Art Education Across the Lifespan II
desc: An exploration of the cognitive, emotional, and social development of adults learning art. Students will engage in experiential learning in formal and informal settings.

name: Anatomical Drawing I
desc: Perceptual and drawing skills pertaining to human anatomical relationships.
prereqs: Art 241.
antireqs: Art 241.

name: Anatomical Drawing II
desc: Further development of anatomical drawing skills including anatomical structures of the hands and the muscles of facial expression.
prereqs: Art 345.
antireqs: Art 345.

name: Drawing for the Biological Sciences
desc: Basic and more complex principles of drawing from subjects pertaining to the biological sciences; drawing from observation, exploration of foundational skills in a cross-disciplinary context.

name: Painting: Materials and Processes
desc: Technical and conceptual exploration of painting, with experimentation in at least two media, including acrylic and/or oil. May include colour theory, painting style, application of materials and different painting supports.
prereqs: Art 231 or 241.
antireqs: Art 231 or 241.

name: Painting: Figuration
desc: Exploration of painting proceeding from observation and traditions of figuration. Media will include acrylic and/or oil.
prereqs: Art 231 or 241.
antireqs: Art 231 or 241.

name: Painting: Abstraction
desc: Exploration of painting proceeding from traditions of abstraction. Media will include acrylic and/or oil.
prereqs: Art 231 or 241
antireqs: Art 231 or 241

name: Visual Research Methods
desc: Students utilize arts-based research methods to formulate and develop an independent project. Projects normally will be completed using digital photography.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level.

name: Advanced Visual Research Methods
desc: Students pursue individually designed arts-based research projects, examine approaches to editing, sequencing, and presenting projects to an audience. Projects normally will be completed using digital photography.
prereqs: Art 361.
antireqs: Art 361.

name: Topics in Studio Research
desc: Studio-based introduction to contemporary and emerging creative practices. Topics may include: installation art, performance art, slip casting, or hybrid art forms.

name: Printmaking: Lithography
desc: An introduction to lithographic printmaking.

name: Printmaking: Screenprint
desc: An introduction to screenprinting.

name: Printmaking: Intaglio
desc: An introduction to intaglio printmaking.

name: Sculpture: Materials and Processes
desc: Technical and conceptual exploration of sculpture through materials and processes. This may include a range of methods such as mold-making, casting, assemblage, carving, welding, forging, riveting, time-based media, installation or digital media.
prereqs: Art 233.
antireqs: Art 233.

name: Sculpture: Concepts and Strategies
desc: Conceptual and professional exploration of sculpture introducing students to strategies and concepts to assist in research and problem solving. Approaches may include understanding object-hood, material as content, serial art, art movements impacting sculpture, public art, and sculpture and the market.
prereqs: Art 233.
antireqs: Art 233.

name: Professional Development
desc: Professional development activities, documentation and dissemination associated with working as a professional artist, including intellectual property, ethics, and the context of different art communities.
prereqs: 12 units of courses labelled Art.
antireqs: 12 units of courses labelled Art.

name: Art in Theory and Practice I
desc: Theories of art, critical methodologies, and aesthetics in the visual arts across history and cultures.

name: Studies in Contemporary International Art
desc: Study of recent international art practices from a range of perspectives in art criticism.

name: Topics in Art Education
desc: Exploration of topics in art education such as multiculturalism, creativity, developmental issues, or special needs learners.

name: Advanced Topics in Indigenous Art
desc: Advanced studio inquiry into Indigenous art developing students’ technical and conceptual skills. Explores advanced practices through topics that may include beading, quilling, and hide.
prereqs: Art 314.
antireqs: Art 314.

name: Advanced Topics in Digital Arts
desc: Advanced studio inquiry into digital art forms developing students’ technical and conceptual skills. Advanced exploration of digital media topics such as 2D graphics, 3D graphics, animation, motion capture, and modelling will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 313, 331, 319, 323, 334.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 313, 331, 319, 323, 334.

name: 3D Digital Imaging
desc: Creative research in 3D digital visualization and fabrication involving multimedia software and hardware. May include 3D printing, rapid prototyping, laser cutting, and computer controlled milling.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 313, 319, 323, 331, 334, 336.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 313, 319, 323, 331, 334, 336.

name: Advanced Topics in Photography
desc: Advanced studio inquiry into photography developing students’ foundational, technical and conceptual skills. Deeper exploration of topics in photography such as long term projects, narrative, projection, printing and alternative processes will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice. Activities will include workshops, studio practice and critique.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including Art 332 or 338.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including Art 332 or 338.

name: Advanced Topics in Drawing
desc: Advanced studio inquiry into drawing that develops foundational, technical and conceptual skills. Deeper exploration of topics in drawing such as mixed media, street art and socio-political issues will enable research and creation directed toward self-generated practice.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 341, 343, 345, 347, 349.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 341, 343, 345, 347, 349.

name: Painting: Expanded Field
desc: Students explore an expanded field of painting through installing and contextualizing their work. This may include pictorial, spatial, performative, and conceptual responses to site. Students may engage in collage/assemblage, shaped canvases, text/image, objects, paint, and unconventional materials.
prereqs: Art 231 or 241.
antireqs: Art 231 or 241.

name: Advanced Topics in Painting
desc: Advanced studio inquiry into painting developing students’ foundational, technical and conceptual skills. Deeper exploration of painting will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice. Activities will include workshops, studio practice and critique. Topics offered may include murals, gender and the body, figure and landscape, or materiality.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 351 or 353.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 351 or 353.

name: Topics in Studio Research and Critique
desc: A studio-based topics course that provides students with an opportunity for developing their exploration of contemporary and emerging creative research practices, contextualized via critique. Examples of topics: visiting artist, studio research, figure painting, visual research. Topics offered may include installation, research creation, site specific art.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including Art History 333.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including Art History 333.

name: Advanced Topics in Printmaking
desc: Advanced studio inquiry into printmaking developing students’ technical and conceptual skills. The course will explore advanced practices in areas such as lithography, screenprinting, intaglio and photomechanical print processes.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 373, 377, 379.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level, including 3 units from Art 373, 377, 379.

name: Sculpture: Mold Making and Casting
desc: An exploration of mold making and casting techniques in the realization of sculptural forms.
prereqs: Art 233.
antireqs: Art 233.

name: Advanced Topics in Sculpture
desc: Advanced studio inquiry into sculpture that develops technical and conceptual skills. Activities will include studio practice and critique enabling research creation directed toward self-initiated practice. Topics may include sculptural exploration of installation, performance, and site specific art.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 381 or 383.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 381 or 383.

name: Community-Based Art Experiences
desc: A seminar and field experience course introducing prospective educators to all facets of planning and implementing positive art experiences in a non-school setting.

name: Art in Theory and Practice II
desc: Examination and discussion of theoretical issues associated with current practice in art.
prereqs: Art 399 and admission to the BFA or BFA Honours in Visual Studies.
antireqs: Art 399 and admission to the BFA or BFA Honours in Visual Studies.

name: Advanced Topics in Media Arts
desc: Advanced studio inquiry into media art forms developing students’ technical and conceptual skills. Topics may include: sound and interactivity, immersive art, tele-arts and projection mapping that will enable research creation directed toward self-generated practice.
prereqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 323, 315, 317, 321.
antireqs: 15 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level including 3 units from Art 323, 315, 317, 321.

name: Computer Game Design
desc: The game design process will be explored, including a history of video games, genres, game mechanics, design documents, and a summary of the development process. The focus will be on design, rather than development, and the artistic and creative assets, rather than the software. Students will design a game and will create a playable prototype. The principles will be applicable to other sorts of games, and to media art in general.
prereqs: Art 251.
antireqs: Art 251.

name: Curriculum Building for Art
desc: Developing curriculum and program structures for formal and community art education. Program design includes current theory and practice and a field research component.
prereqs: 12 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 12 units of courses labelled Art at the 300 level or above.

name: Directed Study
desc: Independent studio research under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Independent studio research and production supported by a research paper for BFA Honours Visual Studies students, culminating in a Thesis Exhibition.
prereqs: Admission to the BFA Honours Visual Studies Program.
antireqs: Admission to the BFA Honours Visual Studies Program.

name: Honours Studio Research I
desc: Directed studio research and production for honours students.
prereqs: Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and consent of the Department.

name: Honours Studio Research II
desc: Further directed studio research and production for honours students.
prereqs: Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and Art 561.
antireqs: Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and Art 561.

name: Advanced Studio Research and Critique
desc: Advanced studio course that develops self-generated approaches to creative research and critique. Encourages engagement with contemporary and emerging practices and leads to critical fluency, contextualized via critique. Situated in an interdisciplinary setting, students can expect to encounter a wide range of themes and approaches to support their practice.
prereqs: Art 465.
antireqs: Art 465.

name: Studio Research
desc: Independent studio research for honours students.
prereqs: Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to Honours in Visual Studies and consent of the Department.

name: Professional Aspects of Art
desc: Examination and discussion of the issues associated with the professional aspects of surviving as an artist. Presentations by professional artists practicing in the field will form a major component of the course.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Art at the 400 level and admission to the BFA or BFA Honours in Visual Studies.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Art at the 400 level and admission to the BFA or BFA Honours in Visual Studies.

name: History of Art I
desc: Individual study: in consultation with the instructor, the student will select a research topic in art history or art criticism.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.

name: History of Art II
desc: Individual study: in consultation with the instructor, the student will select a research topic in art history or art criticism.
prereqs: Art 601.
antireqs: Art 601.

name: Critical Study and Research
desc: Individual study and research in the area of studio specialization, critical theory, methodological issues and/or historical topics.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.

name: Art Theory and Criticism
desc: Investigation of contemporary global art theory and criticism.
prereqs: Consent of the Department  of Art.
antireqs: Consent of the Department  of Art.

name: Research Methods in Art
desc: Introduces students to art making as a process of knowledge production and research creation.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.

name: Advanced Studio Practice
desc:
Individual study in studio, with seminar-based discussions in research area.
661.01. Advanced Studio Practice I
661.02. Advanced Studio Practice II 
661.03. Advanced Studio Practice III
661.04. Advanced Studio Practice IV
prereqs: Consent of the Department; courses must be taken sequentially.
antireqs: Consent of the Department; courses must be taken sequentially.

name: Pedagogy and Professional Practice
desc: Issues in professional practice and post-secondary teaching in visual art. Optional course.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.

name: Advanced Independent Studio research
desc: Theoretical and applied concepts in studio.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in the Department of Art.

name: Introduction to Art History I
desc: An examination of art and architecture before 1400  in relation to significant historical and cultural events.

name: Introduction to Art History II
desc: An examination of art and architecture after 1400 in relation to significant historical and cultural events.

name: Writing and Art History
desc: An introduction to the techniques and strategies of writing about art and cultural objects within the discipline of art history. Students develop and strengthen their writing skills in relation to addressing, evaluating, and assessing art.

name: Canadian Art History
desc: A critical analysis of the forms, objects, and practices that compose the art canon of northern North America. Organized thematically, this course covers the period of history ranging from European contact to the present day.

name: Topics in Art History and Visual Studies
desc: Key concepts and theories within the discipline of Art History. Topics may include: Feminist Art Histories; and Art and Social Critique.

name: History of Photography
desc: An examination of the development of photography as a technology, an art medium, and a way of envisioning the world. Historical antecedents of contemporary practices will be emphasized.

name: Medieval Art and Architecture
desc: An examination of art and architecture c. 400- 1400.

name: Survey of Far Eastern Art: India and Related Civilizations
desc: An examination of the art and architecture of ancient India and related civilizations, with special emphasis on Buddhist, Hindu and Islamic art.

name: Survey of Far Eastern Art: China and Related Civilizations
desc: An examination of the art and architecture of ancient China and related civilizations, with special emphasis on Confucian, Taoist and Buddhist art.

name: Renaissance Art
desc: An examination of the arts and architecture of Europe from c. 1300-1600.

name: Modern Art and Architecture
desc: A critical exploration of the development of and discussions about different art movements in relation to Modern Art and the avant-garde, addressing the historical circumstances that enabled the creation of selected art movements, which may include Impressionism, the Arts and Crafts Movement, Cubism, Surrealism, Pop Art, Fluxus, and Situationist.

name: Contemporary Art and Architecture
desc: An introduction to the socio-political approaches and critical theories that have informed art-making in the contemporary period. Examines artworks and their production, circulation, and reception through a variety of positions including gender, race, sexuality, and post-coloniality.

name: Topics in Art and Technology
desc: Examination of the development of art techniques and forms in relation to a variety of technologies. Topics may include the printing press, the history of video games, telematics, interactive art, and structures of surveillance.

name: A History of Design
desc: An introduction to the history of design including international movements, materials and technologies, production and consumption, and contemporary issues of critical design practice.

name: Baroque Art
desc: An examination of the art and architecture of Europe during the seventeenth century.

name: Eighteenth- and Nineteenth-Century Art
desc: An examination of the art and architecture in Europe and its colonies during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

name: Survey of Far Eastern Art: Japan
desc: An examination of the art and architecture of dynastic Japan, with special emphasis on Shinto and Buddhist traditions.

name: Indigenous Art of the Americas
desc: Historical and contemporary studies of indigenous cultural production within the geographic context of the Americas.

name: Art and Site
desc: An exploration of the ways in space, place, and context influence the meanings and values of art objects. Topics may include the history of displays, street art, art and the environment, and art in public spaces and sacred sites, and monuments.

name: Artist Case Study
desc: Introduction to case study methodology in Art History by way of an in-depth study of the work and life of a particular artist.

name: Topics in the History of Art
desc: An in-depth examination of a particular topic related to the study of Art History.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled Art History.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled Art History.

name: Architecture in the Western World Since 1900
desc: A survey of significant examples of modern architecture, defining their stylistic character in light of developments in technology, the history of ideas, and social and historical factors.

name: Art and the Body
desc: A critical analysis of the power dynamics inherent to forms of looking and representations of the body in a variety of historical periods and geographical locations. May include gendered representations, the medicalized body, the body in classical art, and displays of marginalized bodies.
prereqs: 3 units from Art History 331, 333, 357 and 3 additional units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 3 units from Art History 331, 333, 357 and 3 additional units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above.

name: Topics in Global Art
desc: An advanced exploration of topics and issues relevant to art-making and exhibitions within global contexts. Topics may include World’s Fairs, art biennales, outsider art, and souvenirs.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above.

name: Independent Research in Art History
desc: Independent research projects for advanced students in art history.
prereqs: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.
antireqs: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

name: Capstone in the History of Art
desc: A critical investigation of a particular subject related to the advanced study of Art History and Visual Culture.
prereqs: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.
antireqs: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

name: Directed Studies in Art History
desc: An independent research project conducted under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.
antireqs: 18 units of courses labelled Art History at the 300 level or above and consent of the Department.

name: Independent Study in Art History
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Conference Course in Art History
desc: Focuses on close examinations and discussions of students’ research and writing, with an emphasis on communicating informed research creation practices. The course will culminate in a conference presentation.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Thesis Development
desc: A reading and conference course in the student's research area.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: International Study Topics
desc: Group or individual study topics which involve international experience. Group study topics will vary from year-to-year.
prereqs: Third-year standing and consent of the Faculty.
antireqs: Third-year standing and consent of the Faculty.

name: Academic Field Placement
desc: Authorized academic field placements will vary from year-to-year.
prereqs: Acceptance to a recognized academic internship or field placement program and approval of the Faculty of Arts.
antireqs: Acceptance to a recognized academic internship or field placement program and approval of the Faculty of Arts.

name: Multidisciplinary Capstone
desc: Participation in a seminar focused on completing and presenting individual research projects that integrate the primary and secondary focus within a student’s multidisciplinary degree program.
prereqs: Admission to the BA Multidisciplinary and completion of 75 units.
antireqs: Admission to the BA Multidisciplinary and completion of 75 units.

name: Collaborative Learning and Peer Mentoring
desc: Study of learning theories and learning processes with practical experience through mentoring learners in an undergraduate course in the Faculty of Arts under the supervision of that course's instructor. Service-learning activities may include facilitating discussion in classrooms or online, discussing topics for term papers, organizing and assisting study groups, and/or coaching peers in their oral presentation or writing skills.
prereqs: 48 units and consent of the instructor.
antireqs: 48 units and consent of the instructor.

name: Research in Peer Mentoring and Higher Learning
desc: Students continue to support peers in their learning processes using a facilitative, collaborative approach. As part of their service-learning mentoring hours, students will assist new peer mentors to grow into their roles. Students will conduct either a textual or field research project related to their peer mentoring roles.
prereqs: Arts 507 or Communication and Culture 507 or Science 511 and consent of the instructor.
antireqs: Arts 507 or Communication and Culture 507 or Science 511 and consent of the instructor.

name: Theory and Practice of Teaching and Learning
desc: An introduction, exploration, and application of the theories and practices of teaching undergraduate students in the arts, humanities, and social sciences.
prereqs: Admission to MA, MSc or PhD program in the Faculty of Arts.
antireqs: Admission to MA, MSc or PhD program in the Faculty of Arts.

name: Ways of Making and Knowing
desc: Exploration of how human beings from diverse communities and cultures have sought to understand themselves and their environments through practices of invention, discovery, preservation, and craft.
prereqs: Admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy Program.

name: Questions for Our Time
desc: Exploration through interdisciplinary frameworks of urgent questions associated with such topics as technology, gender, digital cultures, creativity, politics, race, and the environment.
prereqs: Arts and Science Honours Academy 221 or 222 and admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy.
antireqs: Arts and Science Honours Academy 221 or 222 and admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy.

name: The Nature of Research
desc: Exploration of interdisciplinary modes of inquiry through case studies, with a consideration of how research and cultural frameworks create objects of knowledge and standards of evidence.
prereqs: Arts and Science Honours Academy 321 or 322 and admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy.
antireqs: Arts and Science Honours Academy 321 or 322 and admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy.

name: Capstone Seminar
desc: . A capstone seminar in which students reflect on their intellectual and experiential journeys from both disciplinary and interdisciplinary perspectives, and develop public-facing forms of mobilizing their research.
prereqs: Arts and Science Honours Academy 422 or 501 and admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy.
antireqs: Arts and Science Honours Academy 422 or 501 and admission to the Arts and Science Honours Academy.

name: Introduction to Canadian Studies
desc: An interdisciplinary examination of the social, cultural, ethnic, political, economic, national, and regional dimensions of Canada, past, present and future.

name: A Comparison of Canadian and American Cultures
desc: An interdisciplinary comparison of Canadian and American cultures and cultural assumptions. A variety of issues and contexts will be dealt with from historical and contemporary perspectives.

name: Introduction to Folklore: The Canadian Context
desc: Introduction to the academic study of folklore: basic terminology, folk groups, performance and applications with examples taken from the Canadian and Albertan context. Introduction to traditional genres of folkloristic expression and analyses of current folk groups and their folklore.

name: Canadian Cities
desc: Canadian urban life from an interdisciplinary perspective.

name: Gender, Race and Ethnicity in Canada
desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to gender, race and ethnicity in Canada to provide an understanding of race, ethnicity and gender as simultaneous and intersecting systems of relationship and meaning.

name: Topics in Canadian Studies
desc: An examination of selected social, cultural, ethnic, economic, political, regional, or national topics in Canadian Studies.

name: Approaches to Canadian Heritage
desc: Examines heritage commemoration, preservation and interpretation by involving students in support projects with local communities.  Projects involve the exploration of presentation methods; the use of oral, artifactual and other evidence in heritage projects; policy and planning issues, the cultural, social, political, ecological and theoretical dimensions of heritage; and the sharing of heritage with the wider public.

name: The Culture of the Calgary Stampede
desc: A particular phenomenon of Calgary - and western Canadian culture - is the Calgary Stampede. In this interdisciplinary course, students will gain an understanding of the rich and complex history, vision and operation of this major western festival.

name: Research in Selected Topics
desc: Supervised individual study of a topic in Canadian Studies.
prereqs: 3 units from Art 361, Communication and Media Studies 313, History 300, Political Science 399 or Sociology 313 and consent of the Department.
antireqs: 3 units from Art 361, Communication and Media Studies 313, History 300, Political Science 399 or Sociology 313 and consent of the Department.

name: Senior Seminar in Canadian Studies
desc: Advanced level seminar(s) in Canadian Studies, for examination of particular topics of special interest to senior students.
prereqs: 72 units, including 6 units from courses labelled Canadian Studies.
antireqs: 72 units, including 6 units from courses labelled Canadian Studies.

name: Honours Directed Study
desc: Directed study for Canadian Studies Honours students in their fourth year.
prereqs: Admission to the Canadian Studies Honours Program and 3 units from Art 361, Communication and Media Studies 313, History 300, Political Science 399 or Sociology 313.
antireqs: Admission to the Canadian Studies Honours Program and 3 units from Art 361, Communication and Media Studies 313, History 300, Political Science 399 or Sociology 313.

name: Honours Writing Seminar
desc: Will participate in sessions throughout the year that will normally be facilitated by the Honours Advisor.
prereqs: Admission to the Canadian Studies Honours Program and 3 units from Art 361, Communication and Media Studies 313, History 300, Political Science 399 or Sociology 313.
antireqs: Admission to the Canadian Studies Honours Program and 3 units from Art 361, Communication and Media Studies 313, History 300, Political Science 399 or Sociology 313.

name: An Introduction to Cultural Traditions
desc: A survey of Russian and Eastern European cultural history from the settlement of the Slavic peoples to the early twentieth century. Included will be such topics as the ethnic, linguistic, and cultural composition of the region; art and architecture of medieval Russia; the Enlightenment; national revival movements; literature, music and painting; modernism; the cultural efflorescence of the early Soviet period.

name: Beginners' Chinese I
desc: Basic concepts of the Chinese National Language. Reading and writing of characters, essentials of grammar, basic vocabulary, and oral drills on normal speech patterns.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Beginners' Chinese II
desc: Continuation of Chinese 205.
prereqs: Chinese 205.
antireqs: Chinese 205.

name: Intensive Beginners' Chinese
desc: Intensive development of conversational skills and the pronunciation of the Chinese National Language. Enhanced training in vocabulary acquisition, grammar and writing. For students with a background in a Chinese dialect.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Beginners I
desc: An introductory course in Chinese stressing oral and aural skills in an immersion setting.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Beginners II
desc: Continuation of Chinese 280.
prereqs: Chinese 280.
antireqs: Chinese 280.

name: Continuing Chinese I
desc: Further acquisition of Chinese characters, and the development of conversational skills through reading and discussion of selected Chinese texts. Structural analysis of normal speech patterns. Preparation of written assignments. A continuation of Chinese 207.
prereqs: Chinese 207.
antireqs: Chinese 207.

name: Continuing Chinese II
desc: Continuation of Chinese 301.
prereqs: Chinese 301.
antireqs: Chinese 301.

name: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Continuing I
desc: A continuing-level course in Chinese stressing oral and aural skills in an immersion setting.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Continuing II
desc: Continuation of Chinese 304.
prereqs: Chinese 304.
antireqs: Chinese 304.

name: Topics in Chinese Culture in an Immersion Setting
desc: An introduction to contemporary Chinese culture and functional Chinese language.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Topics in Chinese Civilization
desc: Distinctive features of Chinese civilization within the Asian context.

name: Intermediate Chinese I
desc: An intermediate course giving equal emphasis to receptive and productive language skills.
prereqs: Chinese 303.
antireqs: Chinese 303.

name: Intermediate Chinese II
desc: A continuation of Chinese 331.
prereqs: Chinese 331.
antireqs: Chinese 331.

name: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Intermediate I
desc: An intermediate-level course in Chinese stressing oral and aural skills in an immersion setting.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Chinese Language in an Immersion Setting Intermediate II
desc: Continuation of Chinese 334.
prereqs: Chinese 334.
antireqs: Chinese 334.

name: Introduction to Chinese Literature
desc: Introduction to Chinese literature through the reading and discussion of selected literary works.
prereqs: Chinese 303.
antireqs: Chinese 303.

name: Introduction to Chinese Language and Linguistics
desc: An overview of Chinese linguistics. Provides an introduction to linguistic concepts and topics to enhance understanding of the structure of the Chinese language.
prereqs: Chinese 207.
antireqs: Chinese 207.

name: Topics in Chinese Literature in Translation
desc: Introduces the literary tradition of China by means of reading the English translations of representative works. Examines the historical and cultural background, as well as literary forms and aesthetics.

name: Topics in Chinese Film
desc: Chinese film from the perspectives of film theory and political and cultural history. The course may concentrate on a specific director, a period, or a genre in Chinese film.

name: Chinese Language in the Cultural Context
desc: Study of the use and function of the Chinese language in its cultural context.
prereqs: Chinese 207 or consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Chinese 207 or consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Classical Chinese I
desc: An introduction to the grammar and vocabulary of the classical Chinese language. Readings of short texts selected from famous classical works.
prereqs: Chinese 303.
antireqs: Chinese 303.

name: Classical Chinese II
desc: Further study of the grammar and vocabulary of the classical Chinese language. Readings of short texts selected from famous classical works.
prereqs: Chinese 371.
antireqs: Chinese 371.

name: Advanced Chinese Conversation
desc: Development of Chinese oral communication skills through contemporary film, television programs and/or other audio materials.
prereqs: Chinese 333.
antireqs: Chinese 333.

name: Advanced Readings and Writing in Modern Chinese
desc: Development of Chinese reading and writing skills on the basis of newspapers, magazines, social commentary and/or literary works.
prereqs: Chinese 333.
antireqs: Chinese 333.

name: Chinese Language Learning and Teaching
desc: Addresses theories and practice in learning and teaching Chinese as a second/foreign language. Examines fundamental concepts and critical issues in the field such as learner strategies, motivation and teaching methods.
prereqs: Chinese 333.
antireqs: Chinese 333.

name: Selected Topics in Chinese Literature
desc: Selected readings on various literary topics, such as contemporary Chinese literature, the Chinese diaspora experience, or readings by specific authors.
prereqs: Chinese 403.
antireqs: Chinese 403.

name: Japanese-Chinese Cultural Relations
desc: Discussion of the cultural relations and influences between Japan and China. Topics may include cultural identities and cross-influences, literary and artistic traditions, writing systems.
prereqs: Chinese 303 or higher (excluding Chinese 317 and Chinese 355).
antireqs: Chinese 303 or higher (excluding Chinese 317 and Chinese 355).

name: Research Seminar
desc: Engages senior students as members of a collaborative research team. Independent research, discussion, group presentations.
prereqs: Chinese 403 or 431.
antireqs: Chinese 403 or 431.

name: Culture Foundations
desc: A critical and inter-disciplinary examination, via classic texts, of the Greco-Roman and Judeo-Christian Heritage of Western Civilization (e.g., Homer, Sophocles, Plato, Augustine). Focus on major ideas, principles and their implications within the time frame of the Ancient and Medieval periods (i.e., 3000 B.C.E.–400 C.E.) and in comparison with non-Western traditions.

name: Roads to Modernity
desc: A critical and inter-disciplinary examination, via classic texts (e.g., Chaucer, Machiavelli, Montaigne, Dante), of how the Greco-Roman and Judeo-Christian traditions were transformed into the Modern West. Focus on the major ideas, principles and their implications within the timeframe from the sixth to the sixteenth century and in comparison to non-Western traditions.
prereqs: Communication and Culture 201 or 301.
antireqs: Communication and Culture 201 or 301.

name: Modernity
desc: A critical and inter-disciplinary examination, via classic texts (e.g., Bacon, Hobbes, Locke, Marx, Woolf, Freud, Sartre), of the meaning of Modernity in Western and non-Western contexts. Focus on the major ideas, principles and their implications from the seventeenth to the twentieth century.

name: Contours of Contemporary Culture
desc: A critical and inter-disciplinary examination, via classic texts (e.g., Bettelheim, Wiesel, Arendt, Ellul, Marcuse, DeBeauvoir, hooks, Foucault, Camus, and Maslow), of how modernity has been transformed within the framework of an evolving global culture. Focus on the major ideas, principles and their implications within the time frame of the twentieth century to the present.

name: Introduction to Communication and Media Studies
desc: A general mapping of the field, with an emphasis on its breadth in the areas of media studies, communication of science and technology and rhetorical communication. General examination of how Communications Studies emerged during the twentieth century and how the field relates to issues of social and cultural change.

name: New Media
desc: An introduction to the social, political and cultural aspects of new media. Examines the social factors that influence the use of new media, as well as the effects of new media on different spheres of social life. Topics may include the historical development of new media; participatory cultures; copyright and Internet law; creative industries; and surveillance and governance in new media.

name: Communication Research Methods
desc: A critical introduction to communication research methods. Students will explore, practice and critique selected quantitative and qualitative research methods and perspectives on the processes of knowledge production.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.

name: Professional and Technical Communication
desc: An introduction to professional and technical communication in diverse media. Examines the rhetorical dimensions of workplace settings as well as the process of planning, composing and delivering professional and technical communication for various audiences.
prereqs: 24 units.
antireqs: 24 units.

name: Visual Communication and Culture
desc: Critical study of images in society. Topics may include formal image analysis; theories of the image; the politics and ethics of visual representation; portraiture and identity; advertising images; spectacle and modern media; war and propaganda imagery; circulation and the networked image; iconoclasm and censorship.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.

name: Rhetorical Communication
desc: An introduction to the basic principles of rhetorical theory, criticism and practice. Examines rhetorical perspectives on elements of communication such as argumentation, persuasion, audience, situation, genre and ethics. Students will apply rhetorical theory to the criticism of samples of public communication and will practice their rhetorical skills through in-class activities and assigned writing and oral presentations.
prereqs: Prerequisite or Corequisite: Communication and Media Studies 201.
antireqs: Prerequisite or Corequisite: Communication and Media Studies 201.

name: Critical Media Studies
desc: Emphasizes major critical approaches and theoretical foundations of media studies research. Explores the contexts in which these theories arose, identifies their major strengths and weaknesses and analyzes how critical theory engages the social world. Areas covered include the Frankfurt School, structuralism and semiotics, cultural studies, post-structuralism and feminist media studies.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.

name: Communications History
desc: A general survey of how various communication systems and practices developed through history and of the social contexts within which they emerged, transformed and adapted through time. Examines major technological developments in the history of human communication and uses theory to understand their origins and impacts on social organization and everyday life.

name: Introduction to Public Relations
desc: Public relations theory and practice, with a particular emphasis on Canadian examples. Focus on links between public relations and new media, ethical standards of practice, and critical perspectives on public relations as well as on the development of practical skills.

name: Critical Perspectives on Health and Science
desc: Examines the construction and communication of health and science as socio-cultural phenomena and interrogates the ways in which health and science issues are communicated, defined, represented and framed, particularly within contemporary media.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.

name: Special Topics in Communication and Media Studies
desc: Critical study of contemporary topics or issues related to communications media, technology, culture, or discourse. Past topics have included Gaming; Video Activism; Intellectual Property; Surveillance; Photography: A Social History; and Children and Media.

name: Advanced Research Methods
desc: An in-depth study of selected methods for social and cultural research. Students will design and carry out empirical research applying these methods.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 313.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 313.

name: Communication and Canadian Society
desc: Explores aspects of Canadian communication, including historical development, theoretical approaches, challenges posed by advances in technology, and policy questions such as media ownership, Canadian content requirements and the relationship between media and democracy.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 201.

name: Race, Representation, and Media
desc: Introduces critical race and intersectional feminist frameworks for examining representations of race and racialized identities in media culture(s) and texts. Emphasis on the production and circulation of racial discourse(s) in mass media, popular culture, and activist media.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 371.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 371.

name: Digital Rhetoric
desc: Rhetorical theory, criticism, production and editing of professional communication in a range of digital media, including websites, social media and other collaborative and multimedia platforms. Experiential learning through team projects that critique and develop an organization’s online content.
prereqs: 3 units from Communication and Media Studies 363, 383, 369.
antireqs: 3 units from Communication and Media Studies 363, 383, 369.

name: Rhetorical History and Criticism
desc: A study of rhetorical thought and action from selected periods, cultures and authors from the classical period to the modern age, with an emphasis on the interaction between rhetoric and philosophical, social and political change. Theories will be applied to the criticism of historical and contemporary public communication.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 369.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 369.

name: Popular Culture
desc: Introduces critical tools for deconstructing and evaluating the social significance of popular cultural texts, including music, television, film, advertising, memes and viral content. Particular focus on audience reception as a key method for understanding fan practices and subcultures
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 371.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 371.

name: Media and Cultural Industries
desc: Considers the role and nature of media and cultural industries, offering students understanding of their role in the production and circulation of popular culture and information. Industries typically examined are television, radio, newspapers and other print media, film, sound recording, book publishing and advertising.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 371.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 371.

name: Food Culture and Communication
desc: A theoretical and experiential introduction to food cultures as processes and products of communication. Examines how food is constructed and represented through text, film, television, art and tourism. Political and economic constructions of food culture, security and sustainability will also be explored.

name: Feminist Media Studies
desc: Introduces critical perspectives and practices of feminist media studies and interrogates how gendered, racialized and sexualized subjectivities are produced, circulated and consumed through media cultures and texts. A key focus will be relationships between power, media and identity.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 371.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 371.

name: Advanced Studies in New Media and Society
desc: Examines the nature, origins and social implications of new media with a focus on the Internet. Evolving forms of interpersonal, group and public communication based on the Internet will be assessed in terms of the role they play in identity formation, cultural integration, learning, political participation, commerce and work.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 203 and 371.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 203 and 371.

name: Environmental Media and Communication
desc: Examines the mutual entanglements of media, communication and the environment, with a particular focus on media representations of the environment and environmental risks. May also examine environmental issues related to communications technologies and global communications infrastructures.

name: Introduction to Acoustic Communications and Acoustic Ecology
desc: Concepts, techniques and applications of the fields of Acoustic Communications (the ways in which speech and music convey meaning) and Acoustic Ecology (the effects of sound in natural and human environments). These interdisciplinary areas weave together communication theory, cognitive psychology, sociology, musicology, physical sciences, health sciences and aesthetics.

name: Independent Research in Communication and Media Studies
desc: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Political Economy of Communication
desc: Examines power relations between public, government and commercial forces in communication. Looks at how media dynamics have shifted historically and how current policies, structures and institutions impact our daily media interactions.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 371 or 435.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 371 or 435.

name: Advanced Special Topics in Communication and Media Studies
desc: Advanced study of contemporary topics or issues related to communications media, technology, culture or discourse.
prereqs: 3 units from Communication and Media Studies 371 or 381 and admission to a major or minor program in Communication and Media Studies.
antireqs: 3 units from Communication and Media Studies 371 or 381 and admission to a major or minor program in Communication and Media Studies.

name: Experiential Learning in Communications and Media
desc: Supervised individual study through guided experiential learning. Opportunity provided to combine interests in communications research and theory with experiential learning opportunities in an organization or university unit. Involves a communication-related placement or project that engages students in critical reflection on community experience in the context of their formal education.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 201 and 3 units of a course labelled Communication and Media Studies and admission to a majors or minor program in the Department of Communication, Media and Film and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 201 and 3 units of a course labelled Communication and Media Studies and admission to a majors or minor program in the Department of Communication, Media and Film and consent of the Department.

name: Senior Project in BCMS/BFS
desc: An advanced research and experiential project incorporating academic research and media production. The project will be produced in a medium appropriate to the student's specialization: print, radio, television, video, film or digital media.
prereqs: 3 units from Communication and Media Studies 369, 371, 381; or 3 units from Film 321, 323, 331, 333; and first year of an applicable diploma program from SAIT or an approved equivalent, and admission to the Bachelor of Communication and Media Studies program or Bachelor of Film Studies program.
antireqs: 3 units from Communication and Media Studies 369, 371, 381; or 3 units from Film 321, 323, 331, 333; and first year of an applicable diploma program from SAIT or an approved equivalent, and admission to the Bachelor of Communication and Media Studies program or Bachelor of Film Studies program.

name: Capstone Seminar in Communication and Media Studies
desc: Explores the variety of ways in which communication builds social and cultural values with reference to a special topic. Completion of a major project that will integrate understanding of communication theory, history and methodology.
prereqs: 78 units, including Communication and Media Studies 313, 369, 371, 381 and admission to the BA in Communication and Media Studies.
antireqs: 78 units, including Communication and Media Studies 313, 369, 371, 381 and admission to the BA in Communication and Media Studies.

name: Honours Seminar
desc: Individual research and seminar activities (e.g., critiques, presentations, and peer reviews of drafts) to produce a proposal and a paper to be used as the basis for the Honours Thesis.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 313 and admission to the Honours Program.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 313 and admission to the Honours Program.

name: Honours Thesis and Seminar
desc: Supervised individual research and preparation of an honours thesis. Incorporating material from the Communication and Media Studies 595 paper to complete the honours thesis. Seminar activities include progress reports, peer reviews, and support for poster presentations and oral exams.
prereqs: Communication and Media Studies 595 and admission to the Honours Program.
antireqs: Communication and Media Studies 595 and admission to the Honours Program.

name: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Communication and Media Studies
desc: An overview of theories, problematics and approaches in communication and media.

name: Critical Media Studies
desc: Theories and perspectives in the study of media production, industries, genres, and reception.

name: Communication and Cultural Theory
desc: An examination of the major perspectives in communication and cultural theory through a historical analysis of classic works and an overview of contemporary approaches and applications.

name: Research Methods
desc: A survey of research methods appropriate to the study of communication and media.

name: Representation and Identity
desc: An investigation of various issues related to representation and identity, including but not limited to race, ethnicity, gender and sexuality.

name: Communications and Cultural Industries
desc: An analysis of the governmental and social contexts which inform the current development of telecommunications, communications, cultural industries and new media in Canada.

name: Social Contexts of Science and Technology
desc: Theoretical perspectives for understanding central debates in the study of science and technology in their social, political, cultural, and communication contexts.

name: Social and  Media Activism
desc: A critical overview of how digital media are being taken up by social justice movements and the implications of these new media practices in relation to politics and activism.

name: International Communication
desc: An examination of cultural/communication issues and practices in international contexts. Examines the role of media systems in processes of culture, development, and identity formation.

name: Methods in Film Studies
desc: An examination of key approaches to studying film, including its aesthetic, historical, and theoretical dimensions.

name: Media and Democracy
desc: An examination of the role played by media in democratic systems past and present. Draws from classic and contemporary democratic theory to explore the changing positions of traditional and new media, focusing on the interrelationships of media, political institutions and citizenship.

name: Communication and Health
desc: Critically exploring the concept of health through the lens of communication, examines cultural and media representations of health, along with questions of health and identity, health promotion and advocacy, health risk and regulation, and social movements.

name: Directed Studies
desc: A research project under the direction of a faculty member.

name: PhD Theory Seminar
desc: A seminar that enables PhD students to focus their research interests and to explore theories relevant to their areas of specialization.
prereqs: Admission to the Communication and Media Studies PhD program.
antireqs: Admission to the Communication and Media Studies PhD program.

name: Selected Topics in Communication, Media and Film
desc: A variety of communication, media and film topics based on faculty expertise.

name: Introductory Contemporary Dance II

antireqs: Dance 201.

An introduction to specific dance forms. Designed for non-Dance majors.
206.01 Ballroom Dance206.02 Latin Dance206.03 Tap Dance206.04 West African Dance206.05 Urban Dance206.06 South Asian Dance206.07 Dance for Musical Theatre

antireqs: Dance 221.

desc: An introduction to the principles of dance writing in combination with movement analysis skills. Focusses on the identification and articulation of one’s identity as a mover in the context of current and historical movement trends.

antireqs: Admission to the Dance major.

antireqs: Dance 267 or 231.

desc: Strategies of creation and composition are examined through theory and practice, with a focus on the invitation they extend to the audience, and in the context of the dance dramaturg’s facilitating role.
prereqs: Dance 333.
antireqs: Dance 333.

name: Dance Pedagogy: Community Populations
desc: An overview of the approaches to dance pedagogy for teaching varied community populations, including adults, seniors, mixed ability and pre-school children etc.

name: Dance Pedagogy: Children and Youth
desc: An overview of the approaches to dance pedagogy for teaching children and youth in public schools and studio contexts.

name: Dance Psychology
desc: An examination of the affective relationships between dance and the cognitive capacities: perception; memory; and learning.
prereqs: 9 units in Dance and/or Psychology.
antireqs: 9 units in Dance and/or Psychology.

name: Complementary Dance Training Practices II
desc: Focus on select methods of complementary training practices for improving dance performance.

antireqs: Dance 375.

desc: Critical dance theory and global dance forms.
prereqs: Dance 345 or 347.
antireqs: Dance 345 or 347.

name: Design and Production for Dance

prereqs: 60 units from the Field of Dance.
antireqs: 60 units from the Field of Dance.

name: Dance Teaching Practicum

name: Dance Performance Practicum IV

antireqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Dance.

desc: Further advanced study of the techniques of contemporary dance.

antireqs: Dance 433 and admission to the BFA Dance program.

antireqs: Dance 407 or 413, 78 units and consent of the Division Chair, Dance.

name: Special Topics in Dance
prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Dance.
antireqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Dance.

name: Creativity
desc: From the economy to the environment and from politics to entertainment, creativity is an endlessly renewable resource that offers benefits for all citizens and may well be the most important human element for our future. Students from all disciplines can investigate the practices and processes of creativity and explore the ways in which it can help enrich their lives.

name: Story
desc: An exploration of the elements of story present in the arts and beyond. Story is an exciting, creative, dynamic and universal form of human expression with the potential to engage and inspire students from across departments and disciplines.

name: Introduction to Acting I
desc: An introduction to creative resources and practices for the actor.

name: Introduction to Acting II
desc: An introduction to the actor’s interpretation and performance of texts for the theatre.
prereqs: Drama 209.
antireqs: Drama 209.

name: Introduction to Theatre Production
desc: An introduction to organizational principles of theatre production and technical theatre skills.

name: Introduction to Scenography
desc: An introduction to performance design and the disciplines within it: scenery, props, lighting, costumes and sound. Includes a study of the history of theatre design and space. Topics regarding contemporary notions of scenography will be explored, for example performance art, ritual, etc.

name: Introduction to the Study of Drama
desc: An introduction to the study of drama, theatre and performance.

name: Introduction to the Practice of Drama
desc: Continued study and practice of drama, theatre and performance.
prereqs: Drama 242.
antireqs: Drama 242.

name: Foundations of Acting I
