desc: Further development of an actor’s interpretation and performance of dramatic text for the stage through investigation of “Naturalism” and contemporary scene study.
prereqs: Drama 200 or 210, audition and consent of Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 200 or 210, audition and consent of Division Chair, Drama.

name: Foundations of Acting II
desc: A continued investigation of fundamental acting principles, continuing with contemporary contexts with an introduction to classical text.
prereqs: Drama 316 and one of 301 or 309.
antireqs: Drama 316 and one of 301 or 309.

name: Scenography I
desc: Basic scenography including set, props, lighting and costume design theory, process and technique for a variety of theatre forms and performance styles.

name: Foundations in Vocal Practice
desc: Foundations in vocal practice and development of the voice for live performance and public speaking.
prereqs: Drama 200 or 210, or consent of the Division Chair, Drama
antireqs: Drama 200 or 210, or consent of the Division Chair, Drama

name: Introduction to Stage Sound
desc: Basic principles of sound for the theatre: recording, reinforcement and reproduction techniques and methods used in creating a production design.
prereqs: Drama 223 and 225.
antireqs: Drama 223 and 225.

name: Foundations in Physical Practice
desc: Foundations in physical practice and development of the body for stylized-live performance and public engagement.
prereqs: Drama 200 or 210, or consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 200 or 210, or consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Graphics and Model Building for Theatre
desc: An introduction to graphic and model building techniques for the theatre designer.
prereqs: Drama 223 and 225.
antireqs: Drama 223 and 225.

name: Introduction to Lighting Design
desc: Basic principles of lighting for live performance including conceptualization of the lighting approach, techniques in communication and skills in execution of a performance.

name: Stage Management
desc: Principles of stage management.
prereqs: Drama 223 and 225.
antireqs: Drama 223 and 225.

name: History of the Theatre: Origins to the Mid-Eighteenth Century
desc: Theatre as an art and society phenomenon in selected cultures, emphasizing the development of Western traditions.

name: Seminar in Drama I
desc: An introduction to play and production analysis, developing skills in critical thinking, research, and oral and written communication about drama and theatre.
prereqs: Drama 243.
antireqs: Drama 243.

name: History of the Theatre: The Late Eighteenth Century to the Present
desc: Theatre as an art and social phenomenon in selected cultures, emphasizing the development of Western traditions from the late eighteenth century to the present.

name: Seminar in Drama II
desc: Further development of skills and competencies, and critical and interpretive skills.
prereqs: Drama 346.
antireqs: Drama 346.

name: Introduction to Canadian Theatre and Drama
desc: A study of Canadian theatre and performance using both formal and theoretical approaches.

name: Performance Creation in Applied Practices
desc: Explorations in personal/group creative process; facilitation of performance forms that may include sound and movement exploration, storytelling, ritual, mask, puppetry, and the collaborative creation of original performance. Emphasis will be placed on collaborative practices and group communication.

name: Theatre for Young Audiences I
desc: Study of the history and production of Theatre for Young Audiences (TYA), as well as the creation of original performances. Exploration of performances techniques specific to TYA content, forms and venues.
prereqs: Drama 209 and 210 or Drama 200.
antireqs: Drama 209 and 210 or Drama 200.

name: Theatre for Young Audiences II
desc: Advanced exploration of performances techniques specific to Theatre for Young Audiences (TYA) content, forms and venues. There is a performance component that includes tours in the community.
prereqs: Drama 365.
antireqs: Drama 365.

name: Introduction to Performance Creation
desc: Introduction to theatrical devising, focusing on the place of the individual within group creation contexts. Emphasis on personal physical awareness, expressivity, discovery of individual strengths and interests, and strategies for collaboration. Creation of short scenes for presentation.
prereqs: Admission to a Drama program.
antireqs: Admission to a Drama program.

name: Introduction to Playwriting
desc: Directed exercises in writing for the theatre; workshop sessions for developing and reworking material.
prereqs: 12 units Drama 200 or 210; 223, 225; and 240 or 243.
antireqs: 12 units Drama 200 or 210; 223, 225; and 240 or 243.

name: Topics in Theatre Practice
desc:
Special topics in the study of scenography and techniques for the scenographer.
381.04. Costume Techniques381.05. Scenic Art381.06. Theatre and Technology381.08 Stage Combat381.09 Voice for Stage and Public Speaking381.10 Mask and Puppetry

name: Practicum I
desc: Practical experience in the practice of disciplinary skills for performance or production.
prereqs: 12 units Drama 200 or 210; 223, 225; and 240 or 243 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: 12 units Drama 200 or 210; 223, 225; and 240 or 243 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Practicum II
desc: Further practical experience in the practice of disciplinary skills for performance or production.
prereqs: Drama 391 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 391 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Advanced Acting I
desc: Investigation and development of the actor’s process with a deepening rigour toward integrating vocal and physical modalities as they connect to dramatic text. A study of best practice in rehearsal, and introduction to live-public performance.
prereqs: Drama 300 or 302 or 310, 316, and 318, audition and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 300 or 302 or 310, 316, and 318, audition and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Introduction to Directing
desc: Fundamental approaches and skills in directing covered through theory and practice.
prereqs: 9 units Drama 223, 200 or 210, and 340 or 346.
antireqs: 9 units Drama 223, 200 or 210, and 340 or 346.

name: Advanced Acting II
desc: Intermediate practice of contemporary and stylized performance and acting techniques, in addition to personal practice associated with strong physical presence.
prereqs: Drama 409 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 409 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Directing I
desc: Extended practices in directing.
prereqs: Drama 411.
antireqs: Drama 411.

name: Vocal Practice for Performance
desc:
Intermediate development of vocal practice for live performance and public speaking. Further exploration of contemporary and classical text. 
416.01 Vocal Practice for Performance I 416.02 Vocal Practice for Performance II
prereqs: Drama 316 or both 301 and 302.
antireqs: Drama 316 or both 301 and 302.

name: Physical Practice for Performance
desc:
Development of physical presence on stage in association to contemporary and classical performance. Exploring physical readiness for live performance. 
418.01 Physical Practice for Performance I418.02 Physical Practice for Performance II
prereqs: Drama 318 or both 301 and 302.
antireqs: Drama 318 or both 301 and 302.

name: Intermediate Performance Creation
desc: Examines a broad cross-section of approaches, both historical and contemporary, to performance creation, physical theatre and theatrical devising. Conceptual and practical introduction to a wide range of distinct models for training and creation.
prereqs: Drama 368.
antireqs: Drama 368.

name: Playwriting
desc: Intermediate studies in writing for the theatre leading to the development of a one-act or full-length piece; workshop sessions for developing and rehearsing material.
prereqs: Drama 371 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 371 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Advanced Topics in Theatre Practice
desc: Immersive Theatre, Wearable Electronics for Costume Design, Design for Devised Theatre, Professional Practice and Career Preparation, Intimacy Coaching, Stage Combat Choreography, Site-Specific Theatre, Advanced Mask and Puppetry, Codes of Performance in Ancient Drama, and Directing, Design and Dramaturgy.
prereqs: 12 units in the field of Drama.
antireqs: 12 units in the field of Drama.

name: Advanced Topics in Theatre Studies
desc: Advanced study in various topics related to theatre studies. Possible topics include, but are not limited to: a particular historical period, genre, theme, playwright, or critical/theoretical approach. Recent topics have included Contemporary Women Playwrights and Gender, Sexuality, Modernism, and Performance.
prereqs: Drama 346.
antireqs: Drama 346.

name: Practicum III
desc: Further practical experience in the practice of disciplinary skills for performance or production.
prereqs: Drama 393 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 393 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Practicum IV
desc: Further practical experience in the practice of disciplinary skills for performance or production.
prereqs: Drama 491 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 491 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Advanced Acting III
desc: Advanced research and development of the actor’s process with attention to leadership within a performing ensemble. Further study of best practice in rehearsal with an increased commitment to the scope of roles within the context of live public performance.
prereqs: Drama 410 or 400 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 410 or 400 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Directing II
desc: Advanced directorial processes from ideas through presentation and documentation.
prereqs: 6 units Drama 410 or 6 units 411 and 413 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: 6 units Drama 410 or 6 units 411 and 413 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Advanced Acting IV
desc: Advanced research and development of the actor’s process with an attention toward the “Moderns” text, sub-text and deepened character analysis. Exploration and preparation for professional practice and auditions.
prereqs: Drama 400 or 509 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Drama 400 or 509 and consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Scenography IV
desc: Advanced set, props, lighting, and costume design theory, process and technique for a variety of theatre forms and performance styles.
prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Advanced Performance Creation
desc: Collaborative contribution to a focused creation process under the individual or team-based mentorship of a SCPA faculty member and/or guest artist. Students generate performance material towards a public presentation.
prereqs: Drama 468.
antireqs: Drama 468.

name: Directed Studies I
desc: Independent research under the direction of a faculty member.
prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Dramaturgy
desc: Theory and core principles of dramaturgy.
prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Advanced Topics in Drama
desc: Advanced studies exploring topics in Theatre Studies, Theatre Practice, or a combination.
prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Drama.
antireqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Drama.

name: Methods in Theatre Research
desc: Methods in research in the four areas of specialization in the MFA Theatre program.

name: Selected Problems in Directing I
desc: Investigates both the theoretical and executive functions of the director. Emphasis will be placed on contemporary theatre practices through research and conceptual design, rehearsal and creation methods, and the development and articulation of a personal approach to theatre-making.

name: Selected Problems in Directing II
desc: A continuation and deepening of the theories, techniques and practices from Drama 611. This course includes the research, development, rehearsal and presentation of a short pre-thesis project to be presented as part of the SCPA Alchemy Festival.

name: Collaboration in Performance Creation
desc: A practical exploration of approaches to collaboration across roles in performance and theatre creation such as playwriting, directing, design, dramaturgy, and acting.

name: Practicum in Design
desc: Supervised, experiential pre-thesis learning, designing lighting, sound, properties, set, or costumes for a production at the School of Creative and Performing Arts.

name: Artistic Research
desc: A series of supervised practical research tasks and exercises, leading to student-led completion of artistic or empirical project plans, ethics protocols, and research instruments for pre-thesis or early thesis exploration.

name: Dramaturgy
desc: An analytical and practical introduction to dramaturgical strategies of creation and composition with attention to their potential effect on audience experiences.

name: Special Topics
desc: Advanced studies in shifting topics such as Theory, Analysis, Praxis; Premodern Theatre; Theatre and Technology; Puppetry and Mask.

name: Studies in Modern Drama I
desc: Studies in the literature, history, theory and criticism of drama, theatre and performance from the late nineteenth century to the mid-twentieth century.

name: Studies in Modern Drama II
desc: Studies in the literature, history, theory and criticism of drama, theatre and performance from the mid-twentieth century to the present.

name: Pre-thesis in Playwriting
desc: Advanced exploration of dramatic structure and character development is accomplished through completion of a one-act play.

name: Topics in Human-Environment Interactions
desc: Exploration of the interactions between humans and environment at different time scales and in different regions. Geographically distinct regions are selected to highlight how humans have adapted to climate change and hazardous natural events. Past adaptations will be examined in the modern context.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Topics in Methods in Earth Science
desc: An introduction to field and laboratory methods used in earth surface processes research. Field excursions may involve travel and will provide the basis for laboratory exercises.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Research Project: Topics in Earth Science
desc: An original research project that focuses on earth surface processes and may target local, regional, or global issues. Participants will be exposed to oral and written communication, field sampling techniques and strategies, laboratory techniques, strategies and limitations, and relevant statistical analysis and graphic communication.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Research in East Asian Languages Studies
desc: A research-oriented seminar to synthesize students' training in East Asian languages and cultures and bring it to bear on a particular subject in Chinese and/or Japanese, or on the relation between East Asian languages and their respective cultures.
prereqs: Admission to the BA in East Asian Language Studies and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Admission to the BA in East Asian Language Studies and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Understanding Contemporary East Asia
desc: An introductory exploration of the cultures of China, Japan, and Korea that outlines their shared characteristics as well as highlighting their differences. Subjects covered include physical environment, history, philosophy, social and political order, economy, and arts.

name: Issues and Methods in East Asian Studies
desc: Contemporary social, philosophical, economic, political and/or international issues within East Asia and methodologies for analysis of the basis for interactions among East Asian countries will be presented in-depth.
prereqs: East Asian Studies 201 and one of Chinese 317 or Japanese 317.
antireqs: East Asian Studies 201 and one of Chinese 317 or Japanese 317.

name: Principles of Microeconomics
desc: Principles of choice under scarcity and the role of institutions, especially markets, for the production and distribution of goods and services: what and how much gets produced, how is it produced, and who gets what is produced.

name: Principles of Macroeconomics
desc: Measurement of economic activity, economic growth, money and financial systems, international economy and exchange rates, business cycles, unemployment and inflation, and macroeconomic policies.

name: Engineering Economics
desc: The basic tools and methodology of engineering economic studies. Topics include investment decisions, theory of replacement, economies of scale, externalities, social decision making and government regulation. Examples are drawn from engineering projects.
prereqs: Admission to the Schulich School of Engineering with second-year standing or higher.
antireqs: Admission to the Schulich School of Engineering with second-year standing or higher.

name: Intermediate Economic Theory - Microeconomics I
desc: Economic methodology, consumer theory, theory of the firm, competitive markets, efficiency, and the role of economics in public policy.
prereqs: Economics 201 and 203; and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.
antireqs: Economics 201 and 203; and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

name: Intermediate Economic Theory - Macroeconomics I
desc: Determination of national output, unemployment, interest rates, inflation, and exchange rates. Analysis of short-term economic fluctuations, the role of expectations and stabilization policies.
prereqs: Economics 201 and 203; and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.
antireqs: Economics 201 and 203; and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

name: Computer Applications in Economics
desc: Use of spreadsheets for economics applications, including project evaluation with financial-economic functions, oil and gas prospect evaluation, investment portfolio management with database functions, database retrieval, and various topics in micro and macroeconomics.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: The Global Trading System
desc: Introduction to the theory of international trade; provides a basis for examining Canadian trade policy, and regional and world trade institutions such as the WTO and NAFTA. Topics include: tariffs, non-tariff barriers and enhancements, countervail and anti-dumping action, multinational enterprises and international joint ventures.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: Natural Gas Markets
desc: Operation of the natural gas industry in North America. Economics of exploration, development, production, marketing and transportation of natural gas. Impact of government regulations and deregulation.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: Petroleum Economics
desc: Crude oil production and markets in North America and globally. Refining economics and markets for refined products. Government policy including royalty regimes, trade quotas, transport infrastructure, conservation and the environment.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: Electricity Markets
desc: Economic analysis of the deregulated electric power industry including the pricing of power, energy and capacity, power supply and demand, market structure, market architecture, and the design and testing of market rules.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: Development Economics
desc: An introduction to developing economies: the meaning, significance and purpose of economic development, major theories of economic development, economic problems of developing countries.
prereqs: Economics 201 and 203.
antireqs: Economics 201 and 203.

name: Canadian Economic History
desc: The growth and development of the Canadian economy in relation to the endowment of natural resources, changing market conditions and technology, and Canadian public policy.
prereqs: Economics 201 and 203.
antireqs: Economics 201 and 203.

name: Money and Banking
desc: Operation of financial markets and institutions: the principles of money creation, interest rate determination, and central banking.
prereqs: Economics 201 and 203.
antireqs: Economics 201 and 203.

name: Economic Analysis of Law
desc: An introduction to the relationship between law and economics. Economic theory will be used to analyze property and tort law.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: The Economics of Social Problems
desc: Contribution that economic analysis can make to the understanding of selected current social issues such as poverty, aging, crime, drug abuse and discrimination.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: Chinese Economy
desc: Survey of the economic institutions and processes shaping the Chinese economy, including but not limited to fiscal and monetary policy, financial institutions and financial sector reforms, the restructuring of state-owned enterprises, and the provision of social welfare.
prereqs: Economics 201 and 203.
antireqs: Economics 201 and 203.

name: Canadian Public Finance
desc: Examination of the institutions behind and economic rationale for Canadian government policy relating to public expenditures and taxation. Topics include the history and present structure of government spending and taxation, tax expenditures, the budgetary process, inter-jurisdictional issues, and program design.
prereqs: Economics 201 and 203.
antireqs: Economics 201 and 203.

name: Intermediate Economic Theory - Microeconomics II
desc: Intertemporal choice and choice under uncertainty. General equilibrium and the welfare theorems. Public and social choice theory. Market failures: imperfect competition, externalities, public goods, and informational asymmetries.
prereqs: Economics 301 and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.
antireqs: Economics 301 and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

name: Intermediate Economic Theory - Macroeconomics II
desc: Macroeconomic analysis based on microeconomic foundations. Analysis of short-term economic fluctuations under flexible and sticky prices, and the role of government policies. Theories of long-term economic growth.
prereqs: Economics 303 and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.
antireqs: Economics 303 and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

name: Economic Analysis of Transportation
desc: Modal choice by passengers, location choice by firms, capital investment choice. Cost, demand, and market structure related to the determination of transportation rates. Cost/benefit analysis of transportation projects. Analysis will be related to contemporary aspects of ocean shipping, air, rail, trucking, pipelines and urban transportation.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: Game Theory and Strategic Thinking for the Social Sciences
desc: Principles of game theory utilizing a non-mathematical and intuitive approach. Strategic reasoning and the use of game theory to explain social interaction. Game theory analysis is illustrated using applications and examples from economics and other social sciences.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: Economics and the Environment
desc: Analysis of environmental problems from an economic perspective. Efficient allocation of resources and its implications for air and water quality, waste management, biodiversity and endangered species will be addressed from local as well as global perspectives.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: The Economics of Health
desc: Theories and evidence regarding demand for health and health care, consumer and physician behaviour, asymmetric information in health care markets, and economic evaluation of health care programs.
prereqs: Economics 201.
antireqs: Economics 201.

name: Introduction to Mathematical Economics I
desc: Mathematics for economics with an emphasis on economic modeling and equilibrium analysis. Multivariate calculus including comparative statics, unconstrained and constrained optimization, and their applications to resource allocation problems.
prereqs: Economics 201, 203 and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.
antireqs: Economics 201, 203 and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265 or 275.

name: Introduction to Mathematical Economics II
desc: Application of linear algebra to economic analysis and optimization. Integration and differential equations and their application in economic analysis.
prereqs: Economics 387 and Mathematics 211.
antireqs: Economics 387 and Mathematics 211.

name: Introduction to Econometrics
desc: Two-variable and multi-variable linear regression models are introduced, developed and evaluated. Topics include basic data manipulation, econometric estimation of economic relationships, model specification and evaluation, hypothesis testing, and binary variables.
prereqs: Economics 201, 203, Statistics 213 and 217.
antireqs: Economics 201, 203, Statistics 213 and 217.

name: Introductory Topics in Economics
desc: Examination of a particular topic. Examples include the economics of sports, the economics of the wine industry, and the economics of popular music.
prereqs: Economics 201 and 203.
antireqs: Economics 201 and 203.

name: Public Sector Economics: Expenditures
desc: Theory of government spending. May include the nature of public goods and externalities, the pricing of public services, causes of growth of public expenditures, expenditure incidence, social insurance, social decision procedures, and political and bureaucratic influences.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: Public Sector Economics: Taxation
desc: Theory of taxation. May include the rationale for and the incentive effects of taxation, efficiency and equity aspects of taxation, partial and general equilibrium tax incidence, open economy effects, choice of governing instruments, and tax reform.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: Political Economy of Public Policy
desc: Introduction to the economic foundations of political economy and economic models of public sector policy formation. May include the role of institutions in policy design, theories of bureaucracy, political business cycles, the formation and behaviour of interest groups, and the strategic use of government debt.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: Computational and Data Methods in Economics
desc: Economic application and utilization of computational methods, programming, and data management. Introduction and use of programming in economic analysis, examples include VBA, R, Python, Mathematica, and MATLAB.
prereqs: Economics 311, 357, 359 and 395.
antireqs: Economics 311, 357, 359 and 395.

name: International Macroeconomics
desc: Foreign exchange markets, and international macroeconomic connections with trade in assets as well as goods and services. May include: alternative exchange rate regimes; monetary and fiscal policy responses to problems of unemployment and inflation; balance of payments adjustment mechanisms; international debt; and Euro-dollar markets.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: International Trade
desc: The general equilibrium treatment of the gains from trade, comparative advantage and trade patterns provides a basis for examining topics such as: trade policy under imperfect competition, trade policy and the environment, trade policy and economic growth, and preferential trading arrangements.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: Energy Economics and Policy
desc: Microeconomic analysis of the allocation of energy resources with a focus on policy issues including the environment, OPEC, national security, price and entry regulation, market design, and the potential for new energy sources.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.

name: Advanced Electricity Markets
desc: Market design of electricity markets; transmission regulation, investment and pricing; ancillary service demand, procurement, and regulation; retail competition; and distribution and distributed generation.
prereqs: Economics 329, 357, 359 and 471.
antireqs: Economics 329, 357, 359 and 471.

name: Labour Economics
desc: Economic analysis of migration, labour force participation, education, fertility, human resources policy, and the measurement and treatment of unemployment.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: The Economics of Financial Markets
desc: Basic functions and structure of financial markets. Economic analysis of trading strategies in financial markets and determinants of equilibrium prices. Institutional features, and analysis, of bond, stock, options, forward and futures markets.
prereqs: Economics 311, 341, 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 311, 341, 357 and 359.

name: Cost-Benefit Analysis
desc: Theoretical basis for social cost-benefit analysis, appraisal techniques for investment projects and public policies, and selected applications.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: The Economics of Business Fundamentals
desc: The application of microeconomic theory to business practice with a focus on accounting and finance practice. Critical assessment of financial statements, financial markets, corporate finance, and project evaluation.
prereqs: Economics 311, 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 311, 357 and 359.

name: Industrial Organization
desc: Behaviour of firms in imperfectly competitive markets. May include the theory of strategic competition; dynamic price competition and tacit collusion; product differentiation, product selection, and preemption; entry deterrence and capacity competition; information, reputation, and predation; the economics of research and development; international trade and imperfectly competitive markets.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: Economics of Natural Resources
desc: Application of economic theory to the problems of natural resource pricing, allocation and conservation. Rent theory, location theory, intertemporal maximization. Natural resource policy formulation. Contemporary Canadian resource problems.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: Regulatory Economics
desc: An introduction to economic regulation, its rationale, form and effects with a focus on the economic theory of regulation and on the practice, structure, and evolution of Canadian regulatory institutions.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 471.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 471.

name: Experimental Economics
desc: Introduces students to the use of and insights gained from experiments in economic research. As part of the course, students will be participating in a variety of in-class experiments.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.

name: Behavioural Economics
desc: Major factors underlying economic behaviour including: various views of the role of rationality in economic analysis and in the economic decision making of individuals and institutions; determinants of individual preferences and decision making procedures; the experimental analysis of economic behaviour; inter-relations between the operation of the economic system and feelings of subjective well-being.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: History of Economic Thought
desc: Traces the evolution of economic ideas from the earliest times up to and including the contributions of the classical economists and Marx. Emphasis will be on understanding these contributions both in terms of their historical context and their relationship to present-day theories and controversies.
prereqs: Economics 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 357 and 359.

name: Economics of the Welfare State
desc: The focus is on ideas and economic analysis relevant to understanding the economics of the welfare state, where issues of income redistribution and social insurance are central.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.

name: Environmental Economics
desc: Applies microeconomic theory to the examination of market failures as the source of environmental problems, and to designing and evaluating environmental policies to correct them.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.

name: Economics of the Movie Business
desc: Applies microeconomic theory to the motion-picture industry, focusing on how information and extreme uncertainty shape the structure of economic transactions. The historical and institutional illustrations are set in the context of Hollywood.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.

name: Managerial and Decision Economics
desc: Systematic economic analysis in managerial decision-making. Application of practical ideas to business decisions, integrating global business issues and practices with conceptually rigorous economic analysis.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.

name: Empirical Energy Economics
desc: Students will study and learn how to apply methods of data analysis that are particularly useful in the context of energy economics.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359, 395 and 427.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359, 395 and 427.

name: Intermediate Econometrics
desc: Theory and application of the multivariable linear regression model in time-series, panel data and limited dependent variable models. Least squares and maximum likelihood estimation. Identification issues, fixed and random effects, and instrumental variables.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359, 395; and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265, or 275.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359, 395; and 3 units from Mathematics 249, 265, or 275.

name: Advanced Econometrics
desc: Advanced application of statistics and mathematical modeling to make inferences and estimate the magnitude of causal effects.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359, 495 and Mathematics 211.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359, 495 and Mathematics 211.

name: Intermediate Topics in Economics
desc: Examination of a particular topic. Examples include advanced game theory, ethics and economics, water resources, and selected topics from other fields of economics.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 395.

name: World Oil Economics
desc: Analysis of the world oil industry in the post-World War II period.
prereqs: Economics 328, 357, 359 and 471.
antireqs: Economics 328, 357, 359 and 471.

name: Trade, Growth and the Environment
desc: Advanced examination of the linkages between international trade, the environment, and economic growth.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359, 395 and 3 units from Economics 425, 475 or 487.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359, 395 and 3 units from Economics 425, 475 or 487.

name: Monetary Theory
desc: A survey of recent work in monetary theory with primary emphasis on financial issues.
prereqs: Economics 341, 357 and 359.
antireqs: Economics 341, 357 and 359.

name: Advanced Microeconomic Theory
desc: Advanced study of optimal decision rules, equilibrium, and efficiency. Partial and general equilibrium, fundamental welfare theorems, social choice theory, and market failures including market power, public goods, externalities, and asymmetries of information.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 389.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 389.

name: Advanced Macroeconomics
desc: Methodological principles and models that underlie modern analysis of macroeconomics. Advanced study and modeling of the determination of aggregate economic activity and its fluctuations, stabilization policy (fiscal and monetary), the determinants of economic growth, the effects of policy on economic growth, and unemployment and the labour market.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359, 389 and 395.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359, 389 and 395.

name: Competition Policy
desc: The law and economics of competition policy. An examination of the economics, jurisprudence and history of competition policy towards mergers, price fixing, vertical restraints, and monopolization, primarily in Canada and the United States.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359 and 471.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359 and 471.

name: Advanced Topics in Economics
desc: Examination of a particular topic. Examples include trade policy, monetary economics, time-series econometrics, and analysis of current issues in other fields of economics.
prereqs: Economics 357, 359, 395 and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Economics 357, 359, 395 and consent of the Department.

name: Computational Optimization and Economic Applications
desc: Explores the theory and numerical implementation of mathematical programming, covering basic classes of optimization problems — linear programming, non-linear programming and complementarity problems — as ways to operationalize models of individual choice and decentralized equilibrium behaviour from economics. Applications will vary.

name: Political Economy
desc: Provides a selective overview of modern political economy.  Gives an introduction to the basic theoretical models, empirical methodologies, and substantive findings in political economy. Covers theoretical and empirical research and the links between the two. Also treats a number of selected topics on the research frontier.

name: Special Topics in Economics
desc: Topics will vary from year-to-year. Consult the timetable or the Department for the topics available in a given year.

name: Econometrics
desc: Provides a foundation of econometric theory relevant for empirical work in economics. Covers classical estimation and inference procedures, including linear regression, linear instrumental variables, differences-in-differences, and linear panel data techniques. Also covers the problem of causality and identification in empirical economics.
prereqs: Admission to the Master of Arts Economics program or permission of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the Master of Arts Economics program or permission of the Department.

name: Empirical International Trade
desc: Examines issues from the economic literature on international trade. Focuses on quantitative and empirical analysis. Specific topics include the factor content of trade, firm level and multinational behaviour, empirical testing of political economy determinants of protection, and assessing the environmental impact of trade agreements.

name: International Trade
desc: Focuses on the microeconomic aspects of international economics with emphasis on general equilibrium models commonly employed in international economics. Specific topics covered include theories of international specialization and exchange, trade policy and economic welfare, international factor movement, trade and growth, under both perfect competition and imperfect competition, and selected problems of trade policy in the international trading system.

name: Energy Economics
desc: Applies the tools of microeconomics, institutional economics, and econometrics to energy markets and policies. Focuses on empirical studies of the energy business including markets for natural gas, crude oil, gasoline, electricity and coal.

name: Labour Economics
desc: Emphasizes empirical implementation of theoretical models through the use of data and econometrics. Topics include labor supply theory, search theory, wage determination theories, and numerical methods for the estimation of dynamic models.

name: Regulatory Economics
desc: An in-depth study of regulatory economics, defined as price and entry regulation. Price and entry regulation occurs when the state restricts who can provide services and approves the terms of service. A considerable part of the course will address regulatory restructuring in network industries, with case studies on electricity reform, local telecommunications, and pipelines.

name: Financial Economics
desc: A review of  the main themes of financial economics and an introduction of  a number of frontier ideas that have marked the recent evolution of the discipline. The main focus is on asset pricing and the application of financial econometrics to modelling and prediction of financial data.

name: Empirical Public Economics
desc: Focuses on empirical research on the economics of the public sector, including material on taxation, public expenditures and social insurance. Gives a broad overview of this growing field and prepares for research in public economics.

name: Redistribution and Social Insurance
desc: A focus on the economics of public expenditure programs designed to redistribute income or to provide social insurance against risks faced by households.

name: Public Revenue Analysis
desc: A focus on the revenue side of public finance, primarily in the form of taxation. The equity and efficiency aspects of different taxes are considered, as is optimal tax design. Possible topics include the taxation of labour and capital, the impact taxation on savings and risk taking, and environmental and resource taxation.

name: Cost/Benefit Analysis
desc: Theoretical and applied aspects of the use of cost-benefit techniques and applied welfare analysis in the evaluation of investment projects and public policies.

name: Microeconomic Theory
desc: Introduction to advanced microeconomic theory. Topics include consumer theory, theory of the firm, general equilibrium, uncertainty, game theory, and informational economics.
prereqs: Admission to the Master of Arts Economics program.
antireqs: Admission to the Master of Arts Economics program.

name: Macroeconomic Theory
desc: Introduction to the analysis of macroeconomics at an advanced level. Provides an overview of theories addressing the major questions of macroeconomic phenomena. Some coverage of applied topics, such as economic growth and government policy.
prereqs: Admission to the Master of Arts Economics program.
antireqs: Admission to the Master of Arts Economics program.

name: Behavioural Economics
desc: Survey of research incorporating psychological evidence into economics. Topics include fairness, altruism, prospect theory, self-control, biases in probabilistic judgment, mental accounting, and the relationship between markets, incentives, and attention and various cognitive processes.

name: Industrial Organization
desc: A focus on market power: its acquisition, maintenance, and exercise. Both theory and application, with an emphasis on how industrial organization does, and should, inform competition policy and antitrust law, will be examined.

name: Empirical Industrial Organization
desc: Firm behaviour in oligopolistic markets, as well as consumer and firm behaviour in environments with asymmetric information. Strong emphasis on combining economic models with econometric techniques to answer economic questions. Models of demand and supply, discrete static and dynamic games, production function estimation, single agent dynamic models and matching models.

name: Natural Resource Economics
desc: Examines economic models of the structure and nature of natural resource industries and their interaction with the rest of the economy. Includes non-renewable and renewable resources and applies methods from capital theory, growth theory, public economics, and industrial organization to the study of natural resources.

name: Environmental Economics
desc: Environmental economics describes the ways in which people interact with their natural environment and the policies that best achieve society's goals in this context. Topics vary from year-to-year and may include benefit-cost analysis, non-market valuation, choice of policy instruments, environmental taxation, trade growth and the environment, global warming and international environmental treaties.

name: Health Economics
desc: An overview of topics in health economics. An introduction to economic principles and techniques used in analyzing and planning health policy, in particular the delivery of health services, and for understanding the health behaviour of individuals.

name: Research Methods I
desc: Survey of research methods in economics. For course-based MA students.

name: Research Methods II
desc: Survey of research methods in economics. For course-based MA students.

name: Research Methods III
desc: Master's research project. Identify an interesting and feasible research question, carry out an extensive literature review of the problem area, develop an economic/econometric model to address the problem, identify and collect appropriate data for empirical research.
prereqs: Admission into the Master of Arts Economics (course-based) program.
antireqs: Admission into the Master of Arts Economics (course-based) program.

name: Research Methods IV
desc: Master's research project. Continuing from Research Methods III, the economic/econometric model is fully developed with specific attention to identification issues and testable hypotheses. Appropriate econometric analyses, validation and testing are carried out, leading to a research paper reporting the problem, the model and the results.
prereqs: Admission into the Master of Arts Economics (course-based) program.
antireqs: Admission into the Master of Arts Economics (course-based) program.

name: Advanced Econometrics I
desc: Devoted to rigorous treatment of asymptotic theory as it applies to econometric practice. Provides a detailed treatment of the theory and practice of classical estimation procedures, including linear regression and instrumental variables, Maximum Likelihood, the Generalized Method of Moments, as well as an extension to simulation-based methods. The theory of hypothesis testing is also covered.
prereqs: Admission to the PhD program in Economics.
antireqs: Admission to the PhD program in Economics.

name: Advanced Microeconomic Theory I
desc: Introduction to advanced microeconomic theory. Topics include consumer theory, theory of the firm, and general equilibrium.

name: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory I
desc: Introduction to the basic structure of the dynamic general equilibrium framework that forms the backbone of most modern macroeconomics research. Selected topics include growth, business cycles, and monetary and labor economics.

name: Advanced Econometrics II
desc: Focuses on the problem of causality and identification of treatment effects in empirical work in Economics. Topics include but are not limited to randomized trials, causality, instrumental variables, difference in differences, regression discontinuity designs. Students are introduced to empirical applications of these different approaches.
prereqs: Economics 705.
antireqs: Economics 705.

name: Advanced Topics in Econometrics
desc: Studies cutting edge econometric tools used to evaluate the impacts of policies, extrapolate their effects to new environments, and predict the effects of policies that have never been tried. Methods from both the structural and treatment effect paradigms of policy evaluation will be considered.
prereqs: Economics 705.
antireqs: Economics 705.

name: Trade, Growth and the Environment I
desc: Covers relevant theoretical work on the environmental consequences of trade liberalization and economic growth, and the relationship between resource use and globalization, focusing on newly published research.  Participants are expected to present and discuss research. The specific choice of topics will be made based on research interests of the class.

name: Trade, Growth and the Environment II
desc: Covers relevant empirical work on the environmental consequences of trade liberalization and economic growth, and the relationship between resource use and globalization, focusing on newly published research.  Participants are expected to present and discuss research. The specific choice of topics will be made based on research interests of the class.

name: Advanced Microeconomic Theory II
desc: Building on Economics 707, a comprehensive treatment of game theory, the economics of uncertainty and information, and the theory of incentives will be introduced.  Other topics may be included as time and interest allow.
prereqs: Economics 707.
antireqs: Economics 707.

name: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory II
desc: Building on Economics 709, a survey of the ideas, controversies, and techniques that constitute modern macroeconomics. The principal issues it covers lie at the heart monetary and fiscal policy and of such important social problems as business cycles and unemployment. The empirical study of key issues raised in theoretical and political debates is also emphasized.
prereqs: Economics 709.
antireqs: Economics 709.

name: PhD Research Workshop
desc: Survey of research methods in economics.
prereqs: Admission to the PhD program in Economics.
antireqs: Admission to the PhD program in Economics.

name: PhD Research Workshop II
desc: Survey of research methods in economics.
prereqs: Economics 791 and admission to the PhD program in Economics.
antireqs: Economics 791 and admission to the PhD program in Economics.

name: Introductory Seminar
desc: An intensive introduction to the field of English emphasizing critical reading and writing as well as discussion. Expectations for writing and research will be higher than in other junior English courses. Includes the study of at least one text by an Indigenous author.

name: Literature and Society
desc: An examination of the relationship of literature to the world around us, with instruction in close reading and critical writing. Considers how literature as a cultural practice responds to and reflects its social context. Includes the study of at least one text by an Indigenous author.

name: Studies in Genre
desc:
A study of the conventions of a genre, with emphasis on close reading and critical writing skills. Includes the study of at least one text by an Indigenous author.
253.01 Short Fiction 253.02 Poetry 253.03 Novel 253.04 Drama 253.05 Non-fiction

name: Introductory Creative Writing
desc: Instruction in the rudiments of craft for poetry, scripts, and fiction, emphasizing the centrality of reading and revision to literary composition.

name: Introduction to Contemporary Theory
desc: An examination of the claims and assumptions of a range of contemporary critical practices, such as formalism, structuralism, deconstruction, feminism and gender studies, new historicism, psychoanalytic criticism, and cultural and ideological critique. Includes sustained engagement with original theoretical texts.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled English.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled English.

name: Theories for Reading
desc: An examination of contemporary critical and cultural theories and their practical applications to reading. Students will learn models of critical reading and gain experience applying them to a variety of literary and cultural texts.

name: Literature Before 1700
desc: A survey of representative works of literature in English from the Middle Ages through 1700.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled English.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled English.

name: Literature After 1700
desc: A survey of representative works of literature in English from 1700 to the Present.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled English.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled English.

name: Literature and the Environment
desc: An examination of the field of nature writing, environmental literature and ecological literary criticism.

name: Shakespeare and Performance
desc: A consideration of Shakespeare’s plays that pairs representative works with stage and/or film adaptations.

name: Comics
desc: An examination of the formal, historical, and social aspects of comics (comic strips, comic books, and graphic novels). Topics to be examined include the historical development of the comic form; formal analysis of the properties of comics; and the significance of comics in the contemporary media landscape.

name: Experiential Learning and Reading
desc: Approaches literary study through theories and practices of experiential learning. Incorporates multiple forms of critical written reflection on assigned literary texts and on reading as a form of experiential learning.

name: Literature and Community
desc: Focuses on the literary treatment of an issue relevant to the larger community. Combines critical and literary readings with service in a community organization.

name: Creative Writing and Reading Like a Writer
desc: Introduction to reading from a writerly perspective as an early but important step in the development of writing practice.

name: Introduction to Creative Writing Practice
desc:
An introduction to the elements of creative writing as the basis of an artistic practice.
336.01 Poetry336.02 Fiction336.03 Popular Writing336.04 Across the Genres

name: Drama: Reading and Analysis
desc: A study of dramatic literature in English from a wide range of historical periods, social contexts, and national literatures. Through textual analysis and close reading, acquaints students with the characteristic techniques of dramaturgy and basic theatric terminology, giving detailed attention to the formal conventions of literature written to be performed on stage.

name: Gender and Sexuality in Literature
desc: Reading and analysis of gender and sexuality in literature. Topics may include queer theory; feminism and women’s writing; masculinity; transgender fictions and theory; gender and sexuality across regions, cultures, and/or historical periods; insectionality with, for instance, critical race theory, disability studies, and/or indigeneity.

name: Canadian Literature
desc: An introduction to major writers and creative voices in Canada, as well as to significant critical and cultural ideas that have developed about Canadian literature.

name: Indigenous Literatures of Turtle Island
desc: An overview of writing by Indigenous Peoples of Turtle Island (North America). Includes study of writers from the territory known as Canada.

name: Comparative Global Literatures
desc: A comparative overview of literature from a range of regions around the world. May include an examination of post-colonial, diasporic, and globalization theories.

name: American Literature
desc: An introduction to works of American literature that illuminate significant aspects of American culture or American literary history.

name: The History of English
desc: An examination of important changes and stages in the history of English including its Indo-European and Germanic origins and a consideration of Modern English grammar and orthography from a historical perspective.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Current Topics in English Studies
desc: Selected topics attentive to current and emergent research directions in the discipline.

name: Topics in Reading Popular Culture
desc: Selected topics in popular culture across media, genres, time, and regions. Examination of popular texts as sites of cultural meaning and socio-political intervention and learn to assess their significance. Topics may include fan culture; television; film; music; performance; adaptation; the intersection of high and low culture; gaming; food; social media; and sport.

name: Speculative Fiction I: Science Fiction
desc: Survey of the genre of science fiction, from its origins to the present

name: Speculative Fiction II: Fantasy
desc: A survey of the genre of fantasy literature. May include works from a range of historical and national contexts.

name: Literature for Young People
desc: A historical survey of children’s and young adult literature from its origins to the present day.

name: Detective Fiction
desc: A survey of the genre of detective fiction. May include works from a range of historical and national contexts.

name: Old English Language and Prose Literature
desc: A study of the language of the Anglo-Saxons through reading of prose texts.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Old English Poetry
desc: Reading and analysis of Old English poetry in the original language.
prereqs: English 401.
antireqs: English 401.

name: Middle English Literature: The Canterbury Tales
desc: A study of Geoffrey Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales in its social, cultural and historical contexts. Texts will be read in the original language and the course will include instruction in Middle English.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Middle English Literature: Selected Works
desc: A study of selected works of Middle English poetry, prose and drama (excluding Geoffrey Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales) in their social, cultural and historical contexts. Texts will be read in the original language and the course will include instruction in Middle English.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Renaissance Literature and Culture I
desc: A study of representative literary works from the reign of Henry VIII to Elizabeth I will be examined in their cultural and historical contexts. May include works by authors such as John Skelton, Sir Thomas More, Thomas Wyatt, Christopher Marlowe, Elizabeth I, Edmund Spenser, and William Shakespeare.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Renaissance Literature and Culture II
desc: A study of representative literary works from the reigns of James I, and Charles I, and the English Civil War will be examined in their cultural and historical contexts. May include works by John Donne, George Herbert, Mary Wroth, Amelia Lanyer, Andrew Marvell and John Milton.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Early English Drama
desc: A study of representative dramatic works from the emergence of the genre to 1600, including the medieval, Tudor, and Elizabethan periods. Works will be examined in their relevant historical contexts.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Shakespeare and his Contemporaries
desc: An examination of the drama of the seventeenth century, examining works written for both public and private theatres as well as for court performance. Will include plays from major writers of the period such as William Shakespeare, Ben Jonson, and Thomas Middleton.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Advanced Studies in Comics
desc: Considers the role and nature of comics (comic strips, comic books, graphic novels) as a distinct form. Topics may include the influence of comics genres; the relationship of comics to other art forms (including literature); major authors; and distinct historical or national cartooning traditions.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Selected Topics in Contemporary Theory
desc: Advanced study in contemporary literary or cultural theory with a focus on a particular school, author, or approach.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Eighteenth-Century Poetry
desc: An examination of the major poetic forms of the long eighteenth century with an emphasis on tradition and innovation in poetic techniques. Includes such authors as John Wilmot, Earl of Rochester; John Dryden; Aphra Behn; Alexander Pope; Jonathan Swift; Samuel Johnson; Thomas Gray; Stephen Duck; Ann Yearsley; Mary Collier; Mary Leapor; and Phillis Wheatley.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Restoration Voices
desc: An exploration of the diverse literary and cultural productions of England during the years 1660-1700 with an emphasis on both court and common spheres. Topics may include the re-opening of the theatres; professional women writers; transatlantic conversations and encounters with indigeneity; newspapers and broadsides; comedy and satire; medicine and science; political and religious dissent; sexuality and gender; town versus country debates; and coffee house culture.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Creative Writing Workshop
desc:
A close examination and discussion of the student’s own work, with emphasis on technique, in order to develop a portfolio.
436.01 Poetry: Short Forms436.02 Poetry: Long Forms436.03 Fiction: Short Stories and Microfictions436.04 Fiction: Long Short Stories and the Novella436.05 Popular Genre Writing
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Experiments in Early Fiction
desc: A study of selected works of prose fiction to 1832 with an emphasis on the development of the novel in England and/or across the Atlantic. Includes such authors as Aphra Behn, Daniel Defoe, Eliza Haywood, Samuel Richardson, Henry Fielding, Laurence Sterne, Frances Burney, Frances Brooke, Charlotte Lennox, James Hogg, Maria Edgeworth, and Jane Austen.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: British Romanticism
desc: A study of selected British literary works from the period roughly between the 1780s and 1830s. Includes such authors as Jane Austen, William Wordsworth, William Blake, Percy Bysshe Shelley, and Mary Shelley.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Early to Mid-Victorian Literature
desc: An examination of the Victorian novel, poetry, and prose. Includes such authors as Charles Dickens, Alfred Tennyson, Robert Browning, and the Brontës.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Late Victorian Literature
desc: An examination of the poetry, prose, and drama of the 1880s and 1890s, with a focus on aestheticism and decadence. Includes such authors as Oscar Wilde, Vernon Lee, and Walter Pater.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: British Literature from 1900 to 1950
desc: A survey of British literature from the first half of the twentieth century.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: British Literature since 1950
desc: A survey of British literature from the last half of the twentieth century to the present.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Digital Research in Literary Studies
desc: An introduction to digital research methods for literary studies. Topics may include text encoding and analysis, data visualization, and public scholarship.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Early American Literature and the American Renaissance
desc: A survey of American literature from its origins to the Civil War. Examines both canonical and newly relevant works of literature and place them in a cultural and critical context.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: American Literature from the Late 1800s to the Mid-1900s
desc: A survey of American literature from the Civil War to World War II, encompassing realism, naturalism, and modernism. Examines both canonical and newly relevant works of literature and place them in a cultural and critical context.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: American Literature since the Mid-1900s
desc: A survey of American literature since World War II. Examines both canonical and newly relevant works of literature and place them in a cultural and critical context.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Canadian Literature from its Origins to 1950
desc: A survey of Canadian literature from its beginnings to the middle of the twentieth century.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Advanced Studies in Young Adult Literature
desc: Contemporary approaches to selected works of young adult literature. Topics may include the problem novel; dystopian literature; gender and sexuality; diversity in young adult books; banned/controversial books; fan culture; and young adults in the digital age.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Canadian Literature since 1950
desc: A survey of Canadian literature from 1950 to the present.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Literature and Science
desc: Study of the relationship between literature and science with respect to a special topic or theoretical approach. Course may cover advanced topics in science fiction such as Cyberpunk or Steampunk; how philosophies of science and technology pertain to literature; or interdisciplinary inquiry into literary texts using, for instance, neuroscience, ecology, and physics.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Studies in Text and Image
desc: An examination of the relationship between the visual and literary. Students will develop a vocabulary for talking about visual texts and learn to articulate the shared and distinctive ways that these texts create meaning. Topics may include illustrated books and manuscripts; visual poetics; graphic novels; adaptation; digital literary forms; history of the book; and letterpress printing.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Literary Theory Pre-1900
desc: A survey of the major theories and approaches to literature from antiquity to 1900.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Advanced Studies in Poetry
desc: Focused study of poetry with an emphasis on formal elements and poetics. Texts will vary but will include some contemporary works.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Advanced Studies in Literature and the Environment
desc: Selected topics in nature writing, environmental literature, ecocriticism and eco-theory. Topics may include climate change; bioregionalism; animals and animality; Indigenous environmental perspectives; risk, disaster, and crises; pollution and waste; the body toxic; and dystopias.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Advanced Studies in Children’s Literature
desc: Contemporary approaches to selected works of historical and/or contemporary children’s literature. Topics may include the Golden Age of children’s literature; picture books; literacy; censorship in children’s literature; gender and sexuality; genre; fan culture; reading in the digital age; storytelling; and diversity in children’s books.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Advanced Studies in Global Literatures
desc: Focused study of post-colonial, transnational, and/or diasporic literatures, with an emphasis on a selection region, author(s), and/or particular theoretical approaches.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Global Indigenous Literatures
desc: Focused study of writing by Indigenous peoples in a global context. Comparative in approach and focus on Indigenous theoretical contexts.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Studies Across Literary History
desc: A historical or transhistorical examination of a literary theme, genre, form, and/or writing and publication practice.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Topics: Selected Author
desc: Advanced study of a selected author. A close look at one writer's oeuvre in social, historical, or theoretical contexts.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units of courses labelled English at 300 level or above.

name: Honours Project
desc: Capstone seminar for English Honours students focusing on research methods and professional issues. Supports and includes the writing of the Honours thesis.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level, admission to the English Honours program and consent of the Department.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level, admission to the English Honours program and consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in a Literary Genre
desc: An in-depth examination of a select literary genre in a critical context. Students will learn to develop research questions and conduct original research.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.

name: Advanced Topics: Canadian Literature
desc: An in-depth examination of a topic in Canadian literature in its critical context. Students will learn to develop research questions and conduct original research.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.

name: Advanced Topics: Global/Indigenous Contexts
desc: Advanced study of a particular topic in post-colonial, transnational, diasporic, and/or Indigenous literary studies, with an emphasis on theoretical context. Students will learn to develop research questions and conduct original research.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.

name: Advanced Topics: Theoretical and Cultural Studies
desc: An in-depth examination of a topic involving advanced theoretical inquiry. Students will learn to develop research questions and conduct original research.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.

name: Advanced Topics in a Historical Topic
desc: An in-depth examination of historical literary or cultural texts in a critical context. Students will learn to develop research questions and conduct original research.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.

name: Community Engagement through Literature
desc: Combines classroom and community-based learning undertaken in association with the Calgary Public Library or other associated non-profit organizations that promote engagement with literature.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics: Book and Digital Culture
desc: Advanced topics in book history, digital humanities, and new media.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.

name: Advanced Topics: A National or Transnational Literature
desc: An in-depth examination of a national or transnational author, genre, or issue in a critical context. Students will learn to develop research questions and conduct original research.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.

name: Advanced Topics: A Selected Author
desc: An in-depth examination of a selected author in a critical context. Students will learn to develop research questions and conduct original research.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.

name: Advanced Topics: Popular/Experimental Genres
desc: An in-depth examination of works or authors that operate outside the traditional literary canon. May include the study of such topics as new or emergent literary forms; the cultural products of fan or digital culture; comics; bestselling genres such as true crime, fantasy, or romance; art books; and formally experimental literature in a historical or contemporary context. Students will learn to develop research questions and conduct original research.
prereqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of English at the 400 level.

name: Studies in Creative Writing: Poetry
desc: A close examination and discussion of the student's own work, with emphasis on advanced technique.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Studies in Creative Writing: Prose Fiction
desc: A close examination and discussion of the student's own work, with emphasis on advanced technique.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Studies in Creative Writing: Creative Non-Fiction
desc: A close examination and discussion of the student's own work, with emphasis on advanced technique.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Studies in Creative Writing: The Book-Length Manuscript
desc: A close examination and discussion of the student's own work, with emphasis on advanced technique.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Topics in Genre
desc: Specialized study of a topic involving a single genre or multiple genres.

name: Topics in National or Transnational Literatures
desc: Specialized study of a topic in national or transnational literary studies, in a critical context.

name: Topics in Theoretical and Cultural Studies
desc: Specialized study of a topic involving theoretical inquiry.

name: Topics in a Literary Period
desc: Specialized study of a topic in a literary period in its critical context.

name: Topics in Canadian Literature
desc: Specialized study of a topic in Canadian literature in its critical context.

name: Topics in Literary Criticism
desc: Specialized study of a topic in the field of literary criticism.

name: Special Topics
desc: Specialized study of a topic in the field of literary studies.

name: Graduate Pro-seminar
desc: Introduces incoming graduate students to critical skills and professional issues in graduate level literary studies.

name: Topics in Creative Writing: Poetry
desc: A close examination and discussion of the student's own work, with emphasis on advanced technique.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Topics in Creative Writing: Prose Fiction
desc: A close examination and discussion of the student's own work, with emphasis on advanced technique.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Topics in Creative Writing: Creative Non-Fiction
desc: A close examination and discussion of the student's own work, with emphasis on advanced technique.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Topics in Creative Writing: The Book-Length Manuscript
desc: A close examination and discussion of the student's own work, with emphasis on advanced technique in a selected genre(s).
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Capstone Project
desc: Independent research and original work to be undertaken under the direction of a faculty member in English, after all required course work has been completed.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Introduction to Film Studies
desc: An introduction to the foundational issues and vocabulary of film studies explored through a wide range of filmic texts. Privileging questions of film technique and style, the course also considers cinema as an institution that comprises an industrial system of production, social and aesthetic norms and codes and particular modes of reception.

name: Introduction to Research in Film Studies
desc: An in-depth introduction to conducting research in film studies, emphasizing critical viewing, reading and writing through the examination of a specific topic, such as a film genre, a national cinema, or a filmmaker.

name: Topics in National Cinema
desc: Topics will explore various aspects of, or historical moments in, a particular nation's cinematic culture. Topics might include Quebecois cinema, current British cinema, German cinema Between the Wars, Canadian cinema, the History of Chinese cinema, etc.

name: Topics in Genre
desc: Topics will focus on the style, narrative form, and historical evolution of selected genres, for example, the Documentary, the Western, the Melodrama, the Musical, etc.

name: Topics in Cinema and Gender Studies
desc: Topics will explore the representation of gender and sexuality in cinema. Topics might include: Images of Women in the American 1940s, Lesbian Images in Current Cinema, The Queer 1950s, Comparative Images of Women in American and French Cinema, etc.
