name: History of Popular Cinema
desc: An assessment of the various ways in which the history of film production can be approached, including the development of filmmaking technologies, evolutions in cinematic style and narrative traditions, particularly as they relate to popular cinema, and changing industrial practices.
prereqs: Film 201.
antireqs: Film 201.

name: Issues in Film History
desc: An introduction to key concepts in cinematic historiography. Emphasis will be placed upon non-traditional or non-canonical films and their relationship to dominant histories of filmmaking.
prereqs: Film 201.
antireqs: Film 201.

name: Film Theory up to 1950
desc: An introduction to theoretical perspectives on film before the mid-twentieth century. Connects film with broader debates on aesthetics, medium specificity, genre, and realism. Includes theories developed in the first half of the twentieth century related to Silent Film, Formalism, Montage, Critical Theory, and Auteur theories.
prereqs: Film 201.
antireqs: Film 201.

name: Film Theory after 1950
desc: An introduction to theoretical perspectives on film developed since the mid-twentieth century, specifically Structuralism, Linguistics, Psychoanalysis, Feminism, Post-structuralism, Cultural Studies, Post-colonialism and Queer Theory.
prereqs: Film 201.
antireqs: Film 201.

name: Canadian Film
desc: An introduction to key historical and theoretical aspects of Canadian film. Topics will include the study of Canadian film auteurs, documentary and social change, feature film genres, and the role of government regulations. Explores the central themes and issues facing Canadian filmmakers and audiences.

name: Topics in Film Theory
desc: Topics will be organized around particular theorists, schools of theory, historical issues in film culture, or contemporary thought on film. Topics may include: Psychoanalysis and/as Film Theory; Kaja Silverman and Teresa de Lauretis; Modernism and Post-modernism; Feminist Film Theory; Queer Theory and Film; Post-colonial Theory and Film; Semiotics.
prereqs: Film 331 or 333.
antireqs: Film 331 or 333.

name: Topics in the Director's Cinema
desc: Topics will examine the distinctive style and concerns of a particular director or directors.
prereqs: Film 201.
antireqs: Film 201.

name: Advanced Topics in Film Genre
desc: Topics will be organized around a specific film generic tradition.
prereqs: Film 201 and 3 units from 305 or 321.
antireqs: Film 201 and 3 units from 305 or 321.

name: Experiential Learning in Film
desc: Provides the opportunity to combine interests in film studies research with experiential learning opportunities in the community and workplace (internships, paid employment, approved film production training or volunteer position).
prereqs: Film 201, admission to the BA in Film Studies or the Bachelor of Film Studies and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Film 201, admission to the BA in Film Studies or the Bachelor of Film Studies and consent of the Department.

name: Special Topics in Film Studies
desc: Topic may be historical, theoretical or analytical in emphasis.
prereqs: 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.
antireqs: 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.

name: The Film Festival
desc: An exploration of the social practices (cultural tourism, tastemaking, identity formation, celebrity and star formation) and operational aspects (marketing, promotion, jurying, lobbying, audience cultivation) of film festivals. Students will be encouraged to participate in community service learning through volunteer opportunities with a particular festival.
prereqs: Film 321.
antireqs: Film 321.

name: The Canadian Film Industry: National and Global Perspectives
desc: A study of the nature of the Canadian film industry. Emphasis will be on the evolution of the Canadian motion picture industry in the twentieth century and how it is situated in contemporary popular culture. Other topics include Canada's historic relationship to Hollywood, the audience for Canadian films, the role of the state in funding, distribution and production systems, the impact of new technologies, and how the structure of Canada's film industry compares with those of other countries.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Film, Communication and Media Studies, or Canadian Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Film, Communication and Media Studies, or Canadian Studies at the 300 level.

name: Film Audience and Reception
desc: Explores aspects of spectatorship, audience and reception approaches as they intersect with the experience and study of cinema.
prereqs: 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.
antireqs: 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.

name: Experimental Film and Video
desc: Explores the genre of experimental film and video. Particular emphasis will be given to the history and evolution of works in this genre with attention to Canadian contributions and the impact of digital and new media.
prereqs: 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.
antireqs: 3 units from Film 321, 331 or 333.

name: Independent Research in Film Studies
desc: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Special Topics in Film Studies
desc: Selected topic in film studies suitable for advanced studies in the degree. Topic may be historical, theoretical or analytical in emphasis.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled Film at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled Film at the 400 level.

name: Capstone Seminar in Film Studies
desc: Explores the variety of ways in which film and the technologies of motion pictures connect with social life with reference to a specific topic. Completion of a major project that will integrate understanding of film theory, history and genres.
prereqs: Admission to the BA in Film Studies and 78 units, of which, 6 units must be taken from Film 321, 323, 331, or 333.
antireqs: Admission to the BA in Film Studies and 78 units, of which, 6 units must be taken from Film 321, 323, 331, or 333.

name: Honours Seminar
desc: Individual research and seminar activities (e.g., critiques, presentations, and peer reviews of drafts) to produce a proposal and a paper to be used as the basis for the honours thesis.
prereqs: Admission to BA Honours Film Studies.
antireqs: Admission to BA Honours Film Studies.

name: Honours Thesis and Seminar
desc: Supervised individual research and preparation of an honours thesis. Incorporating material from the Film 595 final paper, to complete the honours thesis. Seminar activities include progress reports, peer reviews, and support for poster presentations and oral exams.
prereqs: Film 595 and admission to BA Honours in Film Studies.
antireqs: Film 595 and admission to BA Honours in Film Studies.

name: Beginners' French I
desc: Basic elements of the French language, including training in comprehension, speaking, reading and writing of French.

name: Beginners' French II
desc: A continuation of French 209.
prereqs: French 20 or French 209.
antireqs: French 20 or French 209.

name: Intermediate French
desc: Development of abilities in spoken and written French. Review of French grammar along with extensive oral and written practice.
prereqs: One of French 211, 30, or N30.
antireqs: One of French 211, 30, or N30.

name: La Grammaire par les textes I
desc: Apprentissage des structures grammaticales et logiques du français contemporain avec lectures de morceaux choisis de textes de la francophonie mondiale.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 30N ou 30S ou 31 (ou équivalents), ou French Language Arts 30, ou French 213.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 30N ou 30S ou 31 (ou équivalents), ou French Language Arts 30, ou French 213.

name: La Grammaire par les textes II
desc: Suite du cours French 225 et mise en pratique des structures acquises.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 225.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 225.

name: Francophonie: Langue et Culture I
desc: Étude de la langue et de la culture des pays francophones, y compris la France, le Canada et les pays de l’Afrique, de l’Asie et des Caraïbes. Introduction aux sources et aux outils de recherche nécessaires pour cette étude et pour la production de travaux écrits et oraux.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 30N ou 30S ou 31 (ou équivalents), ou French Language Arts 30, ou French 213.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 30N ou 30S ou 31 (ou équivalents), ou French Language Arts 30, ou French 213.

name: Expression écrite et orale
desc: Grammaire avancée. Perfectionnement de techniques d’expression écrite et orale. Introduction à la recherche.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 227.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 227.

name: Concepts littéraires
desc: Concepts fondamentaux de l'analyse littéraire. L'accent sera placé principalement sur les traditions littéraires des pays francophones. Initiation à l'utilisation de sources bibliographiques particulières à l'étude de la littérature de langue française.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 227.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 227.

name: Cinéma de langue française
desc: Introduction à l'analyse de films en français.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 227.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 227.

name: Histoire littéraire
desc: Aperçu chronologique des périodes, mouvements et écoles des littératures de langue française, accompagné d’études de textes.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 227.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 227.

name: Introduction à la linguistique française
desc: Initiation à l'approche scientifique (objective et systématique) du langage humain. Fonctions du langage et rôle des linguistes. Concepts de base de la linguistique: langage, langue, parole; synchronie vs diachronie; signifiant vs signifié; paradigmatique vs syntagmatique; double articulation; phonèmes, monèmes. Différents domaines de la linguistique.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 227.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 227.

name: Francophonie: langue et culture II
desc: Étude de la langue française et de la culture des pays de la francophonie: France, Canada, pays d’Afrique, des Caraïbes et d’Asie. Recherche documentaire et production de textes écrits.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 227.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 227.

name: Français professionnel, domaines variés
desc: Cours de langue française sur objectifs spécifiques et à visée professionnelle. Idéal pour les domaines aussi variés que les affaires, le tourisme, le droit, la médecine, les sciences, les relations internationales, la traduction, etc. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une année à l'autre.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 227.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 227.

name: Langue française, littérature et culture, matières variées
desc: Étude des aspects de la langue française, de la littérature et de la culture. Les supports utilisés incluent les textes authentiques, la BD, la chanson, les media, etc. Exemples de sujets traités: le monde francophone, l’histoire de la langue française, etc. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une année à l'autre.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 227.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 227.

name: Le Canada francophone
desc: Panorama de la littérature canadienne de langue française.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.

name: Littératures francophones
desc: Panorama des productions littéraires de langue française en Afrique, au Maghreb et aux Antilles.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.

name: Littérature du Moyen-Âge et de la Renaissance
desc: Panorama de la littérature française du Moyen-Âge et de la Renaissance.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.

name: Littérature du XVIIe siècle
desc: Panorama de la littérature française du XVIIe siècle.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.

name: Littérature du XVIIIe siècle
desc: Panorama de la littérature française du XVIIIe siècle.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.

name: Littérature du XIXe siècle
desc: Panorama de la littérature française du XIXe siècle.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.

name: Littérature des XXe-XXIe siècles
desc: Panorama de la littérature française des XXe-XXIe siècles.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 339, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 339, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.

name: Aspects de la linguistique française
desc:
Étude des différents aspects de la langue française. Méthodes d’analyse et de description. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d’une année à l’autre.
489.01. Phonologie 
489.02. Morphologie
489.03. Syntaxe
489.04. Sémantique 
489.05. Lexicologie
prereqs: Prérequis: French 369, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 369, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.

name: Langue française, littérature et culture II, matières variées
desc: Étude des aspects de la langue française, de la littérature et de la culture. Les thèmes de ce cours seront abordés à l'aide de méthodes novatrices.
prereqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: French 329, plus 6 autres unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 300 qui portent l'étiquette French.

name: Théories critiques, domaines variés
desc: Présentation de certaines théories contemporaines qui ont cours en études littéraires et culturelles. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une année à l'autre.
prereqs: Prérequis: 9 unités dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: 9 unités dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.

name: Études indépendantes: apprentissage expérientiel
desc: Stage de recherche sous la direction de professeurs de la Division d’études françaises et francophones. Rapport de fin de stage rédigé en français.
prereqs: Prérequis: Autorisation de la Division d’études françaises et francophones.
antireqs: Prérequis: Autorisation de la Division d’études françaises et francophones.

name: Étude spécialisée du Canada français
desc: Séminaire sur des sujets avancés dans le domaine de la langue, de la littérature ou de la culture du Canada français. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une année à l'autre.
prereqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.

name: Étude spécialisée du Cinéma de langue française
desc: Séminaire sur des sujets avancés ayant trait au cinéma de langue française. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une année à l'autre.
prereqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.

name: Étude spécialisée de la francophonie
desc: Séminaire sur des sujets avancés ayant trait à la langue, aux littératures ou aux diverses cultures de la francophonie. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une année à l'autre.
prereqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.

name: Étude spécialisée de littérature française
desc: Séminaire sur des sujets avancés ayant trait à la littérature française. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une année à l'autre.
prereqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.

name: Étude spécialisée de linguistique française
desc: Séminaire sur des sujets avancés dans le domaine de la linguistique française. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d'une année à l'autre.
prereqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.

name: Mémoire de baccalauréat spécialisé
desc: Après consultation étroite avec un des professeurs de la Division d’études françaises et francophones, chaque étudiant(e) rédigera un mémoire, comportant une cinquantaine de pages, sur un sujet qui le/la passionne. Ce sujet doit être approuvé par la Division.
prereqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French, acceptation dans le programme du baccalauréat spécialisé (Honours) et autorisation de la Division d’études françaises et francophones.
antireqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French, acceptation dans le programme du baccalauréat spécialisé (Honours) et autorisation de la Division d’études françaises et francophones.

name: Études spécialisées de la langue, de la littérature ou de la culture
desc: Séminaire sur des questions d'actualité ayant trait à la langue, à la littérature ou à la culture au sens large. Exemples de sujets traités: l’histoire des idées, la littérature française du Moyen-Âge, l'autobiographie, l'écriture des femmes de langue française, le créole dans les écrits de langue française, etc. Le format et le contenu peuvent varier d’une année à l’autre.
prereqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.
antireqs: Prérequis: 9 unités puisées dans les cours du niveau 400 qui portent l’étiquette French.

name: Global Environmental Change
desc: Examination of current environmental issues related to physical geography, including topics such as climate change, energy and sustainable resource development, weather extremes, and natural hazards. The course uses contemporary topics to introduce fundamental principles of physical and environmental geography while highlighting societal impacts and influences.

name: Society and Environment
desc: Foundations of human geography presented with integrative case studies of current and urgent human-environment issues from global to regional to local. Examines the complex interconnections between humans and environment using topics such as climate change, sustainability, development, poverty, food, urbanization, and technologies of the digital age.

name: Thinking Spatially in a Digital World
desc: Introduces mapping technologies and digital spatial data for solving geographical problems that focus on how to collect, manage, analyze, and communicate diverse spatial data. Topics include geographic information systems (GIS), remote sensing, spatial statistics, geovisualization, cartography, and web mapping.

name: Introduction to Climate Change
desc: Introduction to climate change science, climate change impacts, and Canadian and international climate policy. Topics include an introduction to the atmosphere, ocean, and cryosphere, the carbon cycle, the greenhouse effect, natural climate variability in Earth history, climate models, and an overview of economic, political, social, and policy dimensions of climate change.

name: Climate and Ecosystems
desc: Introduction to the Earth’s atmospheric environment (elements and controls of climate and their implications for hydrology, vegetation, and soils) and the nature and distribution of ecosystems and vegetation. Incorporates interactions between humans and their environment, especially those leading to global change on the decade to century time-scale.

name: Landforms and Soils
desc: Introduction to physical landscapes and soils, emphasizing the formation and geographic distribution of mountains, volcanoes, valleys, and deserts, and their shaping by rivers and glaciers; and the fundamental concepts in soil science. Incorporates human modification of the Earth’s surface.

name: Society and Environmental Change
desc: Environmental and resource issues, with emphasis on topics such as climate change, sustainability, ethics, planning, policy and decision making, and management strategies. Case examples highlight issues in resource sectors such as freshwater, oceans, parks and wildlife, tourism and recreation, forests and energy.

name: Geographies of Canada
desc: Exploration of what it means to be Canadian in a global context. Examination of the historic, cultural, social, political, economic, and environmental factors that promote unity and inter-regional tensions.

name: Geographies of East and Southeast Asia
desc: An introduction to the geographies of East and Southeast Asia utilizing the foundations of physical and human geography. The logical divisions based on culture, physiography, history, migration, social and economic both currently and historically. Issues of development and the environmental impacts relating to rapid growth, urbanization, and intensive use of resources will be addressed.

name: Geographies of Europe
desc: An introduction to the geographies of Europe utilizing the foundations of physical and human geography. The logical divisions based on culture, physiography, history, migration, social, and economy will be explored both currently and historically. Settlement patterns, transportation networks, economic activities, and contrasting cultural, ethnic, linguistic and religious variations will be emphasized.

name: Political, Economic, and Urban Geography
desc: A introduction to the major concepts of human geography including political geography, economic geography, the uneven distribution of development across the surface of the Earth, and the urbanization of the developed and developing world.

name: Social and Cultural Geography
desc: An introduction to the major concepts of human geography including demography, migration, cultures, languages, and religions.

name: Geospatial Communication
desc: An introduction to fundamentals in cartography, remote sensing, geographic information systems, and descriptive spatial statistics.

name: International Field Studies
desc: An introduction to conducting international reconnaissance research in geography. Provides a background in various aspects of ethical research practices, qualitative and quantitative data collection, analysis, and dissemination.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Geographic Field Studies
desc: An introduction to field research techniques and topics in physical and human geography. Lectures and projects will provide an introduction to a range of geographic disciplines. Field exercises will normally be conducted away from Calgary for about ten days before Fall Term.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Meteorology and Hydrology
desc: Atmospheric connections with the hydrological cycle, including evapotranspiration, water vapour, stability, cloud development, and precipitation. Water transport is followed through soil moisture, groundwater, and stream flow. Discussed methods focus on tracking water transport through the land-atmosphere system at various scales. Additional topics may include water quality, water resource management, and hydrology of selected landscapes.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 211, 308.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 211, 308.

name: Process Geomorphology
desc: A systematic study of the physical processes that shape the Earth's surface. Emphasis is on the mechanics of geomorphic processes and their interaction with Earth materials.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 211, 310.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 211, 310.

name: Soil Science
desc: Exploration of soil science including the chemical, physical, and biological properties of soils; soil formation and development, including the classification of soils, and the application of soil science to land use, environmental quality, global change, and sustainable development.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 211, 308, 310.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 211, 308, 310.

name: Climate Change and Society
desc: Overview of social dimensions of climate change. Addresses representation, governance, knowledge production, power and justice. Examines how responses and policies are shaped across various scales including global, national, regional, urban and individual.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.

name: Sustainability and Political Ecology
desc: Exploration of the challenges associated with environmental management and governance, particularly in terms of achieving sustainability. Emphasis is placed on ongoing local, regional, and global environmental problems, using political ecology perspectives to understand power, discourse and interest mechanisms behind environmental rights, controls, and sustainability needs.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.

name: Animal Geography
desc: Explores the socio-spatial relationships between humans and animals, with the goal of elucidating the ecological, economic, political, social, and cultural pressures shaping these relations, and the conflicts arising from human-animal interactions. Inter-species bonds and emotional lives of animals are also covered.
prereqs: 3 units from courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 3 units from courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.

name: Global Change and Hazards
desc: Examination of the factors that influence vulnerability and resiliency to environmental hazards. Emphasis on how human activities change both the dynamics of natural processes and the spatio-temporal variability of vulnerability and resiliency.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.

name: Field Studies in Social and Economic Geography
desc: Field research and reconnaissance survey techniques. Individual and group travel-study combined with formal instruction and seminars.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Field Studies in Physical and Environmental Geography
desc: Field research and reconnaissance survey techniques. Individual and group travel-study combined with formal instruction and seminars.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Urban Social Geography
desc: Concepts of urban geography with particular reference to intra-urban social issues.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 251, 253, 352, 354, Urban Studies 253.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 251, 253, 352, 354, Urban Studies 253.

name: Economic Geography
desc: Theories, concepts and techniques of economic geography with emphasis on policy issues relating to examples at the urban, regional, and national levels.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 251, 253, 352, Urban Studies 253.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 251, 253, 352, Urban Studies 253.

name: Uneven Development
desc: Foundations of development geography and its concern with multiscalar, multidimensional processes of intervention and change. Focus on urban-rural and global-local change effects and human settlement. An interrogation of globalization, poverty, marginality, human settlement and the diversity of development actors, the state, the aid community, and the people directly affected by development.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 251, 253, 352, 354, Urban Studies 253.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 251, 253, 352, 354, Urban Studies 253.

name: Political Geographies
desc: Spatial study of political systems, structures, and processes, and their relationship to geographic factors.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 251, 253, 352, Urban Studies 253.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 251, 253, 352, Urban Studies 253.

name: Cartography and Geovisualization
desc: Focuses on mapping technologies for cartography and geo-visualization. The role of cartography and geovisualization is explored both theoretically, and practically in the communication of spatial data. In lecture and lab-based settings, examines data considerations, map design fundamentals and techniques, map use and interactive design for the communication of geographic information.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 231, 380.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 231, 380.

name: Geographic Information Systems and Science
desc: The technical and theoretical foundations of Geographic Information Science. Explorations of data types and structures, data integrity, metadata, data acquisition and maintenance, analytical techniques, and methods for geovisualization will be explored in lecture and laboratory.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 231, 380.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 231, 380.

name: Ways of Knowing in Geography
desc: Conceptualizing human-environment realities into research: an introduction to philosophical foundations of ways of thinking and critical perspectives; qualitative and mixed methods approaches. Examination of 'rules' of research and the challenges of real world complexities. In-depth examples of human-environment research from theory to practice, broad research design and proposal writing practice.
prereqs: 3 units from Urban Studies 253, Geography 251, 253 or courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 3 units from Urban Studies 253, Geography 251, 253 or courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.

name: Remote Sensing Essentials
desc: Instruction in the background, use and interpretation of remote sensing imagery. Labs and topics introduce fundamental principles of raster-based image analysis, visualization and classification. Labs will include identification, interpretation and mapping of both physical and cultural landscape features.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 231, 380.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 231, 380.

name: Quantitative Analysis
desc: Introduction to quantitative research methodology, sampling and survey design in geography. Covers the background analytical techniques for an understanding of geographic literature. Examples will involve the use of statistical computer packages.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 231, 380.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 231, 380.

name: Critical Zone Science
desc: Examination of the Critical Zone, Earth's outer layer that extends from the top of vegetation to the bottom of the fresh groundwater zone. It is a constantly evolving boundary layer where rock, soil, water, air, and living organisms interact to regulate the landscape and natural habitats, and determine the availability of life-sustaining resources, including our food production and water quality.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 313 or 412 and 3 units from Geography 305, 307, 408, 410.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 313 or 412 and 3 units from Geography 305, 307, 408, 410.

name: Arctic Systems Science
desc: Investigates the Arctic as a coupled system, and how the Arctic interacts with other Earth systems. Draws on physical, chemical, and biological sciences to understand linked topics such as Arctic glaciers, marine environments, hydrology, permafrost, wildlife, vegetation, and sea ice. Particular focus is paid to cycles of carbon, water, and energy as key drivers of the Arctic system. Selected human interactions with the Arctic system are also examined.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 408.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 408.

name: Climate Change
desc: Overview of global climate dynamics and the interactions between ocean, atmosphere, biosphere, cryosphere, and biogeochemical cycles. Examination of climate change in Earth's past, present, and future, scrutinizing both natural and anthropogenic influences on the global climate system.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 408.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 408.

name: Oceanography
desc: Physical ocean processes including circulation, waves, and tides are examined as part of the Earth’s climate system. These physical processes are then linked to controls on primary production in the ocean, and marine foodwebs/ecosystems. Chemical processes driven by circulation and biology are examined, with a focus on marine feedbacks related to past and present climate change.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 408.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 408.

name: Wind Science
desc: Physical laws governing wind processes in the upper atmosphere and the planetary boundary layer. Topics include: global wind patterns, boundary layer wind flow, pollution, wind energy, wind erosion, and wind storms.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 408.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 408.

name: Watershed System Science
desc: Introduction to advanced concepts in hydrology and watershed analysis, including the impacts of a changing climate and human influence. Involves hands-on computer modelling and experimental labs, and a design project.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Biogeography and Landscape Ecology
desc: Explores the distribution (past and present) of animals and plants, causes of variation in species types, and their abundance and survival. Topics focus on bioregions, biodiversity, communities, ecosystems at multiple scales, as well as investigation of ways that human and natural disturbance affect these patterns. Uses qualitative and quantitative approaches to measure these effects to inform management and conservation.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 313, 412.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 313, 412.

name: Advanced Field Methods
desc: Focuses on field data collection and laboratory and computational analysis techniques practiced by physical geographers. Students will conduct an integrated analysis of a local landscape, including site selection, sample collection, lab analysis, and data assimilation and interpretation for report writing. Approximately one-half of the course is taught outdoors.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 307, 313, 408, 410, 412, 413 or Archaeology 413.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 305, 307, 313, 408, 410, 412, 413 or Archaeology 413.

name: Urban Political Ecology
desc: Urban political ecology helps to untangle the interconnected economic, political, social, and ecological processes that together form highly uneven urban landscapes. Through theoretical and case study articles, discussions of themes such as water, food, green space, housing, waste, and through local case-studies, students will examine the evolution of urban political ecology, its main tenets and its relevance for understanding urbanization processes.

name: Development and Participation
desc: Critical engagement with development studies, with emphasis on local populations as development subjects, actors and potential agents of change. Opportunities and limitations of participation as development paradigm, methodology and practice are addressed in diverse problem settings to interrogate the multi-dimensional challenges of development for sustainability.

name: Environmental Governance and Conflict
desc: Foundations of environmental governance, management and discourse research from literature to practice, paired with case-specific applications on the changing roles of global, local and online spheres in today’s environmental conflicts. Examples include global conservation, international climate change negotiations, carbon forests, environmental services, Indigenous movements, renewable technologies, oil and gas conflicts, ecotourism, rural marginalization, and international environmental action strategies.

name: Science, Technology, and Society
desc: Seminar-style overview of core readings, key concepts and central debates in science, technology and society (STS) in Geography. Considers mutual shaping of science, technology and society as context-dependent practices involving institutions and discourses that vary across regions and time. Themes include social construction of knowledge and technology, agency, networks, co-production, expertise, authority, legitimacy, and democratic engagement. Empirical cases at global, national, and regional scales illustrate key concepts and debates.
prereqs: 9 units in courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 9 units in courses labelled Geography at the 300 level or above.

name: Geographies of Food
desc: Explores geographies of food on different scales – from the global to the local – with an emphasis on links between urban and rural contexts. By applying diverse perspectives (ecology, economy, equity, culture, policy, politics, gender, justice etc.) and normative concepts such as food sovereignty, we learn about the current globalized industrial agri-food regime as well as alternative and sustainable food systems.

name: Environment and Behaviour
desc: An approach to human geography that attempts to understand human activity in space, place, time, and the environment through the lens of the individual. Focus on how humans perceive the environment around them in both perceptual, cognitive, physical and behavioural terms, and how they use this information when making judgments and choices that lead to spatial behaviour.

name: Tourism, Parks and Protected Areas
desc: Interdisciplinary perspectives that directly influence policy, planning, and management of nature-based parks and protected areas. Examines the evolving social, economic, political and environmental aspects of parks and protected areas and considers current management challenges.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 321, 324.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 321, 324.

name: Globalization and the City
desc: Introduction to the social, cultural, political and economic forces operating on a global scale that increasingly shape the dynamics of cities. Emphasis is placed on social and cultural hybridity, translocal interaction, geographies of social and economic polarization, and the scalar politics and regulation of globalization.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 341, 351, 365, 452, 454, 456, Anthropology 379, 387, Economics 365, Sociology 353.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 341, 351, 365, 452, 454, 456, Anthropology 379, 387, Economics 365, Sociology 353.

name: Social Movements, Possible Worlds
desc: How urban social movements arise in the context of broader urban and societal processes. The geographical strategies and social, cultural, and political grievances of urban social movements are examined in a variety of contexts around the world.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 351, 452, Sociology 353.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 351, 452, Sociology 353.

name: Urban and Regional Political Economy
desc: A critical review of the geographical principles of urban growth and uneven development in the context of local, regional and global urban systems. Topics may include urbanization processes under capitalism, city-regions, global city networks, returns to urban agglomeration, inter-spatial competition, and transnational movements of capital and labour.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 351, 452 and 3 units from Geography 341, 454.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 351, 452 and 3 units from Geography 341, 454.

name: Spaces of Urban Politics
desc: An examination of how urban spatial relations shape, and are shaped by, political institutions, organizations, and social movements. Themes may include the politics of urban growth, urban environmental justice, urban sustainability, place-based politics, and multi-scalar politics.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 351, 452.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 351, 452.

name: Introduction to Programming in Geographic Information Systems
desc: Introduction to computer programming for customizing and automating a GIS. Topics include object-oriented programming techniques, advanced geoprocessing, scripting, and automation using a programming language such as Python or Visual Basic.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 357, 482.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 357, 482.

name: Technology, Society, and Space
desc: Explores the relationship between spatial technologies and social/political systems. Examines the ways geographers have made sense of the social construction and societal implications of technologies across time and place.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 357, 482.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 357, 482.

name: Advanced Qualitative Methods
desc: Exploration of the underlying theories and procedures of qualitative research, in human geography. Overview of methodologies including conventional approaches such as case studies and ethnographies and critical avenues such as feminist, Indigenous and science and technology studies approaches. Main qualitative research methods (interviews, discourse analysis, observation, action-oriented research) are covered.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 340, 483.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 340, 483.

name: Advanced Remote Sensing
desc: Advanced remote sensing topics and labs (e.g., Geographic Object Based Image Analysis (GEOBIA), LiDAR, Urban Heat Islands, microwave remote sensing, etc.). Students will develop a remote sensing project with potential to result in a commercial remote sensing product/service and formally present their ideas (in class) as if they were presenting to their business manager/supervisor.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 333, 484.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 333, 484.

name: Multivariate Statistics
desc: Methods for the analysis of temporal, spatial and multivariate data sets. Emphasis is placed on data sets relating to geographic phenomena, resource utilization and environmental problems, with examples from the geographic literature. Examples will involve the use of computer packages.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 339, 485.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 339, 485.

name: Web Mapping and Internet GIS
desc: Explores and practices theoretical and applied concepts related to online mapping. Covers advantages and techniques for publishing, visualizing and accessing maps and data on the Internet. Develops web mapping applications including static and interactive platforms.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 357, 437, 480, 482.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 357, 437, 480, 482.

name: Geospatial Project Management
desc: Capstone course applying the broad methodological training from GIS, remote sensing, cartography, qualitative and quantitative methods. Collaborative research and project management is stressed.

name: Urban GIS
desc: Surveys GIS applications for urban studies, and the data structures, sources, and analysis techniques used in them. Explores urban spatial analysis, decision-making in a GIS environment, and representational challenges, including project planning, spatial data acquisition, data preparation and coding, analysis and visualization of project findings, and communication and implementation of project results.
prereqs: 3 units from Geography 357, 482 and 3 units from Geography 231, 380.
antireqs: 3 units from Geography 357, 482 and 3 units from Geography 231, 380.

name: Honours Thesis Research
desc: Initiation of an individual research project and preparation leading to an Honours thesis under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Admission to Geography Honours or Earth Science Honours and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to Geography Honours or Earth Science Honours and consent of the Department.

name: Directed Independent Study
desc: Advanced study of a particular topic under the direct supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Human Geography
desc: An examination of selected topics in Human Geography in a seminar format.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Continuation of supervised individual research and completion of an Honours thesis under the supervision of a faculty member. A public presentation of the thesis is expected.
prereqs: Admission to Geography Honours or Earth Science Honours and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to Geography Honours or Earth Science Honours and consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Physical Geography
desc: An examination of selected topics in Physical Geography in a seminar format.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Graduate Research Seminar
desc: Presentation and evaluation of graduate research seminars.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Remote Sensing: Basics and Beyond
desc: Introduction to the theory and practice of remote sensing. Topics include physics of remote sensing, sensor systems, resolutions, geometric and radiometric correction, image analysis (enhancements, filtering, texture analysis, principal components, classification approaches and algorithms and accuracy). May include specific image acquisition systems and their methodological requirements. Emphasis is on fundamental concepts. Laboratory provides experience with fundamental image processing techniques.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Statistical Analysis: Basics and Beyond
desc: Introduction to applied statistics, particularly as they are used in geographical analysis. Topics include sampling design, summary statistics, probability theory, inferential statistics, and multivariate analysis. Laboratory exercises give students hands-on experience in computer-based statistical analysis.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Geographic Information Systems: Basics and Beyond
desc: Introduction to the world of Geographic Information Systems (GIS). Includes: representing reality in the digital realm, georeferencing, data structures, software history and comparison, and the full spectrum of analytical approaches associated with advanced GIS software. A major part of the work will be hands on. Software is used as a vehicle for taking the theory and concepts into a working reality.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: The Politics of Environment
desc: Contemporary issues in environmental conflict, management and governance with case-specific applications from global to local.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Research and Applications in Remote Sensing
desc: Review and basic and advanced principles of image analysis. Includes advanced laboratory techniques, integration of remote sensing with GIS, current research in remote sensing, project organization, and data sources for remote sensing.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Spatial Analysis and Modelling
desc: History of spatial modelling in geography; comprehensive coverages of techniques, spatial analysis and spatial modelling as currently used within GIS and remote sensing.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Research and Applications in Geographic Information Systems
desc: Focus on advanced GIS applications in core areas; methodological developments in GIS, and current research directions in GIS.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Principles of Digital Cartography and Geovisualization
desc: Theoretical and practical approaches to map design are used to explain techniques for effective map production and communication of inherently spatial information. Static, dynamic, and interactive visualizations of maps and spatial processes are used to explore geographic data from a variety of sources in physical and cultural spaces.
prereqs: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Geospatial Information Technology or consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Geospatial Information Technology or consent of the Department.

name: Geographic Information Systems Project: Theoretical Issues
desc: A critical and comprehensive review of information and literature on a GIS research topic This course provides the conceptual basis for Geography 683.
prereqs: Geography 633, 639 and 647 and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Geography 633, 639 and 647 and consent of the Department.

name: Fundamentals of Geographic Information Science
desc: Theoretical topics include cognition of geographic phenomena, digital representations of geographic features, coordinate systems and map projections, spatial data models, and problems of scale and uncertainty. Applications include data acquisition, geographic database design and spatial data management, basic spatial operations, surface analysis, and network analysis. Examples from physical and cultural landscapes and industry-standard geographic information systems software are used.
prereqs: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Geospatial Information Technology or consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Geospatial Information Technology or consent of the Department.

name: Geographic Information Systems Project: Application
desc: Implementation of a project on a GIS topic which will involve demonstrating mastery of GIS project design and the implementation and presentation of results commensurate with graduate level work. This topic will relate to material covered by the student in Geography 681.
prereqs: Geography 681 and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Geography 681 and consent of the Department.

name: Fundamentals of Remote Sensing
desc: Theoretical topics include physics of remote sensing data capture, sensor systems, representation and data models, as well as the science behind techniques such as reflectance and radiance calibrations, atmospheric corrections, and image transformations. Applications include topics such as visual interpretation of imagery, supervised and unsupervised image classification, model validation, and accuracy assessment.
prereqs: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Geospatial Information Technology or consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Geospatial Information Technology or consent of the Department.

name: Arctic System Science
desc: This course investigates the process linkages at various spatiotemporal scales between the atmosphere, lithosphere and hydrosphere operating within high latitude environments of the Northern Hemisphere. Of particular interest is the response of the terrestrial and marine cryosphere to climate variability and change, including methods for its detection and quantification.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Applied Statistics and Geospatial Analysis
desc: Topics include descriptive statistics, probability theory, sampling design, inferential statistics, model validation and assessment of uncertainty, and applied multivariate analysis. Techniques and examples emphasize the use of geospatial data for constructing models of geographic phenomena and spatial problem-solving.
prereqs: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Geospatial Information Technology or consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the Graduate Certificate in Geospatial Information Technology or consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Glacial Geomorphic Systems
desc: Contemporary topics in glacial geomorphology and sedimentology. Course consists of lecture, seminar and field trip components.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Geocryology
desc: Contemporary topics in the science and engineering of seasonally and perennially frozen ground. Course consists of lectures and seminars.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Fluvial Geomorphology
desc: Advanced theory and research issues in fluvial geomorphology. Topics may include flow hydraulics, sediment transport, river morphology, channel networks, sediment routing, drainage basin evolution, and channel response to environmental change.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Seminar in Geographic Research Methods
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Urban, Regional and Global Political Economy Seminar
desc: Spatial and power relations that shape urban, regional and global processes. Investigation of a wide range of processes, ranging in scale from the local to the global: capital investment and disinvestment; state power and policymaking; planning, governance and governmentality; political struggle, all in multiple forms of spatiality: place, scale, territory, networks.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Seminar in the Philosophy and Nature of Human Geography
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Seminar in the Philosophy and Nature of Physical Geography
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Selected Topics in Geographic Research Methods
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Selected Topics in Human Geography
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Selected Topics in Physical Geography
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Talking Gender and Sexuality
desc: An interdisciplinary and intersectional examination of the social and cultural constructions of gender and sexuality. Uses a series of case studies involving historical events and current affairs to discuss how ideas about gender and sexual identity shape our social systems, cultural expression, and political values. The Canadian context is emphasized.

name: Topics in Feminism
desc: Explores key issues in feminist theory and activism, including relevant related issues in gender, sexuality, race and others.

name: Topics in Gender and Sexuality
desc: Explores key issues in gender and sexuality studies.

name: Theorizing Gender and Sexuality
desc: Explores contemporary approaches to theorizing gender and sexuality, with attention to their historical bases. Includes consideration of feminist, queer, trans, and intersectional theories.

name: Methods for Gender and Sexuality Research
desc: Explores the scholarly and political implications of engaging in research on gender and sexuality by examining key feminist, queer, trans, and intersectional methods.

name: Special Topics in Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
desc: An in-depth exploration of a specific area of research interest in feminist, gender or sexuality studies.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Women’s Studies or Gender and Sexuality Studies.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Women’s Studies or Gender and Sexuality Studies.

name: Praxis Seminar
desc: Reflection upon best practices and theoretical paradigms for feminist, gender, and sexuality activism. Activist/volunteer work, outside of class-time, will be required.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Women’s Studies or Gender and Sexuality Studies.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Women’s Studies or Gender and Sexuality Studies.

name: Special Topics in Theory
desc: In-depth study of a specific approach to theorizing gender and sexuality.
prereqs: Women's Studies 311 or Gender and Sexuality Studies 311.
antireqs: Women's Studies 311 or Gender and Sexuality Studies 311.

name: Special Topics in Research Methods
desc: In-depth study of specific group research methods used in feminist, gender, and/or sexuality studies.
prereqs: Women's Studies 315 or Gender and Sexuality Studies 315.
antireqs: Women's Studies 315 or Gender and Sexuality Studies 315.

name: Ecofeminism
desc: An immersive experience, both theoretical and experiential, of ecofeminist analyses.
prereqs: 3 units of course labelled Women’s Studies or Gender and Sexuality Studies.
antireqs: 3 units of course labelled Women’s Studies or Gender and Sexuality Studies.

name: Independent Research
desc: Supervised individual study of a special topic. Intended primarily for students in Gender and Sexuality Studies programs.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Community Service Learning
desc: An opportunity for students to learn from volunteer service in community organizing and/or activism relating to feminist, gender, and sexuality studies. Students will present findings related to their community engagement placement to the class in scheduled sessions during the term.
prereqs: Women's Studies 201, 405 or Gender and Sexuality Studies 201, 405 and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Women's Studies 201, 405 or Gender and Sexuality Studies 201, 405 and consent of the Department.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Supervised individual research and preparation of an Honours thesis.
prereqs: Admission to the Honours program in Gender and Sexuality Studies and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the Honours program in Gender and Sexuality Studies and consent of the Department.

name: Made in Germany
desc: An introduction to the study of German-language cultures through key historical and contemporary works.

name: German I
desc: A comprehensive course for students with no prior knowledge of the language. Includes training in listening, speaking, reading and writing of German in its cultural context. Corresponds to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference.

name: German II
desc: A continuation of German 202. Corresponds to level A2.1 of the Common European Framework of Reference.
prereqs: German 202.
antireqs: German 202.

name: Topics in German Cultural History
desc: Distinctive features of German culture within a wide historical perspective.

name: Continuing German I
desc: A comprehensive course that includes training in listening, speaking, reading and writing of German in its cultural context. Development of increased sophistication in language production and cultural understanding. Corresponds to A2.2 of the Common European Framework of Reference.
prereqs: One of German 30 or 30-3Y, 204, 223, 302, or 303.
antireqs: One of German 30 or 30-3Y, 204, 223, 302, or 303.

name: Continuing German II
desc: A continuation of German 331. Corresponds to B1.1 of the Common European Framework of Reference.
prereqs: German 331.
antireqs: German 331.

name: German Studies Research Methods
desc: Introduction to research questions and research methods in German studies through case-study application.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Structure of German
desc: Development of a structural understanding of the German language through an introduction to linguistic analysis, including research questions and research methods in German linguistics.
prereqs: German 333.
antireqs: German 333.

name: Topics in Film
desc: German film from the perspectives of film theory and political and cultural history. May concentrate on a specific director, a period, or a genre in German film.

name: Topics in German Texts in Translation
desc: Study of literary and cultural texts within the rich tradition of Germany's Dichter und Denker (poets and philosophers).

name: Telling Stories: Exploring German Literature
desc: An introduction to historical and contemporary literary and cultural texts in German.
prereqs: German 333.
antireqs: German 333.

name: Intermediate German: Speaking and Listening
desc: Targeted focus on aural/oral communication skills in a variety of contexts and media. Corresponds to B1.2 of the Common European Framework of Reference.
prereqs: German 333.
antireqs: German 333.

name: Intermediate German: Reading and Writing
desc: Targeted focus on reading strategies, interpretive skills, and the production of a variety of texts. Corresponds to B1.2 of the Common European Framework of Reference.
prereqs: German 333.
antireqs: German 333.

name: Topics in Film
desc: German film from the perspectives of film theory and political and cultural history. May concentrate on a specific director, a period, or a genre in German film.  Requires course work to be completed in German.
prereqs: German 333.
antireqs: German 333.

name: Topics in Advanced German Linguistics
desc: In-depth exploration of topics in German linguistics in a particular field (i.e., synchronic linguistics, diachronic linguistics or language acquisition).
prereqs: German 353.
antireqs: German 353.

name: Topics in Culture Change: Concepts and Critique
desc: In depth exploration of topics in German culture, such as memory and memorials, counter cultures, (trans)nationalism, and media/intermediality, with an approach to texts and representations that incorporates new directions in cultural criticism.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Inter-Cultural Immersion Experience
desc: Independent study course. Project with Inter-cultural theme, derived from an immersion experience at an advanced level, most likely abroad.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Topics in Advanced Communication and Projects in German
desc: Students will increase their overall proficiency, enhance intercultural competence, and review key grammatical features as well as integrate theory and practice through a variety of class projects. Corresponds to B2 of the Common European Framework of Reference.
prereqs: German 413 or 415.
antireqs: German 413 or 415.

name: Independent Study
desc: Research project developed in consultation with and under supervision of instructor.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Honours Project
desc: The Honours project for Honours students in their final year.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Seminar in German Literature and Culture
desc: Selected topics in literary history.

name: Seminar in German Language and Linguistics
Bibliography, Research Methods and Grant Proposal Writing
Conference Course
desc: Meets the needs of individual students. It may include a general or specific linguistic topic; or the detailed study of an author, period, genre; or any literary problem not dealt with in the honours or graduate courses listed above.

name: Introduction to Global Development Studies
desc: An interdisciplinary course focusing on development in both a northern and international context. Explores factors that shape development processes; introduces concepts and issues such as poverty; colonialism and self-determination; human ecology and sustainable development; and appropriate technology. Examines the origins, purposes, and performance of contemporary national and international institutions and their effect on people in different geographical and socio-economic contexts.

name: Topics in Global Development Studies
desc: Examination of selected issues in Global Development Studies.
prereqs: Global Development Studies 201 or Development Studies 201.
antireqs: Global Development Studies 201 or Development Studies 201.

name: Community Development
desc: Examines the processes whereby communities take action to solve common problems in both urban and rural settings.
prereqs: Global Development Studies 201 or Development Studies 201.
antireqs: Global Development Studies 201 or Development Studies 201.

name: Gender and Development
desc: Examines development from the critical perspective of the key role played by gender in development. Case studies from Canadian and international contexts will provide illustrative material for analyzing the issues that emanate from the gendered nature of development processes and practices.
prereqs: 3 units from Global Development Studies 201, Development Studies 201, Gender and Sexuality Studies 201, Women's Studies 201.
antireqs: 3 units from Global Development Studies 201, Development Studies 201, Gender and Sexuality Studies 201, Women's Studies 201.

name: Theories and Applications of Development
desc: A study of development theories and applications through northern and international case studies. Examines practical manifestations of those theories and approaches in development planning, implementation, and praxis including Modernization theory; dependency theory; basic needs approach; neo-liberalism; the staple thesis; globalization; women in development; gender and development.
prereqs: Global Development Studies 201 or Development Studies 201.
antireqs: Global Development Studies 201 or Development Studies 201.

name: Field School
desc: A field course for the on-site interdisciplinary study of a country or region with regard to issues of development from variety of perspectives, e.g., cultural, economic, environmental, geographical, historical and political perspectives.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Development Studies
desc: Advanced examination of selected topics using theoretical and analytical tools to develop a critical understanding of contemporary development processes.
prereqs: Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393.
antireqs: Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393.

name: Global Food Politics
desc: Examination of the socio-economic, ecological, and political implications of food and farming systems at local, regional, national, and international levels.
prereqs: Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393.
antireqs: Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393.

name: Sustainability and Political Ecology in the Circumpolar Arctic
desc: The history of northern development and resource management in Canada with emphasis on specific case studies involving sustainability and human ecology in the Circumpolar Arctic. The role of traditional environmental knowledge and its significance to northern development will be examined. Participatory research methodologies may be introduced.
prereqs: 3 units from Global Development Studies 393, Development Studies 393, Anthropology 357, Indigenous Studies 317.
antireqs: 3 units from Global Development Studies 393, Development Studies 393, Anthropology 357, Indigenous Studies 317.

name: Environment and Development
desc: Critical engagement with sustainability through study of the intersections between environment and development, such as planning and development, management, and implementation, the political economy of environment, and political ecology. Topics may include political and economic systems, resource depletion, industrial agriculture, biodiversity, gender, hazards, traditional knowledge, and resistance.
prereqs: 3 units from Global Development Studies 393, Development Studies 393, Anthropology 313, Indigenous Studies 317.
antireqs: 3 units from Global Development Studies 393, Development Studies 393, Anthropology 313, Indigenous Studies 317.

name: International and Intercultural Communication
desc: Examines cross-cultural communication at the personal, organizational, societal, and international levels. Discusses the concept of "Globalization" and its implications for communication among different cultures; analyses various theoretical perspectives underlying intercultural communication; explores issues of power, identity and influence; examines intercultural encounters in the context of specific diversified settings; and helps students develop intercultural communication competence.
prereqs: Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393.
antireqs: Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393.

name: Directed Research
desc: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Critical Perspectives on Development Practice and Research
desc: An interdisciplinary consideration of selected issues and methodologies in development, providing the critical perspective and skills needed to conceptualize, design, implement and effectively manage community development projects and programs.
prereqs: Global Development Studies 302 or Development Studies 302; Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393; and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Global Development Studies 302 or Development Studies 302; Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393; and consent of the Department.

name: Honours Seminar in Development Studies
desc: Current theoretical and methodological issues will be explored in a discussion-based seminar format, with the aim of development of a research project.
prereqs: Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393 and admission to the Development Studies Honours Program.
antireqs: Global Development Studies 393 or Development Studies 393 and admission to the Development Studies Honours Program.

name: Ancient Greek I
desc: This course for beginners provides the first steps towards reading classical and New Testament Greek texts.

name: Ancient Greek II
desc: Continuation of Greek 201.
prereqs: Greek 201.
antireqs: Greek 201.

name: Ancient Greek III
desc: Completes the study of basic grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.
prereqs: Greek 203.
antireqs: Greek 203.

name: Intermediate Readings in Classical and New Testament Greek
desc: Translation and study of text(s) drawn from classical Greek prose and/or the New Testament.
prereqs: Greek 301.
antireqs: Greek 301.

name: Topics in Greek Prose
desc: Readings will normally be selected according to genres, such as Historiography, Oratory, Philosophic and Didactic Prose, and the Novel.
prereqs: Greek 303.
antireqs: Greek 303.

name: Topics in Greek Poetry
desc: Readings will normally be selected according to genres, such as Epic, Tragedy, Comedy and Lyric.
prereqs: Greek 303.
antireqs: Greek 303.

name: Directed Studies in Greek
desc: Readings may be selected from any genre of Greek text at an advanced level.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Introductory Ancient Greek for Graduate Students
desc:
Introduction to grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.
Greek 602.01 Ancient Greek I Greek 602.02 Ancient Greek II
prereqs: Greek 602.01 must be taken before Greek 602.02.
antireqs: Greek 602.01 must be taken before Greek 602.02.

name: Intermediate Ancient Greek for Graduate Students
desc: Consolidation of grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.

name: Introduction to Greece and Rome
desc: A historical survey from the eighth century BCE to the fourth century CE.

name: Classical Mythology and Literature
desc: An introduction to Greek and Roman myths as presented in classical literature and art, and to their cultural context.

name: Technical Terms of Medicine and the Life Sciences
desc: The Greek and Latin elements of modern medical and life-sciences terminology, with a brief introduction to their history and cultural background.

name: Greek Religion
desc: A survey of religious beliefs and practices in the pre-Christian Greek world.
prereqs: 3 units from Greek and Roman Studies 205, 209, Religious Studies 201, 205, 273.
antireqs: 3 units from Greek and Roman Studies 205, 209, Religious Studies 201, 205, 273.

name: Roman Religion
desc: A survey of religious beliefs and practices in the pre-Christian Roman world.
prereqs: 3 units from Greek and Roman Studies 205, 209, Religious Studies 201, 205, 273.
antireqs: 3 units from Greek and Roman Studies 205, 209, Religious Studies 201, 205, 273.

name: Comparative Mythology
desc: An examination of Greek and Roman myths in comparison with myths of other cultures and societies.

name: Sport in Ancient Greece and Rome
desc: A survey of sports practised in Greece and Rome and the role of sport as a cultural, political and historical phenomenon.

name: The Ancient Novel and Its Predecessors
desc: A survey of ancient Greek and Roman 'novels' or romances, with reference to their roots in epic poetry and New Comedy.

name: Women and the Family in the Greek and Roman World
desc: A survey of the lives, social roles and representations of women based on documentary evidence, literature and art. Emphases may vary from term-to-term.

name: Humorous Prose:  From Rome to the Renaissance
desc: A survey of ancient, medieval and Renaissance humorous prose, with reference to their roots in classical literature.

name: Ancient Technology
desc: A survey of major technologies in antiquity (metallurgy, agriculture, hydraulics, pottery, textiles, transportation, writing, construction) with special emphasis on the technological achievements of the Bronze Age and the cultures of Greece and Rome.

name: Ancient Medicine and the Mind
desc: A survey of ancient science and medicine, with special emphasis on early conceptions of the human mind, thought and knowledge.

name: Greek Art and Architecture
desc: A survey of Greek art and architecture from the Bronze Age to the Hellenistic period.

name: Roman Art and Architecture
desc: A survey of Roman art and architecture from the Etruscans to the beginning of the Christian Empire.

name: The Ancient Near East to Alexander the Great
desc: History of the Near East from the tenth to the fourth century BCE.

name: Early Greece
desc: Early Greece from the late Bronze Age to the Persian Wars.

name: History of Classical Greece
desc: History of the Greek world from the Persian Wars to the conquests of Alexander the Great.

name: History of Rome's Expansion into the Mediterranean to 30 BCE
desc: The expansion of Rome into an empire to the time of Augustus.

name: Rome: The Late Republic and Early Empire
desc: History of Rome from 133 BCE to 180 CE.

name: Late Roman Antiquity
desc: History of the Roman and Byzantine world from 180 to 565 CE.

name: Warriors and Lovers: Greek Literature in Translation
desc: An introduction to Greek literature from Homer to the Hellenistic Period.

name: Myths, Slaves and Heroes: Roman Literature in Translation
desc: An introduction to Roman literature from its beginnings to the second century CE.

name: Topics in Early and Classical Greek History
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in Hellenistic and Roman Republican History
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in the History of the Roman Empire
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in Late Antiquity
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in Greek and Roman Political and Military History
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in Greek and Roman Social and Economic History
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics: Greeks, Romans and Other Cultures
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Studies in Ancient Myths
desc: Studies in the nature and functions of myth in ancient Greek and Roman culture and society. Topics will reflect developments in current research, will vary from term-to-term, and will be announced in advance.
prereqs: Greek and Roman Studies 209.
antireqs: Greek and Roman Studies 209.

name: Topics in Greek and Roman Religion, Intellectual and Cultural History
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in Greek Art and Archaeology
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in Roman Art and Archaeology
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in Greek Literature in Translation
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in Latin Literature in Translation
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research.

name: Topics in Ancient Greece and Rome on Film
desc: The reception of ancient Greek and Roman mythology and history through selected films.

name: Practicum
desc: Provides students with program-related experiential learning through practical activities such as teaching, editing, publishing, translating, performances, exhibitions, museum work, conferences, information and website development, and campus, school and community programs.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Field Work
desc: Provides credit, when transfer credit is not available of program-related study or field work in Europe or the Mediterranean area. Preliminary readings and a substantial report are normally required.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Field Work
desc: Similar to Greek and Roman Studies 491 but provides 6 units of credit for appropriate projects.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Topics in Ancient and Medieval Historiography
desc: Topics will include the analyses of the methods, sources, and key themes of major ancient and medieval historians.

name: Majors’ Special Topic
desc: Interdisciplinary course to link knowledge and skills learned throughout the student’s undergraduate career.
prereqs: Admission to one of Greek and Roman Studies or Ancient and Medieval History majors and completion of 90 units and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to one of Greek and Roman Studies or Ancient and Medieval History majors and completion of 90 units and consent of the Department.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: The Honours essay for Honours students in their final year.
prereqs: Admission to the Honours programs in Greek and Roman Studies or Ancient and Medieval History and completion of 90 units and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the Honours programs in Greek and Roman Studies or Ancient and Medieval History and completion of 90 units and consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Greek and Roman Studies
desc: Research topics in Greek and Roman history, literature, art, and archaeology. Seminar discussions will require a high level of student participation.

name: Directed Research
desc: Qualified students will undertake supervised research projects individually or in small groups.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
