antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Directed Studies
desc: Qualified students will undertake supervised research projects individually or in small groups.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Events and Ideas that Shook the World
desc: Designed for non-history majors, this course introduces students to the historical craft through a series of short lecture sequences that focus on specific events, ideas, and individuals that changed the course of world history.

name: The History of Europe
desc: Selected topics may include formation and breakdown of political structures: cultural, social, and technological continuity and change; development of religious and secular belief systems; interactions among cultures. Course content will vary each session. Please consult the History Department for more specific information.

name: An Introduction to Military History
desc: Significant events and themes in military history.

name: The World to 1500
desc: The development and rise of civilizations, their divergent and interacting patterns of belief, social and political organization and material and cultural life.

name: The World, 1500-1800
desc: The political, economic, cultural, ecological and social connections among world regions.

name: The History of China
desc: A survey of thought in China from the cultural heroes to the present, with emphasis on philosophy, religion, and ideology. Topics covered include Shang religion, Confucianism, Taoism, Mohism, minor schools of thought, Legalism, Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism, Qing textual studies, republican ideologies, nationalism, Marxism-Leninism Mao Zedong Thought, and late twentieth-century reformist movements.

name: Canada: Origins to 1867
desc: An introduction to the dynamic themes in early Canadian history. Special attention will be devoted to social, economic, and political development, Indigenous-Settler relations and the settlement of the Maritimes and the Canadas, and the opening of the West.

name: Canada Since 1867
desc: Themes in the development of the Canadian nation from Confederation to the present, with particular attention to federal-provincial relations, economic development, social movements, and western political protest.

name: The Practice of History
desc: Provides a grounding in the methods and practice of history.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled History, excluding History 200.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled History, excluding History 200.

name: Great Explorations
desc: The concept of exploration from the time of Columbus to the space voyages, based on the reading of primary sources. Topics include the idea of conquest, views of different races and religions, and myths and realities of explorers and discovered lands.

name: Slavery in the Americas
desc: History of the enslavement of Africans and their descendants in the New World from 1492 to 1888. Themes may include the slave trade, labor, culture and religion, resistance and rebellion, abolition, and slavery’s legacy.

name: The Contemporary World
desc: The contemporary world from the nineteenth century era of industrialism and empire, through to twentieth century struggles of underdeveloped countries for independence. Focus on growing global interdependency and the rise and the erosion of western cultural, economic, and political hegemony.

name: Gender History
desc: A global history of the construction of gender and sexual identities.  Examines how changing ideas about what it means to be male and female have influenced family structures, sexual mores, work life, military ideals, politics and culture.

name: East Asia from 1800
desc: The modern histories of China, Japan and Korea beginning with the Mid-Qing dynasty in China and the Late Tokugawa period in Japan.

name: Early Medieval Europe, 410-1076
desc: The sack of Rome to the eve of the Investiture Controversy. The economic, social and institutional features of Western Europe, including the origins and rise of the church, monasticism, barbarian kingdoms, feudalism and the agrarian economy.

name: High and Late Medieval Europe, 1076-1418
desc: Western Europe from the emergence of national states to the end of the Great Schism. The evolution of the economic, social, religious and cultural structures of Medieval Europe: the revival of agrarian, commercial and urban economies, the development of religious divisions, and the rise of church and state powers.

name: Europe in the Age of the Renaissance and Reformation, 1400-1559
desc: Political, social, cultural, intellectual and religious developments that transformed Europe at the end of the middle ages; roots of religious schism and its impact on politics, diplomacy and society.

name: Europe in the Era of Religious War, 1559-1715
desc: The clash of Protestant and Catholic forces, the eventual decline in religious passions, and the general crisis of the seventeenth century.

name: Death and Disorder: The History of Early Modern England
desc: An introduction to the history of early modern England with a focus on death and disorder.

name: The Age of Totalitarianism
desc: Europe from 1900 to the Cold War. Emphasis will be placed on totalitarian regimes in Italy, Germany, and the Soviet Union; war and society in the two world wars; the Holocaust; and the Cold War.

name: Twentieth-Century Canada
desc: Explores major themes in the emergence of modern Canada, with emphasis on the rise of a national consciousness, military and diplomatic involvements, the role of the state, socio-economic developments and national unity.

name: Modern Britain 1714 to Present
desc: The Industrial Revolution; nationalism and imperialism; the rise of the middle and working classes; the social welfare state; emergence of modern British society, economy, politics, and constitution.

name: Ethnicity, Race, and Immigration in Canada
desc: Examines developments in and challenges to diversity in Canada from the eighteenth to twenty-first centuries with emphasis on ethnic and immigrant cultures in rural communities and urban centres.

name: History of Popular Culture in Canada, 1850-Present
desc: Selected themes in the historical development of popular culture in Canada. Topics include: leisure and recreation, sports and games, the arts, popular entertainment, travel and tourism, national heroes and icons, consumerism and the mass media.

name: Canadian Indigenous History
desc: Indigenous Canada, from the beginnings of contact with Europeans in the sixteenth century, to the present, with particular emphasis on Indigenous-Settler relations.

name: Western Canada
desc: An exploration of Western Canadian history, including themes such as: the Indigenous peoples, European exploration, settlement, rural and urban society, social and political reform, the New West, and culture.

name: Canadian Military History
desc: Survey of the history of the Canadian military in peace and war from 1867 to the present. Emphasis will be placed on Canada's role in World War I and World War II and on the development of the Canadian military in the Cold War era.

name: A History of Canadian Politics
desc: The historical development of Canadian politics and political culture since Confederation. Major themes will include the emergence and changing role of parties, the impact of federalism, political insurgency and reform, and leadership.

name: Cities in Global History
desc: History of the making of urban, landscapes in a global context. Topics may include the development of economic centres, urban technological and infrastructural innovations, and the complex relationships developing between the metropolis and its rural and wild hinterlands.

name: Wild West/Mild West?: Comparative History of the U.S. and Canadian Wests
desc: The similarities and differences in the histories of the Canadian and U.S. Wests from the pre-colonial periods to the present. Topics may include the place of frontier and the West in national historical narratives, myths, and imaginations; Indigenous peoples; immigration and settlement; land policy and land use; and the social relationships and economies that characterize the U.S. and Canadian Wests.

name: The United States to 1877
desc: A history of the United States from colonial settlement through the era of Reconstruction.

name: The United States since 1877
desc: A history of the American people since the era of Reconstruction.

name: Latin America before Independence
desc: The history of colonial Latin America with particular reference to political, social and economic themes such as race relations, imperial rivalries and the struggle for national independence.

name: Latin America since Independence
desc: A history of the Latin American nations since independence with special attention devoted to political change, economic dependency and modernization, social and economic revolution, and inter-American relations.

name: Ways of Knowing: Science, Technology, and Medicine
desc: A transnational examination of the relationships among these traditions in historical and cultural context. Topics may include: the scientific revolution; the early modern period; nineteenth-century technology and medicine; the emergence of the modern life sciences and neurosciences; changing scientific paradigms and research traditions.

name: History of Death in Western Culture
desc: Examines the social, cultural, political, intellectual and religious developments from the Roman Empire to the contemporary period that transformed western concepts of death.

name: Military History: The Era of Revolutionary War and Total War
desc: Significant events and themes in military history from the early modern period to the end of the Second World War.

name: Military History: The Cold War Era and Beyond
desc: Significant events and themes in military history from the Cold War through to recent post-Cold War history.

name: History of Energy: From Fire to Fossil Fuels and Beyond
desc: Transnational examination of the sources and uses of energy through history and their social, political, economic, and environmental impacts.

name: Topics in World History
desc:
397.01 African History
397.02 History of the Middle East
397.03 South Asian History

name: Topics in History
desc: Exploration of select regional, thematic or methodological issues in history.

name: Military History of Africa
desc: Explores the history of warfare and military structures in Africa from earliest times to the present. Informed by what is often called the “New Military History,” discussion takes place within the context of broader social, cultural, economic and political developments.

name: The History of Taiwan
desc: Survey of Taiwan history from ca. 1550 to the present, emphasizing the history of pre-Chinese yuan-zhu-min/indigenes, Chinese migration to the island, government, society, inter-communal relations, Taiwan's international status, and recent democratization.

name: The Mongol World Empire
desc: The rise of Chinggis Khaghan (Genghis Khan) in early thirteenth-century Eurasia, the growth and conquests of the Mongol world empire, and the individual khanates of Yuan dynasty China, the Golden Horde in Russia, the Il Khanate in the Middle East, and the Chagadai Khanate in Inner Asia.

name: The Global 1960s
desc: Examines social, cultural, and political change in “the long 1960s” from a global perspective.

name: Topics in Great Cities of the World
desc: An augmented experiential learning course where students integrate their own observations and experience with scholarly readings in a “Great City.” The regional and theoretical focus of the class will vary with the subject city.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Russia and the Soviet Union
desc: A short introduction to pre-nineteenth-century Russian history and a survey of the history of Russia and the Soviet Union in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, finishing with a brief examination of post-Soviet Russia.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled History at the 300 level or Russian 317.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled History at the 300 level or Russian 317.

name: Modern Germany
desc: German political, social, and cultural history from the late nineteenth century to the present. Topics will include unification, both world wars, Nazism, the Holocaust, the division of Germany, society and politics in the Cold War, and reunification.

name: The Holocaust
desc: A survey of the history of the Holocaust in its pan-European context. Highlights the central role of antisemitism and the Nazi regime’s genocidal intentions towards Jews, takes a victim-centred approach and includes diversity of groups targeted by Nazi racial ideology.

name: The Vikings
desc: Origins and impact of Viking raids in Europe, North America, and the Middle East from the eighth through eleventh centuries, using historical accounts, archeological reports, material culture, film and fiction.

name: Early Medieval England, 500-1100
desc: An examination of early medieval England from post-Roman settlement to the Viking incursions of the ninth century and the Norman Conquest. Investigation of events crucial to shaping many of the cultural, political, and religious patterns of English life that endured into the medieval and early modern periods.

name: Societies and Cultures in the Middle Ages
desc: Explores the development and characteristics of Western medieval societies with regard to the social fabric, economic, religious, and intellectual life.

name: History of the Atlantic World
desc: The history of the Atlantic Ocean world as a zone of contact, conflict, and co-operation between and among Europeans, Indigenous peoples of the Americas, and Africans, circa 1450-1800.

name: The European Reformations of the Sixteenth Century
desc: The origins, course, and impact of the religious reformations (Protestant and Catholic) of the sixteenth century, including changes to institutional structures, theology, and popular belief.

name: Ideas and Events that Shaped Modern Europe
desc: Topics will vary to address major ideas and events that helped to shape modern Europe.

name: Canada During the World Wars
desc: The nature, course and impact of Canada's involvement in the two world wars, with emphasis on home front developments.

name: History of Religion in Canada
desc: A historical analysis of the pluralistic character of Canadian religions. Themes will include missions, Indigenous religions, awakenings, revivalism and social reform, fundamentalism and modernism, secularization and belief.

name: Canadian Environmental History
desc: Historical development of Canadian attitudes towards nature, from those of Indigenous people and first European settlers to those of the present day.

name: History of Women in Canadian Society
desc: Topics may include the role of women in the economy, politics, social reform, the law, health care, the domestic sphere, life course experiences, and culture.

name: Topics in the Canadian West
desc: Thematic treatment of topics in Western Canadian history.

name: Activism and Protest in Canada, 1867-Present
desc: Examines cultures, ideas, and practices of activism and protest since Confederation. Topics include historical forms of political, ethnic, gender, religious, legal, and class-based meanings of equality and social justice.

name: The Métis People of Canada
desc: An interdisciplinary study of the Métis people of Canada, with special emphasis on the historical, social, economic, and political factors influencing their emergence and continued survival as a distinct Indigenous group in Canada.

name: Northern Horizons: Subarctic and Arctic Canadian History
desc: Historical development of the region from the beginnings of European exploration to the present day. Themes include: the Indigenous peoples, Arctic exploration, Canadian sovereignty, and the politics of northern development.

name: History of Social Policy in Canada
desc: A historical analysis of the development of social policy in Canada from the colonial period to the present. Themes may include the relationship between citizens and government, changing perceptions on the role of the state, grassroots demands for government intervention, and the relationship between private and public programs.

name: The United States in the Era of Depression and WWII, 1900 to 1945
desc: The history of the United States from the dawn of the twentieth century through World War II, a turbulent period of wars and economic depression at the end of which the U.S. had emerged as a global superpower. Major themes include the rise of liberal reform; the experience of the U.S. in two world wars; the interplay of race, class, and gender in shaping American identity; and the economics of boom and bust culminating in the Great Depression and wartime boom of the 1940s.

name: The United States Civil War Era
desc: The political, economic and social history of the United States in the decades leading up to the Civil War, the military conflict itself and the aftermath of war.

name: From the Pueblo Uprising to Wounded Knee: A History of American-Indian Conflicts
desc: Military and political clashes between tribal groups, colonial governments, and the U.S. government from the late 1400s to the late twentieth century, focusing on causal factors and eventual socio-political consequences.

name: United States Political History
desc: Aspects of the history of American politics from the Revolution to the twentieth century. Emphasis on the process of governing; elections and party politics; legal and constitutional affairs.

name: The United States Since 1945
desc: The political, social, economic, and cultural dimensions of the United States from 1945 to the present. Major themes include the role of U.S. as a global superpower during the Cold War and after; the contest between liberalism and conservatism in American politics; the social movements of the 1960s and 1970s and their lasting impact; suburbanization and consumer culture; and the transition to a post-industrial economy.

name: From Colonies to Nation: Making the United States
desc: Explores the creation of the United States from its colonial origins through the Early National Period. Topics may include the political, military, diplomatic, legal, cultural and socio-economic challenges faced by the new nation.

name: Mexican History
desc: Themes of Mexican history from the founding of Spain’s most important colony, New Spain, to the present.

name: The Military in Latin America
desc: The history of warfare and the armed forces in Latin America from colonial times to the present. Emphasis upon modern wars, militarism, the rise of caudillos, and the impact of the military on society.

name: Latin American Revolutions
desc: Thematic treatment of social revolutions in twentieth-century Latin America.

name: History of Crime and Criminal Justice in England
desc: Crime and the development of the criminal courts and jurisdictions, the police, punishments, and correctional institutions, from medieval to modern times. Attention will be given to the relationship of criminality to moral attitudes and socio-economic conditions, and to the historic role of crime and punishment in local communities, society and the state.

name: A Cultural History of Biomedical Sciences
desc: Explores changing concepts about life, biology, and medicine from the European Renaissance to the twentieth century. Topics may include the rise of natural history, genetics, molecular biology, and neuroscience.

name: World War I
desc: An examination of the nature and course of the First World War (1914-1918), with an emphasis on the Western Front. Topics will include the historiography of the war, strategy and tactics, the impact of technology, and the effect of the war on the nations involved.

name: World War II
desc: The nature, course and short-term results up to 1950 of the Second World War in its global dimensions. The political as well as the military side of the Allied/Axis conflict will be studied.

name: History of Air Power
desc: An examination of the nature and development of air power across the world. Topics may include: technology; tactics; doctrine; the relationship between air power, weapons of mass destruction and precise attacks; the limits to air power and its role in war, peace, and deterrence.

name: Brazilian History since 1500
desc: Economic development, political institutions, social and cultural trends, and the interaction between men and women and the environment.

name: Great Britain as a Great Power, 1690 - 1970
desc: A study of British military, diplomatic and imperial history between 1690 and 1970, with a focus on the roots of Britain's power.

name: Espionage and the State, 500 BCE - 1939
desc: The rise of modern intelligence services in the West. Changes in the role, importance and technology of intelligence will be assessed. The contribution of intelligence to political and military strategy in selected conflicts will be examined.

name: Espionage and the State, 1939 to the Present
desc: Intelligence during the Second World War, the Cold War, and afterward. Changes in the role, importance and technology of attention will be assessed. The contribution of intelligence to political systems, international relations and military operations will be assessed.

name: Diplomatic History
desc:
A history of international relations and foreign policies of states in Europe and the world. 
491.01. Diplomatic History, 1793-1918 
491.02. Diplomatic History Since 1919

name: Intermediate Topics in History
desc: Selected topics in social, cultural, political, or military history. Previous topics have included the Vietnam War, the North American Petroleum Industry.

name: International History of Energy
desc: Twentieth-century history of energy in an international context. Topics may include international relations and political economy focusing on governments, international institutions, and multinational corporations and the role of energy in international conflict and co-operation.

name: Film and History
desc: Film as a historical document, in particular as a source of social and intellectual history. Topics include: the role of film at moments of decisive historical change; the content and dissemination of political ideologies and social values; film as a source of propaganda; changing attitudes to minority groups; preservation of historical detail.

name: Historical Methods and Philosophies of History
desc: A seminar for honours students on the interrelationship between the philosophies of history and historical methodology.
prereqs: History 300 and admission to Honours degree program.
antireqs: History 300 and admission to Honours degree program.

name: Religion, Politics, and Culture in Early Modern Europe
desc: Examines the nature of late medieval religion, the social impact of the Reformations, religious violence and co-existence, and the nature and practice of royal absolutism.
prereqs: History 300 and 3 units from 326, 327 or 426.
antireqs: History 300 and 3 units from 326, 327 or 426.

name: Topics in Gender and Sexuality in History
desc: An examination of gender theory and history with an emphasis on issues of sexuality. Topics and geographic concentrations will vary.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Topics in Britain and the Wider World, 1500-1800
desc: Topics in British imperial and global history.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Social and Political History of Modern Britain
desc: Topics in social, cultural and political history in early modern and modern times: e.g., the rise of the gentry and the middle class, working class identity, radical ideology and two-party politics.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Topics in Twentieth-Century German History
desc: Topics may include: thematic explorations and/or comparisons of dictatorial regimes (Nazi Germany and the German Democratic Republic); the history of the GDR; the two Germanies during the Cold War; memory and memorialization in popular culture; the contested formation of a multicultural society; and social protest in the post-WWII period. For further information on specific topics to be offered in any year, consult the History Department.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Canada and the First World War
desc: Discussion topics will focus on the major themes in Canada's Great War military experience, including the Canadian Expeditionary Force's recruitment and training, leadership, tactical doctrine, and integration within the British Expeditionary Force, as well as developments in civil-military relations, conscription politics and the country's post-war military legacy.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Canadian Biography
desc: A thematic approach to Canadian personalities, emphasizing the biographer's method and changing interpretations of major Canadian figures, e.g., the prime ministers, prominent women, radicals, prophets, scientists, explorers, entrepreneurs, journalists and artists.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Topics in Alberta History
desc: Selected topics in Alberta history with emphasis upon the use of local archival sources.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: The Canadian Military in the Second World War
desc: Examination of the political parameters imposed by the Canadian government on the military, the quality of Canadian leadership, and the "fit" between British forms of military organization and the fighting quality of Canadian soldiers, sailors and aircrew during the Second World War.
prereqs: History 300 and 349 or 431.
antireqs: History 300 and 349 or 431.

name: Exchange, Trade, and Cultural Encounter in North America
desc: The history of cross-cultural contact in North America from the late sixteenth through nineteenth centuries, examining cultures, economies, trading institutions and views of New and Old World people.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Topics in Indigenous History
desc: A history of the Indigenous peoples of Canada: the First Nations, Inuit and Métis.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Topics in Canadian Foreign and Defence Policy from 1919 to the Cold War Era
desc: Selected topics in the history of Canadian foreign policy and defence policy from the end of World War I to the 1980's.
prereqs: History 300 and one course in Canadian History.
antireqs: History 300 and one course in Canadian History.

name: Topics in American History
desc: Selected topics in the history of the United States from the colonial period to the present.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: American Memories
desc: Introduces students to the broad subject of historical memory, with a focus on the United States. Considers ways that historians have grappled with constructions of collective memory, personal memory, commemoration, and remembrance. Focuses on publicly controversial topics like remembering slavery, the Civil War, and the use of the Atomic Bomb in World War II.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Oral History
desc: Introduces students to the theory and practice of oral history. Topics include ethics, methodology, memory, and community-based research. Students will conduct oral histories as one of their assessments.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Topics in Medieval History
desc: Selected topics in Medieval History. Subjects may include: the history of medieval families; collective and individual identities, the social fabric; economic, religious and intellectual life.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Topics in the History of Science
desc: Selected aspects of the history of science, e.g., the scientific revolution, science and religion in the seventeenth century, history of scientific methods, studies of individual scientists such as Galileo, Boyle, Newton, or Darwin.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Topics in Great Power Diplomacy and Intelligence
desc: An exploration of selected themes in the history of modern statecraft. Topics may include: theories of international relations, war origins, treaty-making, Fascist diplomacy, appeasement, wartime alliances, intelligence and policy, cold war diplomacy. A seminar in which primary sources will be used.

name: Topics in Military History
desc: An examination of selected problems in modern military history. Topics may include: military theory; guerrilla warfare from the eighteenth century to the twentieth century; evolution of tactics in World War I; development of military medicine; innovation in European armies; colonial wars.

name: Formation of Anglo-Saxon Kingdoms
desc: The Anglo-Saxon period from the fifth through eleventh centuries, including invasion, the formation of kingdoms, conversion to Christianity, warfare and diplomacy, towns/trade, and West Saxon expansion under Alfred the Great.
prereqs: History 300 and 3 units of History 319, 321, or Greek and Roman Studies 347.
antireqs: History 300 and 3 units of History 319, 321, or Greek and Roman Studies 347.

name: Chinese Strategic Thought
desc: The history of Chinese strategic thought from antiquity through modernity, with emphasis on the Seven Military Classics, Chinese military history, and recent scholarship on the extent of the connection between historical and modern Chinese strategic thought.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Women in Canadian Politics
desc: A political history of women in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Topics include campaigns for suffrage, legal personhood and equality rights, women’s political activism, the evolution of public policy concerning women, and the participation of women in public life.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Slavery in Latin America and the Caribbean, 1492-1888
desc: Themes may include the slave trade, plantation and urban slavery, resistance and rebellion, women, culture and religion, abolition, free people of colour in slave societies, and the post-abolition legacy.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Latin America and the Outside World
desc: The Latin American nations in world affairs with special reference to their intellectual, economic, and political relations with Europe, North America, Africa, and the Pacific Rim. Themes will be drawn from the sixteenth to the twentieth centuries.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Topics in African History
desc: Selected topics in African history from pre-colonial times to the present. Topics may include the “Scramble for Africa,” Africa and the World Wars, decolonization and African nationalism, and mass violence and genocide.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Directed Research
desc: The analysis of historical problems and the use of primary sources.
prereqs: History 300 and consent of the Department.
antireqs: History 300 and consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in History
desc: Exploration of select regional, thematic, or methodological issues in history.
prereqs: History 300.
antireqs: History 300.

name: Honours Individual Study
desc: Directed study for Honours students in their third or fourth year.
prereqs: History 300 and consent of the Department.
antireqs: History 300 and consent of the Department.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: The Honours Thesis for Honours students in their fourth year.
prereqs: History 300 and consent of the Department.
antireqs: History 300 and consent of the Department.

name: Topics in Canadian History
desc: An examination of crucial issues in Canada's political, economic, social and cultural history.

name: Topics in History of Science
desc: Topics may include the scientific revolution, science and religion, and the reception of scientific ideas.

name: Topics in Medieval or Early Modern European History
Research Essay I
desc: Provides course-based students an opportunity to propose their MRE projects to the other students, critique as a group their methods, sources and bibliographies, and present drafts of their projects for peer comment.

name: Research Essay II
desc: In consultation with their supervisor, the student completes an essay modelled on a scholarly research article, to be evaluated on use of primary sources, historiographical framing, and argumentation.

name: Classics of Strategy
desc: Strategic thought from Sun Tzu to Clausewitz, Mahan to Corbett. Analyzes the writings of classic strategic thinkers, and then by way of case studies examines their theories as they pertain to military and political planners from the Peloponnesian War to the present.

name: Historiography and the Theories of History
Conference Course in Special Topics (Advanced Level)
Indigenous Language I
desc:
Primary emphasis on the acquisition of conversational skills and vocabulary in an Indigenous language spoken in Alberta.
301.01. Blackfoot 
301.02. Cree 
301.03. Michif 
301.04. Stoney 
301.05. Tsuu T’ina

name: Indigenous Language II
desc:
Continuation of Indigenous Languages 301, with special attention to grammatical structures and written materials. 
303.01. Blackfoot 
303.02. Cree 
303.03. Michif 
303.04. Stoney 
303.05. Tsuu T'ina
prereqs: Indigenous Languages 301 and consent of the Linguistics Division of the School.
antireqs: Indigenous Languages 301 and consent of the Linguistics Division of the School.

name: Introduction to Indigenous Studies
desc: A multi-disciplinary, theoretical and empirical overview of the situations, perspectives, and aspirations of selected Indigenous peoples with a focus on the Canadian context.

name: Indigenous Ways of Knowing I
desc: An introduction to various Indigenous peoples’ ways of knowing (epistemology) with a special emphasis on the contextualization of knowledge-building. Deals with various aspects of building knowledge, such as listening, reflection, protocol, and experience; emphasis will normally be on local traditional knowledge.

name: Indigenous Ways of Knowing II
desc: An exploration of contemporary Indigenous interpretations of traditional thought and beliefs, as well as ways of organizing, validating, and communicating knowledge in various contexts, including community, research, and learning. May introduce issues of methodology, protocol, relationship, and comparative Indigenous knowledge systems.
prereqs: 3 units from Social Work 201, Indigenous Studies 303, Social Work 553.30, Social Work 553.33 or admission to the BSW Post-Diploma.
antireqs: 3 units from Social Work 201, Indigenous Studies 303, Social Work 553.30, Social Work 553.33 or admission to the BSW Post-Diploma.

name: Cultural Immersion Field Course
desc: Experience of ceremonial and cultural activities, with a focus on four themes: living values; spirituality; health and healing; and roles, responsibilities, and respect.
prereqs: Indigenous Studies 303 or 317.
antireqs: Indigenous Studies 303 or 317.

name: Ecological Knowledge
desc: Experiential exploration, consideration, and application of Indigenous ecological knowledge, philosophies, and contemporary issues.

name: Indigenous Law in Canada
desc: Examination of the special legal and constitutional principles, provisions and instruments that have an impact on Indigenous individuals, governments and organizations. Topics covered may include aboriginal rights, treaty rights, self-government, fiduciary duties, the Royal Proclamation of 1763, the Indian Act, the 1982 Constitution, and pivotal court decisions.

name: Topics in Indigenous Gender, Sexuality and Feminism
desc: Selected topics that engage the history, politics, and contemporary contexts of Indigenous feminisms, queer studies, two-spirit studies, maternity, and masculinities in Canada and throughout Indigenous North America.

name: Topics in Canadian Indigenous Studies
desc: Selected themes in Canadian Indigenous studies.

name: Topics in International Indigenous Studies
desc: Selected themes in International Indigenous studies. May focus on Indigenous peoples of only one country.

name: Directed Research in International Indigenous Studies
desc: Supervised study of a theme in the area of International Indigenous Studies.

name: Comparative International Indigenous Communities
desc: Social, economic, and political comparisons between selected Indigenous communities throughout the world.
prereqs: 6 units from Indigenous Studies 303, 305, 399.
antireqs: 6 units from Indigenous Studies 303, 305, 399.

name: Indigenous Ethics and Protocol
desc: Examines principles underlying Indigenous ethics and academic and local research protocols, including Indigenous ways of knowing, indigenous methodologies, notions of relationship, spirituality, community, and responsibility in academic research, teaching and learning when collaborating with Indigenous peoples.
prereqs: Indigenous Studies 201 and an additional 3 units from the Core Courses in the Field of International Indigenous Studies (Anthropology 210, English 376, History 345, 443, Indigenous Studies 303, 305, 407, Indigenous Languages 301, Political Science 345, Sociology 307).
antireqs: Indigenous Studies 201 and an additional 3 units from the Core Courses in the Field of International Indigenous Studies (Anthropology 210, English 376, History 345, 443, Indigenous Studies 303, 305, 407, Indigenous Languages 301, Political Science 345, Sociology 307).

name: Indigenous Psychology
desc: An in-depth examination of research in psychology related to Indigenous populations, including the history of research, major topics, appropriate approaches to conducting research, and new directions.
prereqs: Psychology 200, 201, and admission to the International Indigenous Studies major.
antireqs: Psychology 200, 201, and admission to the International Indigenous Studies major.

name: Advanced Topics in Canadian Indigenous Studies
desc: Investigation of selected topics in Indigenous issues in Canada.
prereqs: 60 units, including 3 units in courses labelled Indigenous Studies at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units, including 3 units in courses labelled Indigenous Studies at the 300 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in International Indigenous Studies
desc: In-depth investigation of selected topics in international Indigenous issues.
prereqs: 60 units, including 3 units in courses labelled Indigenous Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: 60 units, including 3 units in courses labelled Indigenous Studies at the 300 level.

name: Principles of Innovation
desc: Innovation is a process through which knowledge and new ideas are applied to create new economic and social benefits. Students are introduced to definitions, contexts, language, dynamics, historical and contemporary examples, issues, aspects, outcomes, pitfalls, and impacts of the innovation process from a multidisciplinary perspective. Literature on innovation is explored. Seeks to develop in students the intuitive and imaginative skills necessary for inventive processes, and to investigate the impact of the innovation process. Blend of face-to-face and web-based instruction.

name: The Practice of Innovation
desc: Provides experience in the innovation process, to aid students to understand the nature of this creative process in different contexts, and to nurture innovative thinking. Hands-on project in multidisciplinary teams of students and professors. Student projects will take the form of case studies of and/or involvement in actual innovation processes in different contexts. Seeks to teach through experience and peer-based interaction the processes of invention. Term will end with an "innovation fair" of teams' presentations. Blend of face-to-face and web-based instruction.

name: A Multidisciplinary Survey of International Relations
desc: A survey of International Relations integrating the approaches applied in various Social Sciences disciplines.
prereqs: Admission to the International Relations program.
antireqs: Admission to the International Relations program.

name: Advanced Seminar in International Relations
desc: An integrative seminar on selected themes from the International Relations field.
prereqs: Admission to the International Relations program and completion of at least 60 units including International Relations 301.
antireqs: Admission to the International Relations program and completion of at least 60 units including International Relations 301.

name: Directed Study in International Relations
desc: Study of a particular topic under the direct supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Admission to the International Relations program, completion of at least 60 units, and consent of the Program Co-ordinator.
antireqs: Admission to the International Relations program, completion of at least 60 units, and consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

name: Beginners' Italian I
desc: This course, designed for students with no previous knowledge of the language, provides training in the comprehension, speaking, reading and writing of Italian.

name: Beginners' Italian II
desc: A continuation of Italian 201.
prereqs: Italian 30, Italian 201 or equivalent.
antireqs: Italian 30, Italian 201 or equivalent.

name: Second-Year Italian I
desc: An intensive course in reading, writing and oral practice.
prereqs: Italian 203.
antireqs: Italian 203.

name: Second-Year Italian II
desc: Further development of communication skills in Italian (listening, speaking, writing, reading), as well as the study of cultural issues in the Italian world with emphasis on reading.
prereqs: Italian 301.
antireqs: Italian 301.

name: Introduction to Textual Analysis
desc: Development of critical thinking and communicative skills through the analysis of selected literary and non-literary texts.
prereqs: Italian 301.
antireqs: Italian 301.

name: Communication
desc: Study of different types of communication (print and electronic media, correspondence, business). Analysis of relevant aspects of Italian contemporary life.
prereqs: Italian 301.
antireqs: Italian 301.

name: Civilization: Culture and the Arts
desc: Aspects of Italian civilization and contemporary cultural issues in Italian Studies.
prereqs: Italian 203.
antireqs: Italian 203.

name: Topics in Italian Culture and Literature
desc: A survey of Italian culture, inclusive of literary and non-literary texts, film, and popular culture. Topics such as Italian history and immigration, Italian cities, Italian food and fashion, and Italian Canadian literature and traditions, in Calgary and elsewhere are covered.

name: Topics in Italian Masterpieces: Film and Literature
desc: Study of one or more Italian works of literature and film, focusing on Italian masterpieces that have had an influence on European culture as a whole. Students will read and analyze the work(s) in English translation, and place it in its historical, philosophical, social and political context.

name: Third-Year Italian I
desc: A course in composition and conversation for advanced students in Italian. Selected readings from literary texts.
prereqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

name: Third-Year Italian II
desc: Intensive study of Italian grammar with the goal of attaining greater proficiency in written and oral communication. Grammatical analysis, vocabulary enrichment and development of conversation skills dealing with cultural issues.
prereqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

name: Selected Topics in Italian Literature
desc: Introduction to Italian literature with particular emphasis on the novel and poetry.
prereqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

name: Performance as Cultural Expression
desc: Study of Italian theatre, opera and drama as well as popular forms of cultural expression such as festival, music and figurative art.
prereqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

name: Italian Culture through Cinema
desc: Significant social, cultural and historical issues in Italian society through the medium of film.
prereqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

name: Topics in Italian Studies I
desc: Selected topics in Italian language, literature or civilization.
prereqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

name: Interdisciplinary Study of Italian Culture
desc: Capstone project in Italian studies. Analytical discussion of selected topics each related to students' field of concentration.
prereqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above and consent of the instructor.
antireqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above and consent of the instructor.

name: Topics in Advanced Textual Analysis
desc: Discussion of selected topics in Italian language, literature or culture. Course designed to develop writing skills. Review of writing strategies, spelling, punctuation, expository and argumentative techniques, using various original sources taken from journalistic, scientific, and literary texts as well as from other media.
prereqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

name: Directed Studies
desc: Directed studies for students in their third or fourth year. Qualified students will undertake research projects in their specified field of interest under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Topics in Italian Studies II
desc: A seminar course for advanced students.
prereqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Italian 303 and 3 units of courses labelled Italian at the 300 level or above.

name: Introduction to Japanese Popular Culture
desc: An introduction to the major forms of popular visual and material culture from Japan in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.

name: Beginners' Japanese I
desc: Basic concepts of modern Japanese. Reading and writing of characters, essentials of grammar, basic vocabulary, and oral drills on normal speech patterns.

name: Beginners' Japanese II
desc: Continuation of Japanese 205.
prereqs: Japanese 30 or Japanese 205.
antireqs: Japanese 30 or Japanese 205.

name: Continuing Japanese I
desc: Further acquisition of Japanese characters, and the development of conversational skills through reading and discussion of selected Japanese texts. Structural analysis of normal speech patterns. Preparation of written assignments. A continuation of Japanese 207.
prereqs: Japanese 207.
antireqs: Japanese 207.

name: Continuing Japanese II
desc: Continuation of Japanese 301.
prereqs: Japanese 301.
antireqs: Japanese 301.

name: Topics in Japanese Culture in an Immersion Setting
desc:
Introduction to contemporary Japanese culture through research projects and life experience. 
309.01. Wisdom, Imagination, and Creation309.02. Longing, Memory, and Inheritance
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Topics in Japanese Language in an Immersion Setting I
desc: Stresses oral skills and cultural understanding in an immersion setting. While the focus will be on speaking and aural comprehension, reading and writing will also be introduced.
prereqs: Japanese 207 and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Japanese 207 and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Topics in Japanese Language in an Immersion Setting II
desc: A continuation of Japanese 310.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Topics in Japanese Civilization
desc:
Distinctive features of Japanese civilization within the Asian context.
317.01. Japanese Civilization
317.02. Japanese Cinema
317.03. Japanese Cultural History in the Present Day

name: Critical Approaches to Manga and Anime
desc: A critical introduction to Japanese manga (print comics) and anime (animation) in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.

name: Japanese Video Games and Gaming Culture
desc: A critical introduction to the history, analysis, and social impact of video games from Japan and Japanese gaming culture worldwide.

name: Modern Japanese Literature in Translation
desc: An introduction to the literature and literary history of modern Japan, with readings drawn from various literary genres, from 1868 to the present.

name: Intermediate Japanese I
desc: An intermediate course giving emphasis to both writing and oral skills. Some of the more difficult aspects of modern Japanese grammar will be studied.
prereqs: Japanese 303.
antireqs: Japanese 303.

name: Intermediate Japanese II
desc: A continuation of Japanese 331.
prereqs: Japanese 331.
antireqs: Japanese 331.

name: Introduction to Japanese Literature
desc: Reading and discussion of selected works of modern Japanese literature.
prereqs: Japanese 303.
antireqs: Japanese 303.

name: Intermediate Skills in Japanese Communication
desc: Targeted focus on further development of self-expression and communication skills through speaking and listening at an Intermediate level.
prereqs: Japanese 301.
antireqs: Japanese 301.

name: Intermediate Skills in Japanese Writing
desc: Targeted focus on further development of productive (writing) skills for Japanese.
prereqs: Japanese 301.
antireqs: Japanese 301.

name: Advanced Manga Studies
desc: Advanced study of manga (print comics) in the original Japanese supplemented with theories and methods in the study of East Asian visual and popular culture.
prereqs: Japanese 303.
antireqs: Japanese 303.

name: Advanced Conversational Japanese
desc: Intensive development of Japanese oral communication skills through a variety of authentic materials.
prereqs: Japanese 331.
antireqs: Japanese 331.

name: Japanese through Contemporary Texts
desc: Language practice and cultural analysis through the study of contemporary Japanese texts. Authentic material will be selected from documents and textbooks. Students will be able to improve their reading skills while enhancing their knowledge of Japanese culture.
prereqs: Japanese 331.
antireqs: Japanese 331.

name: Japanese-Chinese Cultural Relations
desc: Discussion of cultural relations and influences between Japan and China. Topics may include cultural identities and cross-influences, literary and artistic traditions, and writing systems.
prereqs: Japanese 303 or higher (excluding Japanese 317).
antireqs: Japanese 303 or higher (excluding Japanese 317).

name: Introduction to Classical Japanese
desc: Basic introduction to classical Japanese language, including core grammar structures, sample masterpieces, and handwriting.
prereqs: Japanese 331.
antireqs: Japanese 331.

name: Introduction to Second Language Learning
desc: Introduction to the process of language learning with a focus on the development of learning strategies. Specific examples will be drawn from ancient and modern languages offered at the University of Calgary.

name: Introductory Topics in Translation Studies
desc: Basics of translation theory and practice for students with sufficient second language background. Establishes a common critical vocabulary to discuss issues in translation.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Advanced Topics in Translation Studies
desc: An in-depth study of the field of translation with a focus on the notions of aesthetics, comparative stylistics, grammar, and literary forms. The applied focus of the course will be on a high-quality translation along with a critical reflection on its production.
prereqs: Language 300.
antireqs: Language 300.

name: Topics in Cross-Cultural and Cross-Linguistic Explorations
desc: Cross-cultural and cross-linguistic comparisons of events, cultural patterns or phenomena, historical periods, or social movements with parallels in multi-cultural traditions.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Cross-Cultural and Cross-Linguistic Research Projects
desc: Cross-linguistic and -cultural analysis through group projects focusing on case studies.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Topics in the Study of Language
desc: Topics will reflect developments in current research in second language acquisition and learning.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Second Language Learning and Pedagogy
desc: Theoretical and practical overview of the processes involved in acquiring a second language, with a focus on naturalistic language acquisition and on classroom strategies and classroom language learning.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Second Language Learning and Technology
desc: Theoretical and practical aspects of incorporating technology into the language classroom. A general overview in the context of theories of second language acquisition of using the web, electronic mail, online chat discussion, and videoconferencing as tools in language teaching/learning; students will also learn to create their own websites and web activities for teaching.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Second Language Learning and Cultural Understanding
desc: An introduction to the interdisciplinary nature of "culture" as it pertains to second language teaching and learning.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Research Seminar in Second Language Learning
desc: Centred round a professor's current research project, the course will engage students as members of a collaborative research team that will serve as a practical exposure to research methods in the area of second language learning and acquisition.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Latin I
desc: This course for beginners provides the first steps towards reading Latin texts.

name: Latin II
desc: Continuation of Latin 201.
prereqs: Latin 201 or 205.
antireqs: Latin 201 or 205.

name: The Latin of Science I
desc: An introduction to Latin through ancient, medieval and modern scientific texts, designed for students in the Sciences and Engineering.

name: The Latin of Science II
desc: Continuation of Latin 205.
prereqs: Latin 205 or 201.
antireqs: Latin 205 or 201.

name: Latin III
desc: Completes the study of basic grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.
prereqs: Latin 203 or 207.
antireqs: Latin 203 or 207.

name: Intermediate Readings in Classical and Post-Classical Texts
desc: Translation and study of text(s) drawn from classical and/or post-classical Latin prose.
prereqs: Latin 301.
antireqs: Latin 301.

name: Topics in Latin Prose
desc: Readings will normally be selected according to genres, such as Historiography, Oratory, Philosophic and Didactic Prose, the Novel, Epigraphy.
prereqs: Latin 303.
antireqs: Latin 303.

name: Topics in Latin Poetry
desc: Readings will normally be selected according to genres, such as Epic, Drama, Lyric, and Satire.
prereqs: Latin 303.
antireqs: Latin 303.

name: Directed Studies in Latin
desc: Readings may be selected from any genre of Latin at an advanced level.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Introductory Language Class for Graduate Students
desc: Introduction to grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.

name: Intermediate Language Class for Graduate Students
desc: Consolidation of grammar, vocabulary and translation skills.

name: Latin America: People, Places and Popular Culture
desc: An introduction to Latin America, one of the most diverse and dynamic regions in the world. What is the origin of this diversity? How does this diversity manifest itself in today’s places and cultures? An interdisciplinary approach is taken to answering these questions, as the course material integrates archaeology, history, political science, economics, geography, anthropology, and cultural studies to introduce students to the region.

name: Field Study in Latin America
desc: An experiential learning course, designed to provide a framework for the student's empirical learning experience during the Latin American Studies Field School. Provides a forum for the sharing of cross-cultural experiences among the students, as they analyze and reflect on the realities of life in Latin America. Students will be expected to live with a local family during the Field School, to take an active part in discussions, and to participate in events and field trips.
prereqs: Consent of the Program Co-ordinator.
antireqs: Consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

name: Latin American Field Research
desc: In a Latin American field setting, this course guides students in integrating their own observations and experiences with scholarly readings on themes of relevance and importance to the particular setting. Attention is paid to the archaeological and historical contexts as well as present day economic, political, and social issues of Latin America. The regional and theoretical focus of the material will vary according to the location at which the course is given.
prereqs: Consent of the Program Co-ordinator.
antireqs: Consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

name: Critical Contemporary Issues in Latin America
desc: An analysis of critical issues that provides students with a framework for understanding Latin America today. Examines themes of contemporary importance, which may include human rights, indigenous issues, energy, the environment, democratization, poverty and inequality, social movements, migration, and the region’s relationship with the United States.

name: Integrative Seminar in Latin American Studies
desc: An advanced seminar involving research on a special Latin American topic integrating a variety of disciplinary and interdisciplinary perspectives (e.g. political science, anthropology, geography, cultural studies).
prereqs: Latin American Studies 201 or 211; and 203 or 311, and 48 units.
antireqs: Latin American Studies 201 or 211; and 203 or 311, and 48 units.

name: Directed Study in Latin American Studies
desc: Students devise a research question and carry out a program of independent research with a specialist on a topic in the area of Latin American Studies.
prereqs: 48 units and consent of the Program Co-ordinator.
antireqs: 48 units and consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

name: Introduction to Legal Studies
desc: Overview of the role of law in society. Examination of different concepts of law. Study of legal rules, institutions, processes and personnel in social context. Discussion of construction and exercise of the power of law. Emphasis on Canadian law and legal system.

name: Introduction to Legal Knowledge
desc: Examination of the philosophy and science of law as tools of social engineering. Students will be introduced to tort, contract, property and criminal law and will review different schools of thought and legal movements specific to these areas of law. Current legal developments (including decided Canadian cases) will be covered to illustrate how concepts such as risk, negligence, neighbour principle, contractual obligations, offer and acceptance, consideration, remedies and punishment play out in contemporary Canadian society.

name: Research Methods in Law and Society
desc: Research and writing methods including legal research basics, legal analysis, qualitative strategies in socio-legal studies, academic writing, and academic methodology.
prereqs: Law and Society 201 and 203.
antireqs: Law and Society 201 and 203.

name: Equality Issues
desc: An examination of the ability of the law to guarantee equality. Issues of gender, racial and class equality will be explored. Topics may include employment law, civil law, criminal law, reproductive rights and family law. All material is studied as it pertains to the Canadian legal culture.
prereqs: Law and Society 201 and 203.
antireqs: Law and Society 201 and 203.

name: Self-Regulation
desc: Examines how individuals and groups create, maintain, and follow non-legal codes of conduct and, in turn, regulate themselves and society. Students will be introduced to concepts of self-governance and moral regulation found in social manners, community standards, religious beliefs, as well as, consciously "legislated" group mechanisms such as professional codes of conduct, mission statements, and corporate governance practices.
prereqs: Law and Society 201 and 203.
antireqs: Law and Society 201 and 203.

name: Topics in Law and Society
desc: An examination of selected topics in Law and Society.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Law and Society at the 300 level.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Law and Society at the 300 level.

name: Liberalism
desc: An examination of the fundamental conceptions of rights and freedoms in the works of J.S. Mill and twentieth- and twenty-first-century philosophers. The treatment of these concepts in contemporary law and their role in contemporary legal and social issues are explored as well.
prereqs: 60 units including Law and Society 335 and 337 and admission to the Law and Society program.
antireqs: 60 units including Law and Society 335 and 337 and admission to the Law and Society program.

name: Socio-legal Issues in Contemporary Liberal Societies
desc: An examination of the ways in which fundamental premises of legal liberalism, such as fairness, equality, and individual liberty, intersect with each other and with other key social values and premises. May include privacy, the nature of the rights attached to property, the different understandings of democracy operating in different countries, and the extent to which the state should support religion.
prereqs: 60 units including Law and Society 413 and admission to the Law and Society program.
antireqs: 60 units including Law and Society 413 and admission to the Law and Society program.

name: Law and Technology
desc: Examines the relationship between law and legal institutions on the one hand, and science and technology on the other. Through close readings of texts and in-depth class discussion, students will investigate thematic issues such as the role of law in regulating science and technology; challenges to law raised by scientific discoveries and new technologies; and the influence of science and technology on law and legal institutions.
prereqs: 60 units including Law and Society 335 and 337.
antireqs: 60 units including Law and Society 335 and 337.

name: Directed Study
desc: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Law and Society Honours Thesis and Seminar
desc: Students will conduct an independent research project under the direction of a supervisor. In the seminar, students will discuss and present their projects and other topics relevant to conducting research.
prereqs: 3 units from the list of Research Methods Courses within Courses Constituting the Field of Law and Society; admission to the Law and Society Honours program; and consent of the Department.
antireqs: 3 units from the list of Research Methods Courses within Courses Constituting the Field of Law and Society; admission to the Law and Society Honours program; and consent of the Department.

name: Integrative Seminar
desc: An advanced seminar integrating philosophical, theoretical, social, and legal approaches to understanding the relationship between law and society.
prereqs: 90 units including Law and Society 413 and 415, and admission to the Law and Society major.
antireqs: 90 units including Law and Society 413 and 415, and admission to the Law and Society major.

name: Introduction to Linguistics I
desc: Introduction to the scientific study of language, including the analysis of word, sentence, and sound structure, and the exploration of language as a human, biological, social, and historical phenomenon.

name: Introduction to Linguistics II
desc: Further introduction to the scientific study of language. Topics include: language change, language acquisition, language families and areas, sociolinguistics, psycholinguistics, and bilingualism, and writing systems.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Modern English Grammar
desc: A comprehensive exploration of contemporary English, based on modern linguistic analysis, but also includes traditional grammatical terminology, as well as language change, attitudes to language varieties and problems in usage.

name: Language and Advertising
desc: An investigation of the nature of persuasive messages from the perspective of linguistic theory. Topics may include truth and falsity, implication, ambiguity, and context-dependence.

name: Varieties of English
desc: Survey and analysis of the varieties of English currently spoken in the world, including various dialects, especially Canadian and American, and English-based pidgins and creoles.

name: Rap Linguistics
desc: The leading music genre known as rap is dominated by language. Explores how this creatively flourishing art-form relates to language science. An examination of the manipulation of sounds, words, grammar, and meaning in rap, and what it reveals about language in the mind and in society.

name: Syntax I
desc: Introduction to syntax. Emphasis on tree-drawing and basic argumentation skills. Topics may include: syntactic categories; grammatical, thematic, and structural relations; syntactic movement.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Phonology I
desc: Theory and practice of phonological analysis: the classical phoneme; distinctive features and their organization; methods of analysis; underlying and surface representations; rules and derivations.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Language and Power
desc: The nature of the linguistic resources used to create, enhance and justify positions of dominance or subordination, or to influence and persuade populations. Examples drawn from the discourse of gender and ethnic relations, government and business.

name: Language Acquisition I
desc: Introduction to basic ideas and issues in first- and second-language acquisition. Adopts a linguistic approach, viewing language acquisition as the acquisition of a “mental grammar”, looking at examples from sound, sentence structure, word learning and meaning. Focus on defining the essential properties of an explanatory theory of language acquisition.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Introduction to Semantics
desc: Introduction to the study of conventional meaning. Topics may include: word meaning, propositional and predicate logic, properties of quantifiers, definite and indefinite descriptions, and pragmatics.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Introduction to Speech-Language Pathology
desc: A comprehensive overview of the subject including: basic components of speech and language, normal language development, communication disorders, and current professional issues.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Phonetics I
desc: Intensive practice in the perception, production and transcription of speech sounds accompanied by an introduction to the physiology and acoustics of speech.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Language and Mind
desc: An overview of central issues in the study of language and its relationship to the human mind. Topics may include the nature/nurture debate, human specialization for language, and theories of mental representation.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Historical Linguistics I
desc: Central topics in the study of language change including: principles and methods of linguistic reconstruction; universals, typologies, and the explanation of language change; sources of language change with a consideration of acquisitional and sociolinguistic factors.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Introduction to Sociolinguistics
desc: Social differentiation of language in terms of the gender, socio-economic status and geographical distribution of speakers.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Introduction to Pragmatics
desc: An introduction to the study of context-dependent meaning. Topics may include: deixis, reference, implicature, presupposition, speech acts, and information structure.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: The History of English
desc: An introduction to important changes and stages in the history of English including its Indo-European and Germanic origins and a consideration of Modern English grammar and orthography from a historical perspective.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Syntax II
desc: A theoretically grounded approach to syntax using data from a variety of languages. Constructing and evaluating syntactic hypotheses. May involve collecting data from a native speaker of a foreign language.
prereqs: Linguistics 301.
antireqs: Linguistics 301.

name: Phonology II
desc: Recent issues in phonological theory.
prereqs: Linguistics 303.
antireqs: Linguistics 303.

name: Morphology I
desc: An introduction to the study of word-structure, inflectional and word-formation morphology, morphological processes, morphological organization, interfaces with phonology and syntax. Practical problems in word analysis.

name: Language Acquisition II
desc: In-depth investigation of issues in language acquisition. Topics include differentiating populations of learners (monolingual, bilingual and delayed first-language learners, child and adult second-language learners, heritage language learners) and the exploration of different kinds of research tasks and methods.
prereqs: Linguistics 316.
antireqs: Linguistics 316.

name: Advanced Semantics
desc: Continuing study of conventional meaning accompanied by an introduction to some technical tools used in the field of semantics. Topics may include: compositionality, sets and functions, tense, aspect, modality, and event semantics.
prereqs: Linguistics 319.
antireqs: Linguistics 319.

name: Phonetics II
desc: Continuing study of the anatomy, physiology, and acoustics of speech and related issues in speech research, paralleled by laboratory work in the acoustic and physiological analysis of speech.
prereqs: Linguistics 341.
antireqs: Linguistics 341.

name: History of Linguistic Thought
desc: A survey of major schools of linguistic thought. Focus on the origin and development of concepts central to contemporary linguistic theory.
prereqs: Linguistics 301 or 303.
antireqs: Linguistics 301 or 303.

name: Historical Linguistics II
desc: Theoretical approaches to current topics in the field of historical linguistics. Research methods and practical skills in data collection and analysis.
prereqs: Linguistics 353.
antireqs: Linguistics 353.

name: Typology
desc: Study of the unity and diversity of the world's languages. How do the grammars of individual languages differ from each other, and in what ways are they all alike? Which characteristics are common across languages, and which are rare? An overview of the methodology and main results of typological research. Students work with data from unfamiliar languages.
prereqs: Linguistics 201 and 301.
antireqs: Linguistics 201 and 301.

name: Psycholinguistics
desc: Exploration of the cognitive, neuropsychological, and social processes that underlie language abilities, with reference to linguistic theory.
prereqs: Linguistics 201.
antireqs: Linguistics 201.

name: Field Methods for Indigenous Languages
desc: Principles and techniques of collecting, editing and analyzing elicited linguistic data and associated problems. Practical experience with language consultant(s).
prereqs: Linguistics 301 and 303.
antireqs: Linguistics 301 and 303.

name: Morphology II
desc: A survey of issues in morphological theory.
prereqs: Linguistics 401 and 407.
antireqs: Linguistics 401 and 407.

name: Advanced Syntactic Analysis
desc: A survey of current work in syntactic theory.
prereqs: Linguistics 401.
antireqs: Linguistics 401.

name: Advanced Phonological Analysis
desc: An advanced course on current work in phonological theory.
prereqs: Linguistics 403.
antireqs: Linguistics 403.

name: Topics in Language Acquisition
desc: Exploration of a selected topic related to current research in language acquisition. Topics may include current research on a specific population of learners, a particular research methodology, and the acquisition of a specific learning problem (e.g., phonotactics, intonation, binding, quantification).
prereqs: Linguistics 416.
antireqs: Linguistics 416.

name: Formal Semantics of Natural Language
desc: Central issues in the logical semantics of natural language, focusing on topics such as quantification, scope, and the interpretation of pronouns.
prereqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.
antireqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.

name: Survey of Indigenous Languages of the Americas
desc: A survey of the indigenous languages of the Americas, including classifications of language families and structural analysis of selected languages.
prereqs: Linguistics 301 or 303.
antireqs: Linguistics 301 or 303.

name: Topics in Phonetics
desc: Exploration of a selected topic related to current research in phonetics. Topics may include theories of speech perception, speech production, the relationship between phonetics and phonology, sources of phonetic variation, or experimental methodologies used in phonetics research.
prereqs: Linguistics 441.
antireqs: Linguistics 441.

name: Topics in Linguistic Analysis
desc: Linguistic analysis of a language or language family.
prereqs: Linguistics 301 or 303.
antireqs: Linguistics 301 or 303.

name: Topics in Historical Linguistics
desc: An advanced course in the theory of historical linguistics.
prereqs: Linguistics 453.
antireqs: Linguistics 453.

name: Statistics for Linguistic Research
desc: Introduction to basic statistical concepts, methods of analysis, and quantitative modelling techniques, with a focus on their application to the unique properties of language research and linguistic data.
prereqs: Consent of the Linguistics Division of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the Linguistics Division of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Corpus and Experimental Methods for Syntax and Semantics
desc: Introduction to programming methods for the development and searching of text corpora, as well as the design and implementation of studies using open source software. Study design will be introduced through critical reading of studies covering a range of syntactic and semantic phenomena.
prereqs: Linguistics 319 and 401.
antireqs: Linguistics 319 and 401.

name: Honours Seminar
desc: Students carry out a specific research project under the supervision of a staff member and submit a thesis acceptable to the Linguistics Division of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
prereqs: Admission to the Linguistics Honours degree program.
antireqs: Admission to the Linguistics Honours degree program.

name: Advanced Topics in Linguistics
desc: Seminar in linguistics for advanced students.
prereqs: Consent of the Linguistics Division of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the Linguistics Division of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Introduction to Graduate Studies in Linguistics
desc: This course provides an introduction to areas of research and theoretical orientations in which faculty in this department specialize, as well as to research and professional skills.

name: Field Methods
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Advanced Syntactic Analysis
desc: An advanced course in syntactic theory with focus on analytical and critical skills required for conducting syntactic research.
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Advanced Phonological Analysis
desc: An advanced course in phonological theory with focus on analytical and critical skills required for conducting phonological research.
prereqs: Linguistics 403 and consent of the program.
antireqs: Linguistics 403 and consent of the program.

name: Topics in Linguistic Theory
desc:
Seminar in any area of theoretical linguistics, including phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. 
631.01. Phonetics 
631.02. Phonology 
631.03. Morphology 
631.04. Syntax 
631.05. Semantics
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Topics in Language Acquisition
desc:
Seminar in language acquisition. 
633.01. First Language Acquisition 
633.02. Second Language Acquisition
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Analysis of a Language or Language Family
desc: Seminar in the analysis of a selected language or language family
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Topics in Historical Linguistics
desc: Seminar in historical linguistics.
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Quantitative Modelling of Linguistic Data
desc: Introduction to basic statistical concepts, methods of analysis, and quantitative modelling techniques, with a focus on their application to the unique properties of language research and linguistics data.
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Methods for Corpus and Experimental Studies in Syntax and Semantics
desc: Introduction to programming methods for the development and searching of text corpora, as well as the design and implementation of studies using open source software. Study design will be introduced through critical reading of studies covering a range of syntactic and semantic phenomena.
