Programming skills to convert experiment software output into a format suitable for statistical analysis will also be covered.
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Thesis Research Development
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Conference and Reading Course
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Senior Doctoral Seminar
desc: A forum for discussing and presenting candidacy paper research, thesis research, and conference presentations/publications in preparation.
prereqs: Consent of the program.
antireqs: Consent of the program.

name: Introduction to Museum and Heritage Studies
desc: Introduces the field of Museum and Heritage Studies by examining heritage sites, museums, art galleries, zoos, natural parks and others. Traditional institutions will be examined along with new forms, including virtual museums.

name: Collections and Exhibitions in Museum and Heritage Institutions
desc: Examines the nature of collecting, curating, exhibiting and interpreting material and non-material culture in museums and heritage institutions.
prereqs: Museum and Heritage Studies 201.
antireqs: Museum and Heritage Studies 201.

name: Ethics in Museum and Heritage Studies
desc: Introduction to ethics in museums and heritage studies. An examination of some recent museums and heritage resources crises. Also museum/heritage processes including the acquisition of artifacts, exhibitions and the representation of indigenous and other minority peoples, interpretation, the appropriateness of conservation, and museum management.
prereqs: Museum and Heritage Studies 201.
antireqs: Museum and Heritage Studies 201.

name: Topics in Museum and Heritage Studies
desc: An examination of selected topics in Museum and Heritage Studies.
prereqs: Museum and Heritage Studies 201.
antireqs: Museum and Heritage Studies 201.

name: Management and Planning in Museum and Heritage Institutions
desc: Examines theoretical and practical issues relating to the management of museum and heritage resources. Topics may include: exhibition planning, human resources, ethics and social responsibility, fundraising, collections, and audience development etc.
prereqs: Museum and Heritage Studies 201.
antireqs: Museum and Heritage Studies 201.

name: Directed Research in Selected Topics
desc: Supervised individual study of a special topic.
prereqs: Consent of the Program Co-ordinator.
antireqs: Consent of the Program Co-ordinator.

name: Practicum
desc: Placement at a museological or heritage institution.

name: Music Listening
desc:
Practical experience in music listening. Concert attendance, exposure to live music performances, and understanding music in its intended context. Music students must receive credit for all four courses in order to graduate.
105.01. Music Listening I105.02. Music Listening II105.03. Music Listening III105.04. Music Listening IV
prereqs: Admission to a BMus program, the BA (Music) program or the BA Honours (Music) program.
antireqs: Admission to a BMus program, the BA (Music) program or the BA Honours (Music) program.

name: Class Piano
desc: Functional approach to the piano.
prereqs: Admission to a BMus program.
antireqs: Admission to a BMus program.

name: Jazz History
desc: Directed listening and analysis of jazz forms from the early beginnings of jazz to the present. Styles examined range from Early Jazz to Jazz-Rock Fusion. Major figures considered include: Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Lester Young, Charlie Parker, Miles Davis and John Coltrane.

name: Introduction to Music Theory for Non-Majors
desc: Introduction to the materials of music through development of both aural and written skills.

name: Diatonic Harmony
desc: Part-writing and analysis with an emphasis on diatonic harmony and modulation in the music of the eighteenth century.
prereqs: Music 211 or successful completion of the Music Theory Diagnostic exam.
antireqs: Music 211 or successful completion of the Music Theory Diagnostic exam.

name: Chromatic Harmony
desc: Part-writing and analysis with an emphasis on chromatic harmony and modulation in the music of the nineteenth century.
prereqs: Music 213.
antireqs: Music 213.

name: Performance Practicum I
desc: Applied instruction in instrument or voice.
prereqs: Admission to the BMus program.
antireqs: Admission to the BMus program.

name: Performance Practicum II
desc: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
prereqs: Music 221 and admission to the BMus program.
antireqs: Music 221 and admission to the BMus program.

name: Musicianship I
desc: Development of skills in rhythm, intonation and sight-singing. Performance of two-part contrapuntal exercises with diatonic modulation.
prereqs: Admission to the Music major or minor.
antireqs: Admission to the Music major or minor.

name: Music History and Literature I
desc: Music from the Medieval through early Baroque periods.
prereqs: Admission to the Music major or minor.
antireqs: Admission to the Music major or minor.

name: Musical Cultures of the World
desc: Detailed ethno-musicological examination of non-Western traditions.
prereqs: Admission to the BMUS or BA MUSI program.
antireqs: Admission to the BMUS or BA MUSI program.

name: Introduction to Music Technology
desc: An exploration of current technology for music making and appreciation including recording hardware and software, MIDI-based devices for integration with sound systems and interactive/media performance, audio file formats, score preparations and basic audition theory.

name: Topics in Music and Popular Culture
desc: Selected topics examining popular music from a critical perspective. Examines the meaning and messages of popular music and its impact on present-day culture. Topics may include the examination of the work of specific creators or performers, the recording industry, the impact of specific instruments (e.g. guitar, percussion, electronic media, etc.), or cross-cultural influences. Attendance at relevant musical concerts and lectures may be required.

name: Topics in World Music
desc: Selected topics examining non-western musical traditions from a historical, sociological, analytical or performative perspective. Topics may include the study of particular musical traditions and repertoire or the study of an instrument or performance practice that appears among many traditions (e.g., hand-drumming). Attendance at relevant musical concerts and lectures may be required.

name: Topics in Composers and Musical Culture
desc: In-depth study of selected composers, their music, and their relationship to intellectual history (e.g., Mozart and the French Revolution), and/or examination of specific western or non-western musical cultures (e.g., Music in India, Music in post-war Germany) and their impact.

name: The Art of Music Listening
desc: An introduction to the sensuous and structural elements of music, leading to a greater appreciation for the art of music in a global multi-cultural context.

name: Materials of Twentieth-Century Music
desc: Compositional and analytical approaches to post-tonal music from the twentieth century to the present.
prereqs: Music 214 or 311.
antireqs: Music 214 or 311.

name: Performance Practicum III
desc: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
prereqs: Music 223 and admission to the BMus program. Students not admitted to a BMus program may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Music 223 and admission to the BMus program. Students not admitted to a BMus program may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Performance Practicum IV
desc: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
prereqs: Music 321 and admission to the BMus program. Students not admitted to a BMus program may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Music 321 and admission to the BMus program. Students not admitted to a BMus program may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Musicianship II
desc: Further development of skills in rhythm, intonation and sight-singing. Introduction to atonal exercises and improvisation.
prereqs: Music 225.
antireqs: Music 225.

name: Second Instrument Study
desc:
Applied instruction on second instrument or voice.
327.01 Second Instrument Study I327.02 Second Instrument Study II327.03 Second Instrument Study III327.04 Second Instrument Study IV327.05 Second Instrument Study V327.06 Second Instrument Study VI327.07 Second Instrument Study VII327.08 Second Instrument Study VIII
prereqs: Open to Music Majors with consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Open to Music Majors with consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Jazz Musicianship
desc: Musicianship in the jazz idiom, stressing the aural perception of jazz scales and modes, seventh-chord and harmonic extensions, common jazz progressions and jazz rhythms.
prereqs: Music 211 or 213.
antireqs: Music 211 or 213.

name: Music History and Literature II
desc: Music from the Late Baroque, Classical and Romantic periods.
prereqs: Music 230 or 232.
antireqs: Music 230 or 232.

name: Music History and Literature III
desc: Music from the Modern Era.
prereqs: Music 330.
antireqs: Music 330.

name: Composition I
desc: Basic compositional techniques, and study of selected twentieth-century compositions.
prereqs: Music 214.
antireqs: Music 214.

name: Composition II
desc: Continued study of compositional techniques and study of selected twentieth-century compositions.
prereqs: Music 341.
antireqs: Music 341.

name: Sonic Arts
desc: An introduction to the creative use of computers and digital media in sonic arts.

name: Sound Recording
desc: An introduction to the practice and theory of sound and music recording.

name: Form and Analysis
desc: Investigations into hierarchical relations in music. Study of how various levels of musical structure relate in order to form a whole.
prereqs: Music 313.
antireqs: Music 313.

name: Advanced Harmonic Analysis
desc: Investigation of the expanded harmonic resources and analytical systems used by composers from the late nineteenth century to the present.
prereqs: Music 313.
antireqs: Music 313.

name: Performance Practicum V
desc: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
prereqs: Music 323 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Music 323 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Performance Practicum VI
desc: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
prereqs: Music 421 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Music 421 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Professional Seminar in Music Performance I
desc: Practical experience in music performance in a team teaching master class format.
prereqs: Music 323 and admission to the BMus (Performance) program.
antireqs: Music 323 and admission to the BMus (Performance) program.

name: Jazz Improvisation
desc: Topics in jazz improvisation, stressing improvisational tools, melody, rhythm, and ear development for the blues progression.
prereqs: Music 213 and admission to the music major or minor.
antireqs: Music 213 and admission to the music major or minor.

name: Composition III
desc: Advanced creative work with an emphasis upon either chamber music composition or studio composition.
prereqs: Music 343 and consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Music 343 and consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Composition IV
desc: Continued advanced creative work with an emphasis upon either chamber music composition or studio composition.
prereqs: Music 441 and consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Music 441 and consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Counterpoint
desc: Practical study of contrapuntal technique, including species counterpoint and eighteenth-century counterpoint.
prereqs: Music 313.
antireqs: Music 313.

name: Orchestration
desc: Practical study of instrumentation and scoring, including orchestral and wind ensemble textures.
prereqs: Music 313.
antireqs: Music 313.

name: Electroacoustic Music
desc: Practical study of electroacoustic and computer music with an emphasis on creative work in the medium.

name: Computer Applications in Music
desc: Use of computers in music composition, performance, education and interdisciplinary media.

name: Junior Performance Project
desc: Applied instruction in instrument or voice in connection with junior recital.
prereqs: Admission to the BMus (Performance) program.
antireqs: Admission to the BMus (Performance) program.

name: Selected Topics in Theory and Composition
desc: Advanced topics in music theory and composition selected from such subjects as: analysis of tonal or post-tonal music, rhythmic analysis, acoustics, critical approaches to music theory, electroacoustic music, orchestration, counterpoint and fugue.
prereqs: 3 units from Music 415, 417, 445, 447, 451.
antireqs: 3 units from Music 415, 417, 445, 447, 451.

name: Seminar in Theory and Composition
desc: Creative and analytic approaches to the study of selected repertoire with an emphasis upon contemporary music.
prereqs: 3 units from Music 415, 417, 445, 447, 451.
antireqs: 3 units from Music 415, 417, 445, 447, 451.

name: Performance Practicum VII
desc: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
prereqs: Music 423 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Music 423 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Performance Practicum VIII
desc: Continuation of applied instruction in instrument or voice.
prereqs: Music 521 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Music 521 and admission to the BMus (Composition, Music History and Theory, or Integrated Studies) program. Students not admitted to the stated BMus programs may register with an audition and consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Topics in Music Performance
desc: Various topics such as applied music literature, piano, wind or string pedagogy, or vocal pedagogy, phonetics.
prereqs: Admission to the BMus or BA(Music) Program and consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Admission to the BMus or BA(Music) Program and consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Professional Seminar in Music Performance II
desc: Continued practical experience in music performance in a team teaching master class format.
prereqs: Music 427 and admission to the BMus (Performance) program.
antireqs: Music 427 and admission to the BMus (Performance) program.

name: Research Techniques and Bibliography of Music
desc: Exploring the basic reference materials and techniques for musical research in all areas.
prereqs: 3 units from Music 332, 333, 336.
antireqs: 3 units from Music 332, 333, 336.

name: Selected Topics in Musicology
desc: A specific musical medium or genre: may include chamber music literature, symphonic literature, dramatic literature and program music.
prereqs: 3 units from Music 332, 333, 336.
antireqs: 3 units from Music 332, 333, 336.

name: Studies in the Music of Selected Composers
desc: Specific composers or groups of composers; may include Beethoven, Debussy, the Second Viennese School, etc.
prereqs: 3 units from Music 332, 333, 336.
antireqs: 3 units from Music 332, 333, 336.

name: Networked Music Performance
desc: Investigation of music performance on high-speed networks.

name: Topics in Sonic Arts
desc: Topics in Sonic Arts selected from such subjects as Sound and Image, Soundscape and Sonic Design, Sound and Space in Sonic Arts, Live Electronic Music and Electroacoustic Music Composition.

name: Senior Project
desc: Major research or creative project in an area of musical study.
prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Independent Study
desc: Individual study in a selected area of music.
prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Senior Performance Project
desc: Applied instruction in instrument or voice in connection with a Senior Recital.
prereqs: Admission to the BMus (Performance) program, Music 313 and 3 units from 333 or 336.
antireqs: Admission to the BMus (Performance) program, Music 313 and 3 units from 333 or 336.

name: Selected Topics in Theory and Composition
desc: Various topics (master's level).

name: Seminar in Theory and Composition
desc: Advanced creative and analytic approaches to the study of selected repertoire with an emphasis upon contemporary music.

name: Pedagogy of Music Theory
desc: Refining ideas about music theory and its teaching, while developing and strengthening teaching skills.

name: Advanced Performance Practicum I
desc: Applied instruction in instrument or voice.

name: Advanced Performance Practicum II
desc: Continuation of Music 621.
prereqs: Music 621 or Music Performance 691.
antireqs: Music 621 or Music Performance 691.

name: Topics in Music Performance
desc: Various topics such as applied music literature, applied pedagogy, accompanying, phonetics and others.

name: Studies at the Banff Centre
desc: Advanced music studies.

name: Research Techniques and Bibliography of Music
desc: Exploring the basic reference materials and techniques for musical research at the graduate level.

name: Selected Topics in Musicology
desc: Various topics such as history of music theory, analysis, notation, or performance practice may be offered. Consult the timetable for current topic.

name: Composition Seminar
prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Music.
antireqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Selected Topics in Electroacoustic Music
desc: Advanced topics in computer music selected from such subjects as: analysis, theory and aesthetics of electroacoustic repertoire, computer programming and software design, interactivity, performance practice and interpretation, sound morphology, sound spatialization, sound synthesis, soundscape studies, tele-media.

name: Projects in Computer Music
desc: Individual and collaborative creative and research projects in computer music.

name: Independent Study
desc: Individual study in a selected area of music.

name: Advanced Topics in Theory and Composition
desc: Various topics (doctoral level).

name: Selected Topics in Musicology
desc: Various topics in the field of Musicology (doctoral level).

name: Composition
desc: Individual study in musical composition (doctoral level).

name: Advanced Topics in Electroacoustic Music
desc: Advanced topics in computer music selected from such subjects as: interactivity, tele-media, sound morphology, sound spatialization, analysis, theory and aesthetics, performance practice and interpretation, computer programming and software design, sound synthesis, soundscape studies.

name: Advanced Projects in Computer Music
desc: Individual and collaborative creative and research projects in computer music.

name: Independent Study
desc: Individual study in a selected area of music (doctoral level).

name: Conducting I
desc: Basic conducting techniques with the use of the baton; simple and condensed scores for selected choral and instrumental works.
prereqs: Music 211 and 225.
antireqs: Music 211 and 225.

name: Conducting II
desc: Continuation of Music Education 331; the full score and more difficult choral and instrumental works.
prereqs: Music Education 331.
antireqs: Music Education 331.

name: Popular Music Pedagogy
desc: Strategies for integrating popular music into the curriculum, including popular music listening strategies, pedagogical approaches and hand-on experience with modern band instruments including guitar, bass, keyboard, drum set, vocals and technology.

name: Elementary Music Education
desc: Strategies for teaching music at the elementary level both in schools following the Alberta curriculum and community contexts.  Learning experiences will help students design lessons with a strong emphasis on music making appropriate for young learners.

name: Instrumental and Band Techniques I
desc: Performing and teaching techniques for instruments used in the schools.
prereqs: Music Education 331.
antireqs: Music Education 331.

name: Instrumental and Band Techniques II
desc: Continuation of Music Education 401. Musical and practical aspects of band conducting, including teaching skills, curriculum and appropriate teaching strategies.
prereqs: Music Education 401.
antireqs: Music Education 401.

name: Vocal Music in the School: Teaching Methods and Materials
desc: Introduction to a comprehensive vocal program for elementary and secondary classrooms, including teaching methods and materials.
prereqs: Music Education 331.
antireqs: Music Education 331.

name: Vocal Music in the School: Curriculum and Teaching Strategies
desc: Continuation of Music Education 413. Musical and practical aspects of vocal music in the classroom, including teaching skills, curriculum and appropriate teaching strategies.
prereqs: Music Education 331.
antireqs: Music Education 331.

name: Topics in Music Education
desc: Various topics such as advanced band techniques and literature, choral techniques and literature, philosophy and foundation of music education or jazz for the classroom.
prereqs: Music 213.
antireqs: Music 213.

name: Topics in Music Education
desc: Various topics such as technology in the classroom, community music practices, curricular design, educational philosophy and world music pedagogy.

name: Independent Study
desc: Individual study in a selected music education area.
prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Music.

desc: Selected topics with emphasis upon practical application relevant to the field of music education. Various topics are regularly offered under this title, such as early childhood, Kodaly pedagogy, administration of school music programs and techniques of school music supervision.

prereqs: Consent of the Division Chair, Music.

name: Mind, Matter and God
desc: An introduction to philosophy through discussion of selected topics such as skepticism, perception, personal identity, free will and determinism, God.

name: Morality, Virtue and Society
desc: An introduction to philosophy through discussion of morality, virtue and the role of morality in society.

name: Sex, Love and Death
desc: Topics to be addressed may include the nature of sex, love, and death, the relation between sex and love, sexual ethics, sexual perversion, sexual harassment and pornography, abortion, suicide, euthanasia and the value of life.

name: How Do We Know?
desc: An investigation of belief, knowledge, and error in everyday life and the sciences, including discussion of the nature of knowledge; patterns of valid reasoning and sources of error; the influence of bias on belief and knowledge; scientific reasoning and theory building; the distinction between science and pseudo-science.

name: Logic I
desc: Sentential and first-order logic from both deductive and semantic points of view. Some elementary metatheorems.

name: The Classical Period
desc: The study of a selection of philosophers from the Pre-Socratics, through Plato and Aristotle, to the Hellenistic and Roman philosophers.

name: The Medieval and Renaissance Period
desc: The study of a selection of philosophers from Augustine to Montaigne, such as Boethius, Abelard, Ibn Rushd, Maimonides, Aquinas, Ockham, and Erasmus.

name: The Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries
desc: The study of a selection of philosophers from Descartes to Kant.

name: Nineteenth- or Twentieth-Century Analytic Philosophy
desc: A study of some major analytic philosophers, such as Frege, Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Carnap, Marcus, Kripke, and/or Quine.

name: Hegel to Nietzsche
desc: A study of nineteenth-century European philosophers, such as Fichte, Schelling, Hegel, Feuerbach, Marx, Kierkegaard, Schopenhauer and/or Nietzsche.

name: Twentieth-Century Continental Philosophy
desc: A study of twentieth-century Continental philosophers such as Husserl, Heidegger, Sartre, Merleau-Ponty, Adorno, Marcuse, Habermas, Foucault, Derrida, Kristeva and/or Irigaray.

name: Bioethics
desc: A critical and analytical examination of ethical and legal problems arising in and about health care. May include euthanasia, abortion, the conditions for the withdrawal of treatment, the physician-patient relationship, research on human subjects, genetic engineering. The practical applications of ethical and legal theory are emphasized.

name: Information Technology Ethics
desc: A critical and analytical examination of ethical and legal problems arising in and about information technology. May include hacking, online privacy, intellectual property rights, artificial intelligence, globalization and regulation issues, cheating in online games, and others.

name: Philosophy in Literature
desc: Introduction to various philosophical problems, theories and points of view as found in works of literature from classical times to the present.

name: Philosophy and Film
desc: Introduction to various philosophical problems, theories and points of view as found in works of film.

name: Law and Morality
desc: An introduction to legal and political philosophy including the relation between law and morality, the nature of legal authority and political and social theory.

name: Business Ethics
desc: A critical and analytical examination of some central moral problems that arise in and for business with emphasis on the details of the particular problems studied and the conceptual and other tools needed to understand and resolve or solve such problems. May include the moral responsibilities and rights of corporations and their officers, codes of business ethics, and conflicts of responsibilities and rights.

name: Philosophy of Money
desc: An examination of the historical and contemporary philosophical issues surrounding money, such as metaphysics of value, the justice of wealth distribution, and the ethics of wealth and charity.

name: Philosophy of Religion
desc: A philosophical examination of the fundamental concepts of religious thinking.
prereqs: Religious Studies 205 or 3 units of a course labelled Philosophy.
antireqs: Religious Studies 205 or 3 units of a course labelled Philosophy.

name: Aesthetics
desc: A philosophical examination of the nature of art, and the place and character of aesthetic appreciation and activity.

name: Asian Philosophy
desc: Considers traditional philosophical topics such as metaphysics, epistemology, logic, ethics, aesthetics, political philosophy, and environmental philosophy as they are dealt with in Asian traditions or texts, as well as topics that are more specific to Asian traditions, such as actionless action, sagehood, karma, rebirth, enlightenment/liberation, egoism, and attachment.

name: Philosophy, Feminism and Gender
desc: Study of social and political issues arising from philosophical considerations of gender including the intersection of gender and race with attention to feminist analyses of gender. May include feminist methodology as well as gender issues in such areas as knowledge and science, language, ethics and political theory.

name: Issues in Environmental Ethics
desc: A philosophical examination of how humans conduct themselves in relation to other living species and the natural environment. May include: obligations to future generations; animal liberation theories; population policy; pollution; the value of species diversity and species preservation; biocentric and holistic ethical theories of environment; ethical dimension of environmental policy formation.

name: Contemporary Moral Problems
desc: A critical and analytical examination of current moral issues, such as authority, religion in society, suicide, sexual morality, abortion, the legal enforcement of morality, justice.

name: Existentialism
desc: An investigation of existentialist treatments of agency, religion, subjecthood, death, and despair. May include Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Dostoevsky, Camus, Kafka, Sartre, and de Beauvoir.

name: Evidence
desc: An investigation of philosophical perspectives on evidence, such as the nature of evidence, whether and how much evidence is required for reasonable belief and action, what sort of evidence might be required for moral, scientific, religious, or mathematical belief, and the role of evidence in medical, legal, political, and social contexts.

name: Science and Philosophy
desc: Examination of the fundamental principles of scientific enquiry, such as scientific explanation, theory, prediction and confirmation.

name: Elementary Formal Logic
desc: Sentential and first-order logic, with identity and descriptions, from both deductive and semantic points of view. Completeness, compactness, decidability for sentential logic.

name: Logic II
desc: Introduction to the metatheory of logical systems. Completeness, compactness, Löwenheim-Skolem, and undecidability theorems for first-order logic. Preview of non-standard models, second-order logic, and Gödel's first incompleteness theorem.
prereqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.
antireqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.

name: Philosophy and Psychology
desc: A study of topics such as: thought, emotions, action and the will, mind-body identity, personal identity, and theories about the nature of mind.

name: Mind and World
desc: An intensive study of selected topics in philosophy of mind, metaphysics and epistemology. Intended for philosophy majors, including students in the history and philosophy of science program.
prereqs: Admission to the BA or BA Honours in Philosophy and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the BA or BA Honours in Philosophy and consent of the Department.

name: Value Theory
desc: An intensive study of selected topics in value theory.
prereqs: Admission to the BA or BA Honours in Philosophy or in Religious Studies and Applied Ethics and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the BA or BA Honours in Philosophy or in Religious Studies and Applied Ethics and consent of the Department.

name: Topics in Philosophy
desc: A detailed examination of a topic or tradition in European or Anglo-American philosophy.

name: Topics: A Classical Philosopher
desc: A study of the writings of a philosopher from the classical period.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.

name: Topics: A Medieval or Renaissance Philosopher
desc: A study of the writings of a philosopher from the medieval or renaissance period.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.

name: Topics: A Seventeenth- or Eighteenth-Century Philosopher
desc: A study of the writings of a seventeenth- or eighteenth-century philosopher.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.

name: Topics: A Nineteenth- or Twentieth-Century Philosopher
desc: A study of the writings of a nineteenth- or twentieth-century philosopher.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.

name: Topics: A Philosopher in the Continental Tradition - Nineteenth Century to Present
desc: A study of the writings of a philosopher from the European tradition, emphasizing the influences of and on other philosophers and movements within the tradition.
prereqs: 3 units from Philosophy 309, 311, 333, 359, Religious Studies 363; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy.
antireqs: 3 units from Philosophy 309, 311, 333, 359, Religious Studies 363; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy.

name: Topics in the History of Philosophy
desc: An investigation of a historical theme or movement in philosophy.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy including 3 units from Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311.

name: Contemporary Continental Philosophy
desc: An investigation of contemporary themes or movements in Continental philosophy.
prereqs: 3 units from Philosophy 309, 311, 333, 359, Religious Studies 363; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy.
antireqs: 3 units from Philosophy 309, 311, 333, 359, Religious Studies 363; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy.

name: Topics in Continental Philosophy
desc: An investigation of a particular theme or movement in Continental philosophy.
prereqs: 3 units from Philosophy 309, 311, 333, 359, Religious Studies 363; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy.
antireqs: 3 units from Philosophy 309, 311, 333, 359, Religious Studies 363; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy.

name: Metaphysics
desc: An examination of some central topics in metaphysics.
prereqs: Philosophy 201 or 395; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Philosophy 201 or 395; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.

name: Philosophy of Law
desc: An investigation of philosophical accounts of the nature of law and legal systems including central positions in jurisprudence, such as natural law, legal realism and legal positivism; and relations between law and morality.
prereqs: 3 units from Philosophy 249, 325, 397; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 3 units from Philosophy 249, 325, 397; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.

name: Contemporary Meta-Ethics
desc: A study of recent theories about the meaning of moral terms, the nature of moral reasoning, and the relations between facts and values. May include naturalism, intuitionism, emotivism, prescriptivism, and nihilism.
prereqs: Philosophy 249 or 397; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Philosophy 249 or 397; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.

name: Contemporary Ethical Theories
desc: A detailed investigation of some central normative ethical theories, including utilitarian, contractarian, and deontological theories.
prereqs: Philosophy 249 or 397; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Philosophy 249 or 397; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.

name: Social and Political Philosophy
desc: A study of fundamental issues in social and political thought, such as rights, justice, authority, equality, freedom, democracy, property, liberalism, communitarianism, socialism, and Marxism.
prereqs: Philosophy 249 or 397; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Philosophy 249 or 397; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.

name: Epistemology
desc: An examination of some central topics in the theory of knowledge.
prereqs: Philosophy 201 or 395; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Philosophy 201 or 395; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.

name: Problems in the Philosophy of Science
desc: An examination of the central methodological and foundational issues arising in the sciences.

name: Philosophy of Language
desc: An examination of some central topics in the philosophy of language.
prereqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.
antireqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.

name: Philosophy of Logic
desc: An examination of some central topics in the philosophy of logic.
prereqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.
antireqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.

name: Logic III
desc: Advanced metatheory for logical systems. Gödel's incompleteness theorems, models of arithmetic, and definability.
prereqs: Philosophy 379.
antireqs: Philosophy 379.

name: Philosophy of Mind
desc: An examination of some central topics in the philosophy of mind.
prereqs: Philosophy 201 or 395; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: Philosophy 201 or 395; and 3 units in a course labelled Philosophy at the 300 level or above.

name: Topics in Philosophy
desc: An intensive study of a selected topic in Philosophy.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy with 3 units at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy with 3 units at the 300 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Ancient or Medieval Philosophy
desc: An investigation into central issues in ancient or medieval philosophy.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be in History of Philosophy (Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311, 401, 403, 405, 407, 408, 411, 505, 507) and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be in History of Philosophy (Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311, 401, 403, 405, 407, 408, 411, 505, 507) and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Modern Philosophy
desc: An investigation of central issues in modern philosophy.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be in History of Philosophy (Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311, 401, 403, 405, 407, 408, 411, 505, 507) and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be in History of Philosophy (Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311, 401, 403, 405, 407, 408, 411, 505, 507) and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Nineteenth- or Twentieth-Century Philosophy
desc: An investigation of central issues in nineteenth- and twentieth-century philosophy.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be in the History of Philosophy (Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311, 401, 403, 405, 407, 408, 411, 501, 505) and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be in the History of Philosophy (Philosophy 301, 303, 305, 307, 309, 311, 401, 403, 405, 407, 408, 411, 501, 505) and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in the History and Philosophy of Science
desc: An intensive investigation of one or more issues in the history and philosophy of science.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be Philosophy 201, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481 or 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level, or above.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be Philosophy 201, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481 or 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level, or above.

name: Formal Semantics of Natural Language
desc: Central issues in the logical semantics of natural language, focusing on topics such as quantification, scope, and the interpretation of pronouns.
prereqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.
antireqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.

name: Advanced Topics in Metaphysics
desc: An investigation of one or more issues in metaphysics.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 201, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481, 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 201, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481, 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Philosophy of Law
desc: An intensive investigation of one or more issues in the philosophy of law.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 249, 325, 397, 425, 449, 453 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 249, 325, 397, 425, 449, 453 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in the Philosophy of Religion
desc: An investigation of one or more issues in the philosophy of religion.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy with 3 units at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy with 3 units at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Applied Ethics
desc: An intensive investigation of one or more issues in applied ethics.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 249, 397, 425, 449, 453 and 3 units of which must be at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 249, 397, 425, 449, 453 and 3 units of which must be at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Ethics
desc: An intensive investigation of one or more issues in normative ethical theory or meta-ethics.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 249, 397, 425, 449, 453 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 249, 397, 425, 449, 453 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Political Philosophy
desc: An intensive investigation of one or more issues in political philosophy.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 249, 397, 425, 449, 453 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 249, 397, 425, 449, 453 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Epistemology
desc: An investigation of one or more issues in epistemology
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 201, 264, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481, 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 201, 264, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481, 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level.

name: Philosophical Topics in the Sciences
desc: A study of philosophical issues arising in a particular area of science, such as biology, a social science, or physics, intended for students who have already done advanced work either in philosophy or in one of the sciences.

name: Advanced Topics in Philosophy of Science
desc: An intensive study of one or more issues in the philosophy of science.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from 201, 264, 367, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481, 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from 201, 264, 367, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481, 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Philosophy of Logic and Philosophy of Language
desc: An intensive study of one or more issues in the philosophy of logic or language
prereqs: Philosophy 279 or 377; and 3 additional units in courses labelled Philosophy at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: Philosophy 279 or 377; and 3 additional units in courses labelled Philosophy at the 400 level or above.

name: Advanced Topics in Logic
desc: An investigation of one or more issues in logic.
prereqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.
antireqs: Philosophy 279 or 377.

name: Advanced Topics in Philosophy of Mind
desc: An investigation of one or more issues in philosophy of mind
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 201, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481, 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy, of which, 3 units must be from Philosophy 201, 395, 421, 423, 461, 463, 467, 481, 483 and 3 units must be at the 400 level.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: A year-long development of the honours thesis, under close supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Admission to the Honours program and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Admission to the Honours program and consent of the Department.

name: Directed Study
desc: Directed reading for students in their third or fourth years.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Honours Seminar
desc: An introduction to the writing of the honours thesis, in which all those enrolled in the Philosophy 590 share their work with each other.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Philosophy
desc: An in-depth investigation into a selected topic in Philosophy.
prereqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy with 3 units at the 400 level or above.
antireqs: 6 units in courses labelled Philosophy with 3 units at the 400 level or above.

name: Topics in the History of Philosophy
Topics in the Philosophy of Religion
Topics in Social and Political Philosophy
Topics in Philosophical Logic and the Philosophy of Language
Metalogic
desc: Introduction to the metatheory of logical systems. Completeness, compactness, Loewenheim-Skolem, and undecidability theorems for first-order logic. Preview of non-standard models, second-order logic, and Godel's first incompleteness theorem.

name: Topics in the Philosophy of Mind
Master's Research and Professional Development
desc: Students develop relevant skills for a successful academic or non-academic career. Topics include research and thesis writing strategies, presentation skills, preparing writing samples and articles for publication, teaching development including teaching portfolios, research statements, and CVs.

name: Doctoral Research and Professional Development
desc: Students develop relevant skills for a successful academic or non-academic career. Topics include research and thesis writing strategies, presentation skills, preparing writing samples and articles for publication, teaching development including teaching portfolios, research statements, and CVs.

name: Introduction to Government and Politics
desc: A systematic introduction to the basic concepts and institutions of the process of politics.

name: Political Ideologies
desc: An introduction to the study of political ideologies such as nationalism, socialism, liberalism and fascism.

name: Politics of the Global South
desc: An introduction to political issues common to the developing regions of Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Middle East, with special emphasis on topics such as democratization, globalization, development, and human rights.

name: Issues and Trends in World Politics
desc: Major trends and issues in world politics, such as international tensions, migration, ethnic conflicts, human rights and sustainable development.

name: Topics in Politics
desc: Introductory examination of a topic in Political Science with a Canadian Politics, Comparative Politics, International Relations, or Political Theory focus.

name: History of Political Thought
desc: An introduction to some of the most profound attempts to think about the meaning, limits, and possibilities of political life through an examination of selected central texts within the history of Western political philosophy.

name: Politics and Government in Canada
desc: An examination of institutions and political processes in Canada. Significant attention is paid to key institutions such as Parliament, the executive, federalism, the Constitution, and the courts. Emphasis is also placed on the way that political processes are shaped by these and other institutions.

name: Law and Politics
desc: An introduction to the interplay between legal and political personnel, institutions, and processes. Examination of these connections in democratic states focusing on Canada in comparative perspective, authoritarian regimes, transitional and hybrid regimes, and the international system.

name: Indigenous Governance
desc: An examination of the institutions and logics of Indigenous governance structures in Canada. Emphasis will be placed on understanding how inter-Indigenous modes of governance contrast with institutions created by non-Indigenous politicians and bureaucrats. Attention will be paid to kinship, gender relations, war and conflict, and treaty land management.

name: Introduction to Public Policy Analysis
desc: An introduction to themes and methods in public policy studies. The practical and normative problems facing governments in initiating, formulating, enacting, and implementing policy will be discussed. May include case studies.

name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
desc: An introduction to the central concepts, problems, and approaches that comprise the field of comparative politics. Emphasis may also be placed on key analytical challenges, competing methods, and basic governance systems in selected parts of the world.

name: Governments and Politics of the Middle East
desc: A survey and analysis of the organization and functioning of governments and politics of the contemporary Middle East, with emphasis on the social and economic environments which influence them.

name: Governments and Politics of Africa
desc: Political institutions of selected African states. The influence of class and tribal structure; political parties; elections, the source and nature of ideologies; and economic and social policies.

name: The Politics of Development
desc: A comparative survey of contemporary approaches to development theory and economics such as: modernization, neo-liberalism, post-development, critical globalism, gender and development, environment and development. Issues treated include poverty, cultural diversity, sustainability, and the role of state, market, NGOs, and science and technology.

name: Introduction to International Relations
desc: The structures and processes of international relations and foreign policy.

name: Introduction to Research Methods
desc: Introduction to the questions, strategies and rationales of political science research methods. Emphasis on the practical and theoretical advantages and disadvantages of quantitative, qualitative, and mixed-methods approaches.

name: Qualitative Research Methods
desc: An introduction to qualitative research methods in Political Science. Topics may include qualitative methodology, elite interviewing, focus groups, content analysis, case studies and qualitative data analysis.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science.

name: Quantitative Research Methods
desc: Quantitative research design, measurement, data collection, and data analysis, as conducted in Political Science.

name: Advanced Topics in Politics
desc: Advanced examination of a topic in Political Science with a Canadian Politics, Comparative Politics, International Relations, or Political Theory focus
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science at the 300 level or above.

name: Greek Love and Wisdom
desc: A study of Ancient Greek attempts to address the relationship between love, sex, marriage, friendship, and how we might best lead our lives in a political community. Works by Aristophanes, Plato, Xenophon, Aristotle, Plutarch and others may be covered.
prereqs: Political Science 310.
antireqs: Political Science 310.

name: Classical Political Thought
desc: An examination of selected classical texts from historians, dramatists and political philosophers with special focus upon the concepts relevant to political problems in the twentieth century.
prereqs: Political Science 310.
antireqs: Political Science 310.

name: The Foundations of Modernity
desc: A study of selected sixteenth- to nineteenth-century political thinkers and themes foundational to the making and understanding of modernity in the West. Works by Rousseau, Kant, J.S. Mill, and others may be covered.
prereqs: Political Science 310.
antireqs: Political Science 310.

name: Recent Critics and Defenders of Modernity
desc: A study of debates in recent political thought between theorists who take a strong stand against the universalistic and rational foundations of Enlightenment-based political thought (such as poststructuralists, postmodernists, communitarians, and Far Right populists) and defenders of Enlightenment modernity (such as liberals and Frankfurt School Critical Theorists).
prereqs: Political Science 310.
antireqs: Political Science 310.

name: Politics and Literature
desc: Political analysis of how selected works of literature articulate visions of order and disorder.
prereqs: Political Science 310.
antireqs: Political Science 310.

name: Politics through Film
desc: An examination of the complex relationship between politics and film, through selected fictional and documentary works.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science.

name: Feminist Political Theory
desc: A comparative and critical survey of the main contemporary feminist approaches to political theory: this may include liberal feminism, radical/cultural feminism, socialist/Marxist feminism, and post-modern/post-colonial feminism.
prereqs: Political Science 310 or 453.
antireqs: Political Science 310 or 453.

name: Indigenous Politics in Canada
desc: An introduction to historical and contemporary socio-political issues associated with Indigenous peoples and state-society relations in Canada.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science or 3 units in courses labelled Indigenous Studies.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science or 3 units in courses labelled Indigenous Studies.

name: City Government
desc: A study of both institutions and political processes relating to city politics.
prereqs: Political Science 321.
antireqs: Political Science 321.

name: Federalism
desc: Theoretical and empirical examination of federalism in Canada and other selected states.
prereqs: Political Science 321.
antireqs: Political Science 321.

name: Government and Politics of Alberta
desc: An analysis of the institutions and processes of Alberta's government as well as activities in selected policy areas. The examination will include historical as well as contemporary references.
prereqs: Political Science 321.
antireqs: Political Science 321.

name: Comparative Provincial Politics
desc: An analysis of provincial politics in Canada focusing on the distinctive political environments as well as similarities and differences in provincial political cultures, party systems and elections, and selected policy areas.
prereqs: Political Science 321.
antireqs: Political Science 321.

name: Electoral Behaviour
desc: An examination of how and why citizens engage with their governments. Topics may include individual and group influences on citizen participation, electoral choice, and political behaviour in Canada and other democracies.
prereqs: 3 units from Political Science 321 or 399.
antireqs: 3 units from Political Science 321 or 399.

name: Public Opinion
desc: An investigation of theories of public opinion in representative democracies and of survey techniques employed in their examination. A portion of the course will normally be devoted to developing and administering a public opinion survey.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science.

name: Canadian Political Parties
desc: An examination of political parties and party systems in Canada. Party history is reviewed and attention is given to issues relating to organization, finance, representation and electoral competition.
prereqs: Political Science 321.
antireqs: Political Science 321.

name: Selecting and Removing Political Leaders
desc: An examination of the processes political parties use to choose and remove their leaders. The focus is on Canadian parties with comparisons to selected parties in other countries.
prereqs: Political Science 321.
antireqs: Political Science 321.

name: Urban Policy and Governance
desc: Examination of policy issues in Canadian cities, with a special focus on domains involving complex governance challenges. Emphasis on the consequences of policy governance for urban public policy, political authority, and democratic accountability.
prereqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 3 units in courses labelled Political Science at the 300 level or above.

name: Canada and World Politics
desc: An analysis and evaluation of Canada's role on the international scene; main objectives of Canadian foreign policy; security and defence policies; Canada's participation in universal international organizations; the influence of Canada as a middle power upon world events.
prereqs: Political Science 381.
antireqs: Political Science 381.

name: Strategic Studies
desc: An analysis of the causes of war, the meaning of security and defence in the post-Cold War era, including the use and control of military force.
prereqs: Political Science 381.
antireqs: Political Science 381.

name: Campaigns and Elections
desc: Explores election campaigns in Canada through case studies of key elements such as the selection of candidates, the building of campaign teams and the strategies and tactics parties use to elect candidates and win general elections.

name: Constitutional Law and Politics
desc: The law and politics of the Canadian constitution, including the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the federal division of powers, and responsible parliamentary government.
prereqs: Political Science 321 and 342.
antireqs: Political Science 321 and 342.

name: Comparative Public Policy
desc: An examination of a range of public policy issues from a comparative perspective. Topics include social policy, family policy, immigration and multiculturalism, and environmental policy across the advanced industrialized democracies.
prereqs: Political Science 357 or 359.
antireqs: Political Science 357 or 359.

name: Public Administration
desc: Theories of public administration and their practical application in Canada and selected countries.
prereqs: Political Science 321 or 357.
antireqs: Political Science 321 or 357.

name: Women and Politics
desc: An examination of current trends in women’s political participation in Canada and around the world. Topics may include: women’s political behaviour, women’s political representation, and women’s movements’ engagement with political institutions.
prereqs: Political Science 359 or 321.
antireqs: Political Science 359 or 321.

name: Protest, Rebellion, and Revolution
desc: A study of the origins, processes, and outcomes of peaceful and violent forms of political protest, rebellion and revolution. Cases may include historical and contemporary examples from around the world.
prereqs: Political Science 359.
antireqs: Political Science 359.

name: Politics of Post-Industrial States
desc: Comparative analysis of the political dynamics of post-industrial states. Focus on problems associated with post-industrialization and on explanations for political stability and change.
prereqs: Political Science 359.
antireqs: Political Science 359.

name: European Politics
desc: An introduction to the governments and politics of the states and societies of Europe, including the importance of their membership in the European Union.
prereqs: Political Science 359.
antireqs: Political Science 359.

name: Chinese Politics
desc: An introduction to the politics of the Chinese communist party-state. Topics may include: the Mao era leadership debates on socialist development; the post-Mao reforms of Deng Xiaoping and his successors; and the emerging challenges associated with market reforms and China’s integration into the global capitalist economy.
prereqs: Political Science 359.
antireqs: Political Science 359.

name: Middle East: Contemporary Political Problems
desc: An in-depth analysis of selected political, economic and social problems and issues affecting individual nations and the area in general.
prereqs: Political Science 369.
antireqs: Political Science 369.

name: Genocide
desc: An introduction to comparative genocide studies. Examines the causes, structures, and dynamics of genocide and mass violence.
prereqs: 3 units from Political Science 359, 381 or Law and Society 201.
antireqs: 3 units from Political Science 359, 381 or Law and Society 201.

name: Africa: Contemporary Political Problems
desc: An analysis of political problems in selected political systems of Africa. Topics will include the politics of rural development, political elites and the state in Africa, political institutions, constraints on development, and urban politics.
prereqs: Political Science 371 or African Studies 301.
antireqs: Political Science 371 or African Studies 301.

name: States Regimes in Latin America
desc: An analysis of how selected Latin American states and societies are addressing both old and new problems such as the transitions from and legacies of dictatorship, political and criminal violence, as well as the construction of democratic institutions and inclusive citizenship.
prereqs: Political Science 359.
antireqs: Political Science 359.

name: American Politics
desc: A study of the institutions and processes of American politics.
prereqs: Political Science 359.
antireqs: Political Science 359.

name: International Relations of the Contemporary Arab World
desc: An examination of the Arab regional system, with emphasis on regional interaction, regional organizations, and external linkages. The specific cultural, political, ideological, and strategic characteristics of the system will be analyzed.
prereqs: Political Science 369.
antireqs: Political Science 369.

name: The Politics of Human Rights
desc: An analysis of the origins, evolution, and contemporary politics of human rights. Topics may include the philosophic and religious roots of human rights; international and domestic human rights laws; and struggles to promote and protect human rights in specific contexts around the world.
prereqs: 3 units from Political Science 310, 359, 381.
antireqs: 3 units from Political Science 310, 359, 381.

name: International Law
desc: The basic concepts, principles, and functions of international law.
prereqs: Political Science 381.
antireqs: Political Science 381.

name: Global Political Economy
desc: Analysis of the politics of international economic relations. Topics may include the politics of trade and money relations, energy, multinational corporations, and the New International Economic Order.
prereqs: Political Science 381.
antireqs: Political Science 381.

name: International Organizations
desc: An analysis of international governmental organizations with main emphasis on the United Nations and selected regional organizations.
prereqs: Political Science 381.
antireqs: Political Science 381.

name: U.S. Security Policy
desc: Examination of U.S. security policy, with emphasis on how it is made and on contemporary security issues the U.S. faces.
prereqs: Political Science 381.
antireqs: Political Science 381.

name: Foreign Policy Analysis
desc: Theoretical and empirical examination of how states’ foreign policies are shaped by individual, domestic, and international factors.
prereqs: Political Science 381.
antireqs: Political Science 381.

name: Advanced Topics Seminar in Politics
desc: Advanced seminar on a topic in political science with a Canadian politics, comparative politics, international relations, or political theory focus.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units in courses labelled Political Science at the 300 level or above.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units in courses labelled Political Science at the 300 level or above.

name: Selected Topics in Political Theory
desc: Focus on perennial questions from classical to contemporary political theory, such as justice, the use of violence, and the goals of political life.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 310.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 310.

name: Sexual Ethics
desc: An examination of attempts to theorize those things associated with human sexuality using works of historical and contemporary political philosophy. Topics may include: the nature of love and friendship, the good of marriage, limits of sexuality, and the place of justice, equality, and shame.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 310.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 310.

name: Social and Global Justice
desc: An examination of contemporary theories and debates in social and global justice. Topics may include: the redistribution-recognition dilemma, multiculturalism, intersectionality, identity/post-identity politics, globalization, transnationalization, and post-Westphalian approaches to governance and democracy.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 310, 379, 381, 481, 417.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 310, 379, 381, 481, 417.

name: Topics in Canadian Political Development
desc: In-depth examination of the development and transformation of Canadian institutions and politics. Topics may include elections and electoral systems, political parties, federalism, Indigenous-state relations, urban politics, provincial politics, and parliamentary institutions.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 321.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 321.

name: Public Policy and Politics
desc: Advanced seminar on the main theories and approaches to the study of public policy in political science. Topics may include health, welfare, immigration, and morality policy.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 357 or 447.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 357 or 447.

name: Advanced History of Political Thought
desc: An intensive study of selected major political thinkers within the history of political thought.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 310.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 310.

name: Interpretation and War
desc: An examination of the philosophical justifications offered to defend the use of military force, based particularly on the analysis of texts in the history of Western political philosophy.
prereqs: 60 units.
antireqs: 60 units.

name: Canadian Federalism
desc: An examination of the dynamics of Canadian Federalism including relations among provinces and between provinces and the federal government.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 321, 426, 427 or 428.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 321, 426, 427 or 428.

name: Canada and the Circumpolar World
desc: An examination of critical national and international issues in the circumpolar world.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 381.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 381.

name: Advanced Seminar in Indigenous Politics in Canada
desc: Engagement with the contributions made by Indigenous scholars to rethinking Canadian politics. Emphasis on Indigenous scholars’ critiques of colonialism and settler-colonialism in Canada, and the decolonizing potential of Indigenous political thought.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 422 or Indigenous Studies 407.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 422 or Indigenous Studies 407.

name: Parties, Elections and Representation
desc: An examination of political parties and elections in both established and emerging democracies as a means of understanding the nature of political representation in modern representative democracies.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 431.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 431.

name: Law and Armed Conflict
desc: An examination of key texts and topics concerning the evolution, conceptualization, codification, and practical application of the laws of armed conflict. Topics may include the historical and philosophical development of the customary and codified laws of armed conflict, military law and military training and education, and the use of law to punish and deter war crimes.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 342 or 483.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 342 or 483.

name: Women in Canadian Politics
desc: A political history of women in Canada in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Topics include campaigns for suffrage, legal personhood and equality rights, women's political activism, the evolution of public policy concerning women, and the participation of women in public life.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 321.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 321.

name: Women and Public Policy
desc: An examination of the impact of public policies on gender relations from a comparative perspective. Topics may include family and social policies, gender and the workplace, reproductive rights, and gender-based violence.
prereqs: 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 357, 359 or 453.
antireqs: 60 units including 3 units from Political Science 357, 359 or 453.

name: Indigenous Politics in the Global South
desc: Advanced examination of the competing theoretical explanations for the sudden and unexpected rise of Indigenous peoples as key political actors in countries of the Global South. May include Indigenous rights struggles in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 359 or Indigenous Studies 407.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 359 or Indigenous Studies 407.

name: Selected Topics in Middle East Politics
desc: Emphasis will be on foreign-policy development and application in the Middle East.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 369 and 3 units of Courses Constituting the Field of Political Science in Comparative Politics or International Relations at the 400 level.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 369 and 3 units of Courses Constituting the Field of Political Science in Comparative Politics or International Relations at the 400 level.

name: Intelligence and Policy
desc: An examination of the role and limits of intelligence in policymaking.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 381.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 381.

name: Political Economy of Development
desc: Third World development projects, programs, and policies in Africa, Asia and Latin America, intended to raise the standard of living and enhance political participation.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 359 or 379.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 359 or 379.

name: Selected Topics in International Law and Organizations
desc: An advanced seminar on international order and on co-operative and competitive efforts by states and other international actors to create, maintain and change that order.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 483 or 487.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 483 or 487.

name: Preventing the Spread of Nuclear Weapons
desc: An analysis of the politics of the international regime governing the control of nuclear weapons, including case studies of states that pose a challenge to that regime.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 381.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 381.

name: Advanced Studies in Global Political Economy
desc: Advanced analysis of selected themes in global political economy. Topics may include trade, migration, exchange rates, and foreign direct investment.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 485.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 485.

name: International Ethics
desc: An examination of ethical reasoning and moral norms in political decision making, institutions, and processes in international politics. Topics such as justice in relation to war and terrorism, sovereignty, intervention and human rights, globalization and global poverty, and the environment may be analyzed.
prereqs: 60 units including Political Science 381 or 310.
antireqs: 60 units including Political Science 381 or 310.

name: Honours Seminar
desc: An examination of classic works in political science.
prereqs: Admission to Political Science Honours program and completion of 75 units.
antireqs: Admission to Political Science Honours program and completion of 75 units.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Preparation of an honours thesis under the supervision of a faculty member who will assign the final grade.
prereqs: Political Science 590.
antireqs: Political Science 590.

name: Directed Study in Political Science
desc: Study of a particular topic under the direct supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: 60 units and consent of the Department.
antireqs: 60 units and consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Introduction to Sexual Ethics
desc: An advanced introduction to theorizing human sexuality using works of historical and contemporary political philosophy. Topics may include: the nature of love and friendship, the good of marriage, limits of sexuality, and the place of justice, equality, and shame.

name: Social and Global Justice
desc: An examination of contemporary theories and debates in social and global justice. Topics may include: the redistribution-recognition dilemma, multiculturalism, intersectionality, identity/post-identity politics, globalization, transnationalization, and post-Westphalian approaches to governance and democracy.

name: Advanced History of Political Thought
desc: An intensive study of selected major political thinkers within the history of political thought.

name: Advanced Political Theory
desc: Discussion of contemporary topics in political thought. Emphasis on analysis of problems rather than history of ideas.

name: War and Interpretation
desc: An examination of the philosophical justifications offered to defend the use of military force, based particularly on the analysis of texts in the history of Western political philosophy.

name: Canadian Political Institutions
desc: Examination of the structure and operation of the central institutions of the Canadian state, including the constitution, federalism, parliamentary government, and political parties.

name: Canadian Political Process
desc: Examination of Canadian political behaviour within its institutional context, including political parties, interest groups, voting and socialization.

name: Advanced Seminar on Indigenous-State Relations in Canada
desc: Structure and operation of colonialism and settler-colonialism in Canada, and Indigenous resistance to those structures of oppression. Attention will be paid to the reconciliation debates, Indigenous gender oppression, and the politics of decolonization in Canada.

name: Parties, Elections and Representation
desc: An examination of political parties and elections in both established and emerging democracies as a means of understanding the nature of political representation in modern representative democracies.

name: U.S. Security Policy
desc: An examination of U.S. security policy, with an emphasis both on how U.S. security policy is made and on the main contemporary security issues the U.S. faces today.

name: Selected Topics in Public Law
desc: Examination of the political, philosophical, and institutional dimensions of selected public law issues, with particular reference to judicial and quasi-judicial tribunals as policy-making institutions. Consult the Department for information on choice of topics.

name: Law and Armed Conflict
desc: An examination of key texts and topics concerning the evolution, conceptualization, codification, and practical application of the laws of armed conflict. Topics may include the historical and philosophical development of the customary and codified laws of armed conflict, military law and military training and education, and the use of law to punish and deter war crimes.

name: Politics and Public Policy
desc: An examination of the main theories and approaches to the study of public policy.

name: Gender and Public Policy
desc: Explores the gendered impact of a range of public policies and also explores the influence of gender norms and ideas on the formulation of public policy. Topics covered include gender-based policy analysis, gender and the welfare state, family and child-care policies, policies to address gender inequalities in the labour market and workplace, and reproductive rights policies.

name: Advanced Seminar on Indigenous Politics in the Global South
desc: Advanced examination of the competing theoretical explanations for the sudden and unexpected rise of Indigenous peoples as key political actors in countries of the Global South. In-depth case studies may include Indigenous rights struggles in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

name: Comparative Politics of Development in the Global South
desc: An examination of the major issues, theories, and debates about development and politics in the Global South.

name: Comparative Politics: Theories and Methods
desc: An examination of the main theories, methods, and debates in the field of Comparative Politics.

name: Selected Topics in Advanced Comparative Politics
desc: Selected regions and topics in Comparative Politics.

name: Advanced Analysis of International Relations
desc: An examination of the main theories, issues, and approaches in the study of International Relations.

name: Advanced Studies in Foreign Policy
desc: Selected themes in the formation and implementation of foreign policies.

name: Human Rights and Humanitarianism
desc: An advanced introduction to the principal contemporary debates in the field of human rights and humanitarian politics.

name: Strategic Studies
desc: Advanced seminar in major topics in strategic studies, such as arms control, deterrence, and other military doctrines.

name: Advanced Seminar in Global Political Economy
desc: Covering in-depth major debates in global political economy, provides an advanced exploration of the causes and effects of globalization, including the determinants of foreign economic policymaking (such as trade, money, migration, global production, finance, and foreign aid) as well as the subsequent impact of these policies.

name: Advanced Studies in Canadian Arctic Security
desc: The Canadian Arctic is an emerging area of concern due to changes scarcely imaginable even a few years ago.
