Examines the nature of some of these changes—e.g., climate change and the northern seas’ dramatically changing ice conditions, growing recognition of the regions’ resource wealth, and evolving international relations in the circumpolar region—and what they mean for Canadian Arctic security.

name: Unconventional Warfare
desc: Analysis of warfare conducted by, or against, sub-state groups. This may include in-depth studies of guerrilla warfare, asymmetric conflict, or terrorism.

name: Quantitative Analysis in Political Science
desc: Examination of empirical research methods and techniques of quantitative analysis in the study of political phenomena. Computer use is required.

name: Advanced Quantitative Analysis in Political Science
desc: Examination of advanced empirical research methods and techniques of multivariate quantitative analysis in the study of political phenomena.
prereqs: Political Science 691.
antireqs: Political Science 691.

name: Major Research Paper
desc: Preparation of a major research paper under the supervision of a faculty member who will assign the grade.

name: Qualitative Analysis in Political Science
desc: An introduction to qualitative research methods in Political Science. Topics may include qualitative methodology, elite interviewing, focus groups, content analysis, case studies and qualitative data analysis.
prereqs: Political Science 691.
antireqs: Political Science 691.

name: Scope and Methods in Political Science
desc: Advanced seminar covering various approaches, topics, methods and theories employed in the discipline of political science.

name: Principles of Psychology I
desc: A survey of topics associated with psychology’s role as a biological science, including neuroscience, sensation and perception, cognition, learning, memory, and language.

name: Principles of Psychology II
desc: A survey of topics associated with psychology’s role as a social science, including personality, motivation, health, social, developmental, industrial/organizational and clinical psychology.

name: Psychology for Everyday Life
desc: Provides students with an understanding of the key theories, research methods, and discoveries in coping and resilience, identity development, interpersonal relationships, and mental health with an emphasis on developing the knowledge and skills necessary to be effective consumers of psychological theory and research. Through a focus on adjustment issues that arise in everyday life, this course will demonstrate some of the ways in which psychology can be used to benefit students’ wellbeing in their personal and professional lives.

name: Human Sexuality
desc: Examination of contemporary knowledge and attitudes toward human sexuality, relying on theoretical and empirical psychological research. Multiple perspectives are presented, including psychosocial, cross-cultural, and psychobiological. Sexuality across the life span is examined, including issues pertaining to sexual differentiation, intimacy and communication, gender role development, varieties of sexual relationships and behaviour, and legal and ethical issues.

name: Research Methods and Data Analysis in Psychology I
desc: Research methods in psychological research, with an introduction to data analysis.
prereqs: One of Mathematics 30-1, 30-2, 31, or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education); Psychology 200; and Psychology 201 or Neuroscience 201.
antireqs: One of Mathematics 30-1, 30-2, 31, or Mathematics 2 (offered by Continuing Education); Psychology 200; and Psychology 201 or Neuroscience 201.

name: Research Methods and Data Analysis in Psychology II
desc: An integration of research methods and statistics in psychological research, with an emphasis on conducting and interpreting inferential statistical techniques.
prereqs: Psychology 300.
antireqs: Psychology 300.

name: History of Psychological Thought
desc: The roots of psychological thought in Western culture, and the relationship between theories of human nature and changing social institutions.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Industrial and Organizational Psychology
desc: Understanding and predicting behaviour and attitudes within an organizational setting. Topics normally include: personnel selection, attraction to organizations and job choice, person-organization fit, organizational culture, motivation and decision-making, employee attitudes, deviant behaviour in organizations, leadership, team behaviour, and personality in the workplace.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Social Psychology
desc: Social psychological approaches to understanding social influence, social perception and cognition, attitudes and group dynamics.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Language Development
desc: Research into language development in typically developing children, with consideration of environmental and other factors that influence acquisition. Consideration also given to atypical language development.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Developmental Psychology
desc: An examination of psychological development through childhood and adolescence.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Psychology of Aging
desc: Examines theory and research related to psychological processes during adulthood and aging. Topics may include life-span developmental theories and methods; biological processes; sensory, perceptual and cognitive processes; personality and social processes; life transitions, mental health issues; and dying.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Cognitive Psychology
desc: A survey of research and theory in cognitive psychology. Research in pattern recognition, attention, memory, language, thinking, and other cognitive abilities is explored, with discussion of associated brain mechanisms.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Sensation and Perception
desc: The psychological and physiological bases of sensory and perceptual processes, including vision, audition, taste, smell, touch, proprioception, and basic psychophysics. Provides a background for advanced courses in sensory and perceptual processing, human factors, and environmental psychology.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Motivation
desc: A survey of theories, models, and research on the psychological aspects of human motivation from social, cognitive, behavioural, and biological perspectives.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Brain and Behaviour
desc: The neural basis of learning, memory, language and thinking, as well as pathological, sexual, aggressive, and emotional behaviour that arises from neural and hormonal malfunctioning.
prereqs: Psychology 200.
antireqs: Psychology 200.

name: Personality
desc: Approaches to the study of personality.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Abnormal Psychology
desc: Abnormal behaviour and experiences, their causes and treatment throughout the lifespan.
prereqs: Psychology 200 and 201.
antireqs: Psychology 200 and 201.

name: Academic Competencies in Psychology
desc: Students acquire personal and academic competencies to support program success including effective communication, critical thinking, information literacy, and techniques to set realistic goals.
prereqs: Psychology 200, 201 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 200, 201 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Professional Development in Psychology
desc: Students acquire professional and career development skills to prepare for the transition into the workplace. Students explore career options and develop materials to increase success in professional and job opportunities.
prereqs: Psychology 200, 201 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 200, 201 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Applied Research Methods
desc:
Students will learn to apply appropriate research methods to answer research questions, to collect and analyze data, and to interpret and report research findings.
400.01. Applied Methods in Abnormal Psychology
400.02. Applied Methods in Applied Psychology
400.03. Applied Methods in Brain and Behaviour
400.04. Applied Methods in Cognitive Psychology
400.05. Applied Methods in Developmental Psychology
400.06. Applied Methods in Industrial-Organizational Psychology
400.07. Applied Methods in Sensation and Perception
400.08. Applied Methods in Social Psychology
prereqs: Admission to the Psychology major or Honours program and: 01: Psychology 300, 301, 385; 02: Psychology 300, 301; 03: Psychology 300, 301, 375; 04: Psychology 300, 301, 365; 05: Psychology 300, 301 and one of 349 or 351 or 353; 06: Psychology 300, 301; 07: Psychology 300, 301, 369; 08: Psychology 300, 301, 345.
antireqs: Admission to the Psychology major or Honours program and: 01: Psychology 300, 301, 385; 02: Psychology 300, 301; 03: Psychology 300, 301, 375; 04: Psychology 300, 301, 365; 05: Psychology 300, 301 and one of 349 or 351 or 353; 06: Psychology 300, 301; 07: Psychology 300, 301, 369; 08: Psychology 300, 301, 345.

name: Contemporary Theories in Psychology
desc: An analysis of what constitutes a "theory," "model" and "explanation" in psychology as a science. Survey of major theoretical positions in twentieth-century psychology.
prereqs: Psychology 200, 201, 3 units in a course labelled Psychology at the 300 level or above, and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 200, 201, 3 units in a course labelled Psychology at the 300 level or above, and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Psychometrics
desc: Theory and application of methodological and statistical issues in psychological assessment. Topics include: theories of psychological measurement, scale development, item analysis, item bias, reliability, validity, and test fairness.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Design and Analysis in Psychological Research
desc: Experimental design problems and techniques for analysis of psychological data.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Qualitative Inquiry in Psychology
desc: Qualitative approaches to psychological research such as phenomenology, grounded theory, and discourse analysis. Specific topics include research interviews, ethics, and evaluating qualitative research.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Human Factors
desc: Application of psychological research and theory to people-system relationships and the work environment; display and control devices, design and evaluation of the built environment, human skills and limitations, work schedules, safety, and research methods in human factors engineering.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Environmental Psychology
desc: The theory and data pertaining to the relationship between human behaviour and the physical environment, both natural and built. Particular emphasis is placed on the implications of current knowledge for the management of the human-environment interface. A research project is an integral part of the course.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Adolescence
desc: An in-depth examination of the physical, cognitive, emotional, and social changes occurring during adolescence, drawing upon theory and relevant research.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 351 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 351 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Psychophysiology in Health Research
desc: An examination of the impact of emotions on physiological activity and risk for disease, including coronary heart disease, ulcers, asthma, cancer and other immune-related disorders, with an emphasis on the discussion and understanding of empirical research. Hands-on experience with psychophysiological measurement equipment and procedures commonly used in stress research will be provided.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Current Issues in Psychopathology
desc: Discussion of current developments and controversies in the assessment, etiology, and treatment of psychopathology. Emphasis will be on teaching students how to strengthen their critical thinking skills using controversial issues in the fields of abnormal and clinical psychology as a basis for discussion and debate.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Clinical Psychology
desc: Assessment and treatment problems in clinical settings.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Behaviour Therapy
desc: Theory, principles, and practices of contemporary behaviour therapy/behaviour modification as applied to a representative range of disorders, problems, and child and adult populations. Laboratory projects introduce methodologies used in behaviour therapy
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Health Psychology
desc: Health psychology involves the discipline and principles of psychology and human behaviour in understanding how the mind, body, and behaviour interact in health and disease. Class topics include psychosocial models of health and disease, stress and coping, health enhancing and health damaging behaviours, pain management, and a variety of specific behaviour-related medical illnesses (e.g., heart disease, cancer, insomnia).
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Psychology of Gender
desc: An analysis of psychological theory and research on gender situated within the interdisciplinary field of gender studies. Topics include the meaning of gender, psychological development and gender, and gender and interpersonal relationships.
prereqs: Psychology 300 and 301; and Psychology 345 or 351; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300 and 301; and Psychology 345 or 351; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Intergroup Relations
desc: In-depth exploration of intergroup relations from a social psychological perspective. Theory and research about the processes involved in stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 345, and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 345, and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Interpersonal Relationships
desc: Application of social psychological theory and methodology to a variety of topics in the area of interpersonal relationships such as attraction, close relationships, interpersonal conflict, communication, and power. Course projects will be an integral part of the course.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 345 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 345 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Social Influence and Persuasion
desc: Focus on the psychology of social influence, persuasion, and compliance gaining.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, and 345 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, and 345 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Psychology of Morality
desc: An exploration of the origins and nature of moral conduct from the perspective of psychological theory and research. Examination of the naturalistic basis for why people care about morality, behave morally or not, and the psychological bases of moral judgment. Topics may include the evolutionary basis for morality, moral intuitionism, moral development, and moral judgment.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Advanced Topics in Personality or Social Psychology
desc: An examination of current research topics in personality or social psychology or gender.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Social-Personality Development
desc: Socialization processes and behaviours from birth to adolescence; observational learning, altruism, moral development, sex-roles, dependency, emotional development, and social motivation.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 351 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 351 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Cognitive Development
desc: Current and classic research in the area of cognitive development is explored. Topics may include sensory and perceptual development, language acquisition, symbolic representation, concept formation, memory, and social-cognitive development.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 351 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 351 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.

name: Sensory, Perceptual, and Cognitive Aspects of Aging
desc: Basic research and contemporary issues in the age-related changes in sensation, perception, attention, learning and memory, intelligence and problem-solving.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 353 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 353 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Social and Clinical Aspects of Aging
desc: Stability and change in the later years of life with a focus on social and clinical areas of aging.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 353 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 353 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Developmental Psychopathology
desc: A critical examination of developmental psychopathology during childhood and adolescence with an emphasis on the characteristics of the disorders, their determinants, and outcomes. Current theories and research, and recent trends in intervention and prevention will be emphasized.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 351, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 351, 385 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Memory
desc: Current memory research is explored. Topics include how memories are encoded and retrieved.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 365 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 365 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Psycholinguistics
desc: Exploration of the cognitive, neuropsychological, and social processes that underlie language abilities, with reference to linguistic theory.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.

name: Vision
desc: A systematic examination of vision and its role in our interactions with the natural environment. Topics may include: the physics of light; optics; eye and retina; visual pathways and visual brain; perception of colour, space, change and motion; visual development and aging; art and vision; visual disorders; and recovery from blindness.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 369 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 369 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Auditory Cognitive Neuroscience
desc: Exploration of auditory perception from an auditory cognitive neuroscience perspective, using music and speech as domains of inquiry. Focus on acoustics, psychophysics, cognitive psychology, cognitive development, neurophysiology, and neuropsychology. Includes hands-on exercises in sound manipulation and experimentation.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 369 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors or the Concentration in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 369 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors or the Concentration in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.

name: Evolution and Human Behaviour
desc: An examination of the scientific synthesis of evolutionary biology and modern psychology, which offers a novel approach to such issues as short-term and long-term human mating strategies, short-term sexual strategies, conflict between the sexes, parental investment, aggression, and social dominance.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Neuroscience of Learning and Memory
desc: An examination of learning and memory from a neuroscience perspective. Molecular, cellular, systems-level, and behavioural approaches will be applied to themes such as consolidation, amnesia, and pathological processes.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Drugs and Behaviour
desc: The behavioural effects of drugs specifically employed to affect the nervous system, as seen in the treatment of mental disorders, behavioural disorders, and other conditions such as Parkinson's, Huntington's and Alzheimer's diseases. Neuro-pharmacologic agents will be discussed as they relate to the biochemistry and physiology of putative neurotransmitters.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Sleep and Biological Rhythms
desc: Behaviours are temporally co-ordinated and occur in a rhythmic fashion. The most obvious rhythmic behaviour humans engage in is sleeping; we spend one-third of our lives asleep. This course will survey the behavioural, physiological, and clinical aspects of sleep and biological rhythms.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Behavioural Neuroscience
desc: An examination of the neural underpinnings of behaviour. Experimental approaches, neural mechanisms, and health implications will be explored through both lecture material and laboratory exercises.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Human Neuropsychology
desc: Integration of the literature on human brain damage with the evidence from animal research. Topics include developmental neuropsychology; cognitive deficits associated with frontal, parietooccipital, and temporal lobes; origins and mechanisms in the determination of cerebral dominancy; disorders of learning and memory; long-term effects of cerebral lesions.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program or to the minor in Speech-Language Sciences for Linguistics Majors.

name: Advanced Topics in Organizational Psychology
desc:
Students will be expected to critically evaluate current theory, research, and practice in the field of Organizational Psychology with content emphasizing primary readings. Student presentations, project work, and debates will emphasize the implications for linking knowledge and practice.
481.01. Leadership and Motivation 481.02. Teams and Teamwork 481.03. Workplace Attitudes and Individual Differences
prereqs: Psychology 300 and 301; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300 and 301; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Advanced Topics in Personnel Psychology
desc:
Students will be expected to critically evaluate current theory, research, and practice in the field of Personnel Psychology with content emphasizing primary readings. Student presentations, project work, and debates will emphasize the implications for linking knowledge and practice. 
483.01. Personnel Selection483.02. Personnel Recruitment and Job Choice483.03. Performance Management
prereqs: Psychology 300 and 301; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300 and 301; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Cross-Cultural Cognition
desc: Theory and research on the interaction of culture and human cognition. Topics include cross-cultural research in perception, language processing, memory, concepts, and reasoning.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 365 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 365 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Indigenous Psychology
desc: An in-depth examination of research in psychology related to Indigenous populations, including the history of research, major topics, appropriate approaches to conducting research, and new directions.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Psychology and Law
desc: Consideration of the contributions of psychological theory and research to the understanding of crime investigation, courtroom dynamics, and the legal system. Specific topics may include eyewitness testimony, police practices, judge and jury decision making, lie detection and confessions, and expert testimony. Topics will be discussed from the perspectives of social and cognitive psychology.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Consumer Psychology
desc: Consideration of the psychological concepts used to understand the processes involved in consumer behaviour. Specific topics may include research methodology, individual and group influences, marketing strategies, and consumer decision making. Topics will be discussed from the perspectives of cognitive and social psychology.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Consciousness
desc: An exploration of the origin, nature, and function of consciousness as informed by research on conscious and unconscious processes, psychological disorders, neuropsychological case studies, consciousness-altering drugs, hypnosis, meditation, state-dependent memory, sleep, and dreams.
prereqs: Psychology 300 and 301; and Psychology 365 or 375; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300 and 301; and Psychology 365 or 375; and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Research Experience in Psychology
desc:
Students acquire research experience working under the supervision of a faculty member. Assignments may include literature search, materials preparation, data collection, data organization and management, and data analysis.
499.01 Research Experience I
499.02 Research Experience II
prereqs: Psychology 300 and 301; 18 units in Psychology, admission to the Psychology major or Honours program, and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Psychology 300 and 301; 18 units in Psychology, admission to the Psychology major or Honours program, and consent of the Department.

name: Honours Topics Seminar in Psychology
desc: Selected topics from one or more areas in psychology.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, admission to the Psychology Honours program and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, admission to the Psychology Honours program and consent of the Department.

name: Selected Topics in Psychology with Lab
desc: Selected topics from one or more areas in psychology.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Selected Topics in Psychology
desc: Selected topics from one or more areas in psychology.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Directed Research in Psychology
desc: Research project in psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, admission to the Psychology major or Honours program and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, admission to the Psychology major or Honours program and consent of the Department.

name: Directed Research in Psychology
desc: Research project in psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, admission to the Psychology major or Honours program and consent of the Department.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, admission to the Psychology major or Honours program and consent of the Department.

name: Directed Readings in Psychology
desc: Directed readings and writing in one or more areas in psychology under the supervision of a faculty member.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Cognitive and Clinical Neuroscience
desc: An examination of how the human central nervous system controls higher order, complex behaviours. Experimental and clinical evidence for the neurobiological regulation of memory, language, attention, perception and emotion will be evaluated.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 375 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Nervous System Development
desc: This course will cover the fundamental principles of the development of nervous systems, integrating anatomical, cellular, molecular, genetic, and behavioural approaches.
prereqs: Psychology 475 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 475 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Advanced Themes in Psychopathology
desc: Examination of assessment, phenomenology, etiology, and/or treatment of common psychological disorders. Course will cover few disorders in greater detail.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 385, 433 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 385, 433 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Advanced Topics in Cognitive Psychology
desc: A detailed examination of current research topics in cognitive psychology. Topics may include one or more of the following: human memory, thinking, attention, language processing, and computer modelling.
prereqs: Psychology 300, 301, 365 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.
antireqs: Psychology 300, 301, 365 and admission to the Psychology major or Honours program.

name: Honours Thesis and Seminar
desc: Research project under the direction of a member of the Department. In the seminar, students will present and discuss their projects and other topics of current relevance.
prereqs: Admission to the Psychology Honours degree program.
antireqs: Admission to the Psychology Honours degree program.

name: Professional Development
desc: Professional development seminar series to prepare students for diverse careers in Psychology. The goals of the seminars are to build transferable skills relating to academic topics, mental health and wellness, and career development.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: History of Psychology
desc: History of psychological concepts in Western culture, major theoretical systems of twentieth-century psychology, foundational assumptions of theories in contemporary psychology.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Research Design and Methodology in Psychology
desc: Survey of advanced topics in the conduct of psychological research including issues in philosophy of science; origins of research ideas; validity and reliability; measurement; experimental, quasi-experimental, and non–experimental designs; survey research; specialized methods such as computer simulation, psychophysiological methods, event-sampling, online data collection, and cognitive procedures; and ethics.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Qualitative Inquiry in Psychology
desc: Qualitative research designs and historical research in psychology. Advanced study of selected qualitative approaches in psychology to include research design, methods, and analysis. Specific topics covered include foundations of qualitative research, evaluation and practical techniques including computerized analysis.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Signal and Systems Analysis in Behavioural Research
desc: Application of signal and systems analysis to behavioural neuroscience and psychophysics.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Analysis of Variance
desc: Applications of the general linear model to research design and analysis. Topics include analysis of variance, regression, and analysis of covariance.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Multivariate Data Analysis
desc: Multivariate techniques and design issues, including canonical correlation, discriminant analysis, multivariate analysis of variance, multivariate regression, principal components analysis and factor analysis.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Special Topics in the Design of Psychological Research
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Brain and Cognitive Sciences
desc: An advanced survey of some of the fundamental issues and recent developments in the Brain and/or Cognitive Sciences. Topics will vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Functional Neuroanatomy
desc: Human neuroanatomy and the development of the central nervous system. Functional relationships between brain and behaviour in a variety of domains (sensorimotor, language, memory, affective processing, social behaviour, etc).
prereqs: Admission to the Psychology or Clinical Psychology graduate programs.
antireqs: Admission to the Psychology or Clinical Psychology graduate programs.

name: Clinical Neuropsychology
desc: Examination of brain disorders across the lifespan. Epidemiology, etiology and pathogenesis, phenotypic expression, and assessment and treatment of these disorders will be considered.
prereqs: Admission to the Psychology or Clinical Psychology graduate programs.
antireqs: Admission to the Psychology or Clinical Psychology graduate programs.

name: Neuropsychological Testing
desc: The clinical assessment of neuropsychological functioning in children and adults using a hypothesis-testing model. Fundamentals of administration, scoring, and interpretation of core tests used in neuropsychological assessment.
prereqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.
antireqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

name: Advanced Topics in Social and Theoretical Psychology
desc: An advanced survey of some of the fundamental issues and recent developments in Social and/or Theoretical Psychology. Topics will vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Industrial and Organizational Psychology
desc: Application of psychological principles, research and methods relating to human interactions and performance in work settings.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Advanced Topics in Health Psychology
desc: Introduces students to current research issues in health psychology. Focuses primarily on issues related to the study of chronic illnesses and evaluates the role of psychological/behavioural factors in: the etiology of disease, disease prevention, adaptation to illness, and disease progression.

name: Clinical Research
desc: An introduction to research and design issues in clinical psychology.
prereqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.
antireqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

name: Lifespan Psychopathology
desc: Current theory, issues, and research regarding the epidemiology, etiology, diagnosis, and prognosis of psychopathology. Implications for assessment and treatment.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Ethics and Professional Issues
desc: Ethical and legal standards for clinical psychologists. An introduction to professional issues in contemporary clinical practice.
prereqs:
Consent of the Department.
 Consent of the Department.
antireqs:
Consent of the Department.
 Consent of the Department.

name: Adult Assessment
desc: Theory, administration and interpretation of assessment procedures for adults including interviews, behavioural assessments, and selected intellectual and personality tests. Supervised experience in conducting assessments in a relevant clinical setting.
prereqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.
antireqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

name: Child Assessment
desc: Theoretical, professional and ethical issues in the psychopathology and psychological assessment of child clinical populations. Instruction and supervised practical experience in the administration and interpretation of child assessment procedures.
prereqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.
antireqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

name: Lifespan Psychotherapy
desc: Presents evidence-based psychological interventions across the lifespan. Includes specific competencies related to child and family, adolescent and adult treatment modalities. The laboratory component includes supervised exposure to the practice of psychological interventions in a relevant clinical setting.
prereqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.
antireqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

name: Integrative Seminar in Psychology
desc: Selected interdisciplinary topics in Psychology. Topics will vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Research in Brain and Cognitive Sciences
desc: Completion of a research project in Brain and/or Cognitive Sciences conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Research in Social and Theoretical Psychology
desc: Completion of a research project in the areas of Social and/or Theoretical Psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Research in Industrial/Organizational Psychology
desc: Completion of a research project in Industrial/Organizational Psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Integrative Seminar in Psychology
desc: Selected interdisciplinary topics in Psychology. Topics may vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Research in Brain and Cognitive Sciences
desc: Completion of a research project in Brain and/or Cognitive Sciences conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Research in Social and Theoretical Psychology
desc: Completion of a research project in the areas of Social and/or Theoretical Psychology conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Topics may vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Seminar in Brain and Cognitive Sciences
desc: Selected topics in Brain and/or Cognitive Sciences. Topics may vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Seminar in Social and Theoretical Psychology
desc: Selected topics in Social and/or Theoretical Psychology. Topics may vary.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Seminar in Industrial/Organizational Psychology
desc: Application of psychological principles and methods to business, industry and other organizational settings.
prereqs: Psychology 639.
antireqs: Psychology 639.

name: Advanced Clinical Seminar
desc:
A doctoral-level seminar in advanced topics in the practice of clinical psychology. 
750.01. Psychopharmacology
750.05. Diversity Issues in Clinical Psychology 
750.06. Clinical Geropsychology 
750.09. Addictions
750.10. Health Psychology 
750.11. Eating Disorders
750.12. Consultation/Supervision
750.13 Program Evaluation
prereqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.
antireqs: Admission to the Clinical Psychology graduate program.

name: Special Topics in Adult Psychopathology
desc: A specialized topic course in the area of adult psychopathology. Course offerings will vary from year-to-year and may include such topics as: schizophrenia, substance abuse, suicide, mental health delivery systems, or computer applications in clinical psychology.

name: Religious Myths and Worldviews
desc: Readings (in English translation) from the classical literatures of middle Eastern and Asian religions. Introduction to the evolving mythological traditions from three geo-cultural centres (the middle East, India, and China) by examining religious themes: cosmology; existential values and goals; destinies of humans, the world, and the cosmos.

name: Jews, Christians and Muslims
desc: Introduction to Judaism, Christianity and Islam.

name: Asian Religions
desc: Introduction to Eastern religions such as Jainism, Hinduism, Sikhism, Buddhism, Confucianism and Taoism.

name: Religion and The Good Life
desc: An introduction to the academic study of religion with particular emphasis on the nature of religion, its role as a response to existential questions, and the relationship of religion to contemporary thought and culture.

name: Classical Hebrew I
desc: Classical or Biblical Hebrew language; the development of ability in the critical reading of ancient texts. No attempt will be made to provide any competence in medieval or modern Hebrew.

name: Studies in the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament
desc: An introduction to the critical study and reading of the books of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament in English translation. The course focuses on the Bible as religious literature.

name: Classical Hebrew II
desc: Continuation of Religious Studies 300.
prereqs: Religious Studies 300.
antireqs: Religious Studies 300.

name: Introduction to Hinduism
desc: The history, textual traditions, schools and sectarian traditions of Hinduism.

name: Greek Religion
desc: A survey of religious beliefs and practices in the pre-Christian Greek World.
prereqs: 3 units from Greek and Roman Studies 205, 209, Religious Studies 201, 205.
antireqs: 3 units from Greek and Roman Studies 205, 209, Religious Studies 201, 205.

name: Popular Hinduism
desc: An introductory survey of the contemporary practices of Hinduism in South Asia and in diaspora Hindu communities throughout the world. Focus on recent ethnographic research and the diversity of popular Hindu practices with special attention to differences defined by region, language, caste, and gender. Topics may include the structure of social and family life, the organization of sacred space and time, ritual practices, and the influence and impact of modernity in Hindu life.

name: Religious Experience
desc: A study of philosophical and psychological theories of the nature and function of religious experiences and an introduction to a variety of religious experiences, which may include theophany, mysticism, enlightenment, conversion, and guilt.

name: Sanskrit I
desc: Classical Sanskrit language; the development of ability in the critical reading of ancient Hindu or Buddhist texts.

name: Sanskrit II
desc: Continuation of Religious Studies 310.
prereqs: Religious Studies 310.
antireqs: Religious Studies 310.

name: Introduction to Buddhism
desc: Buddhist developments from the time of Buddha to the development of Mahayana.

name: Tibetan I
desc: Classical Tibetan language; the development of ability in the critical reading of ancient Bon and Buddhist texts.

name: Tibetan II
desc: Continuation of Religious Studies 314.
prereqs: Religious Studies 314.
antireqs: Religious Studies 314.

name: Religion in South Asia
desc: An in-depth survey of the religious traditions of the Indian sub-continent. Special attention to the long history of religious pluralism and recent communal conflicts in South Asia. Covers religious traditions that have come to South Asia from other parts of the world (primarily Islam, but also Zoroastrianism, Judaism, Christianity and Baha’i).

name: Esoteric Buddhism
desc: The development of Vajrayana, Tantric and other esoteric traditions of Buddhism in India, Tibet, China, Japan and in the West from medieval times to the present.

name: Classical Chinese for Religious Texts I
desc: Introduction to Classical Chinese language, with emphasis on developing the ability to read ancient Chinese religious texts.

name: Classical Chinese for Religious Texts II
desc: Continuation of Religious Studies 320.
prereqs: Religious Studies 320.
antireqs: Religious Studies 320.

name: Mahayana Buddhism
desc: Mahayana developments in India, China, Tibet or Japan.

name: Zen Buddhism
desc: An exploration of the thought and practice of Chan (Chinese) and Zen (Japanese) Buddhism, including twentieth-century developments in the west.

name: Tibetan Religious Traditions
desc: The religious developments in Tibet, with emphasis on religious history, literature and philosophy and their contemporary implications.

name: Buddhism in East Asia
desc: The history, doctrines, literature and leading figures of Buddhism in China and Japan.

name: Religious Perspectives on Suffering
desc: An examination of various religious perspectives on the nature and causes of human suffering.

name: Religious Perspectives on Death and Afterlife
desc: An examination of various religious perspectives on the nature of death and life after death.

name: Ritual and Religion
desc: A major form of religious expression is the various practices and rituals performed by individuals and the community. Various ritual theories and approaches will be examined along with different examples of religious ritual expressions.

name: Atheism
desc: A consideration of various historical and thematic critiques of religion, including the development of modern agnosticism, atheism and in recent times, the ‘new atheism’.

name: Transformations of Religion in Africa
desc: Nature of religion through a study of religious transformations in Africa.

name: New Religious Movements
desc: An examination of the beliefs, practices and developments of new religious movements of both Eastern and Western origins (e.g. Krishna Consciousness, Transcendental Meditation, Unification Church, Children of God, etc.).

name: Religion and Social Morality
desc: Critical examination of social theories of religion and religious perspectives on ethical issues of social, economic, and political consequence in contemporary cultures.

name: The Bible as Literature
desc: An exploration of the various literary genres that make up the sixty-six books of the Bible, understood as a compilation of human literature reflecting millennia of communal struggle, vision, and engaged reception.

name: God and Transcendence
desc: Comparative and theoretical discussion of various traditions, Eastern and Western, regarding the object of religious belief and devotion.

name: Chaos, Demons and Monsters
desc: An examination of religious depictions of supernatural evil agents and forces in the light of their role in the experience of good/evil, suffering/happiness, and existence/death.

name: Religion, Empire and Colonialism
desc: An examination of the complex interplay of religious traditions and imperial projects, focusing on the development of religion in response to engagement with other cultures, religions and traditions brought on by colonialism, as well as the religious construction and categorization of these others through comparative, historical, literary and/or thematic lenses. Exploration of modern responses to colonialism as well as multiculturalism and immigration as they relate to religion.

name: Religion and Politics
desc: A study of the complex relationship between religion and politics, including nationalism and political religions. Topics may include the origin of apartheid in South Africa, Black Theology, the rise of the New Christian Right in America, Hindu and Islamic political movements, and various forms of Fascism including the Nazi movement.

name: Islam in the Modern World
desc: Reform, revivalist and sectarian movements and significant thinkers in Modern Islam.

name: Islam
desc: A survey of the basic religious ideas, texts, figures, and practices in Islam, including their historical development.

name: East Asian Religious Traditions
desc: The history, doctrines and literature of the major religious traditions of China, Korea and Japan.

name: Buddhist Practice Traditions
desc: An introduction to different kinds of meditation practices in Buddhist traditions, through their historical trajectories and their related devotional and ritual aspects. The material is organized according to principal contemporary areas (Vipassana, Chan/Zen/Son, Pure Land, Tibetan).

name: Cross-Cultural Philosophy of Religion
desc: Comparative study of philosophical issues of religious interest arising from diverse cultures.

name: Topics: Comparative Studies in Western Religions
desc: A comparative and critical examination of a specific topic within Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Possible topics include: Material Culture, Pilgrimage, and Scriptural Exegesis.

name: Introduction to Judaism
desc: An introduction to the major practices, beliefs, institutions and religious literature of the Jewish religion, as developed from antiquity to modern times.

name: Topics in Religious Studies
desc: Topics may include an overview of a specific religious tradition, an examination of religious expressions in a particular context, a thematic study of a religion or religions, or a methodological approach to the study of religion.

name: Research and Critical Inquiry in Religious Studies
desc: Systematic instruction in research methods, academic writing, and the practice of critical analysis in the field of Religious Studies. Besides practical instruction, students will be introduced to a variety of methods and theories used in the academic study of religion.
prereqs: Admission to Religious Studies major or minor.
antireqs: Admission to Religious Studies major or minor.

name: Gender, Sex and Religion
desc: An examination of the complex interrelationship between understandings and constructions of gender, sexuality and Religion as they arise in the context of several religious traditions.

name: From Jesus to Christ
desc: The study of formative Christianity up to 200 CE in its political, social and religious contexts.

name: Pagans and Christians
desc: Examination of the evolution of ancient ‘pagan’ (Greek and Roman non-Christian) and early Christian religions from 200-800 CE, exploring their similarities, differences, and interactions, and situating them in their social, economic, cultural, and political context.

name: Christian Monks, Mystics and Reformers
desc: An overview of medieval Christian monasticism and mysticism, including female mystics such as Margery Kempe and Julian of Norwich, as well as humanists such as Erasmus, and early modern Protestant and Catholic Reformers.

name: Christian Responses to Modernity
desc: Examines various Christian responses to modernity from 1600 CE, including German Pietism, English Puritanism, John Wesley and early Evangelicalism, Protestant Liberalism, Vatican II and modern Roman Catholicism, Liberation Theology, and inter-religious dialogue.

name: Religion and Science
desc: The relationship between religion and science with emphasis on contemporary discussions regarding the intersection of religious thought and theories in the natural sciences.

name: Religion and the Environment
desc: Consideration of issues of public environmental concern from the perspectives of religious studies and ethics. Possible topics include climate change, water depletion, environmental pollution, animal stresses, species/ecosystem decimation, and the climate refugee problem.

name: Topics: Religion in Popular Culture
desc: The intersection of religion with popular culture is explored through specific topics.

name: Topics: Recent Religious Thought
desc: Detailed examination of a selected writer, topic, or intellectual current in recent religious thought.
prereqs: 3 units in Nature of Religion at the 300 level.
antireqs: 3 units in Nature of Religion at the 300 level.

name: Hermeneutics
desc: Significance of the hermeneutical tradition for an understanding of religious issues and traditions with attention to the thought of Schleiermacher, Dilthey, Husserl, Heidegger, Gadamer, and Ricoeur among others.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.

name: Advanced Topics in New Religious Movements
desc: Detailed study of selected topics in New Religious Movements.
prereqs: Religious Studies 341.
antireqs: Religious Studies 341.

name: Religion and Economic Systems
desc: A consideration of the relationship between religious practices and systems of exchange, credit, and economic rationalization. Historical documents will be used to illustrate the complex nature of religion and economics.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.

name: Existentialism
desc: An examination of existentialist thinkers from the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, contextualizing their work within both modernity and theist/atheist discourses.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.

name: Advanced Studies in Asian Thought
desc: A critical examination of Asian philosophical and religious thinkers.
prereqs: Philosophy 335 or 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: Philosophy 335 or 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.

name: Theories of Religion
desc: A critical examination of various theories used in the academic study of religion.
prereqs: Admission to Religious Studies major, Religious Studies 377 and 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: Admission to Religious Studies major, Religious Studies 377 and 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.

name: Advanced Topics in Hinduism
desc: In-depth study of the historical developments of Hinduism (Vedic, Classical, Medieval, Modern) in a seminar or independent study format.
prereqs: Religious Studies 303 or 307.
antireqs: Religious Studies 303 or 307.

name: Advanced Topics in Buddhism
desc: A seminar course that focuses on selected traditions, or philosophical or historical themes, such as Madhyamaka, Yogacara, T'ien T'ai, Hua Yen, Zen, Pure Land, Nyingma, Kargyud, Abhidharma, Tathagatagarbha, and Dhyana.
prereqs: 3 units from Religious Studies 313, 319, 323, 327 or 329.
antireqs: 3 units from Religious Studies 313, 319, 323, 327 or 329.

name: Advanced Topics in East Asian Religions
desc: A seminar course that focuses on selected topics related to the Confucian, Daoist, Buddhist, or Shinto traditions in China, Korea and Japan.
prereqs: Religious Studies 359.
antireqs: Religious Studies 359.

name: Advanced Topics in Cross-Cultural Philosophy of Religion
desc: Advanced comparative study of selected philosophical issues of religious interest arising from diverse cultures.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.

name: Advanced Topics in Judaism
desc: Selected topics in Jewish practices, institutions, beliefs and religious literature. Possible topics include: Jewish Movements of the Second Temple Era; Jewish Rituals and Observances; Midrash and Jewish Biblical Interpretation; Law and Religion in Judaism; Jewish Philosophy and Theology; Judaism in the Modern World; Kabbalah and Jewish Mysticism.
prereqs: Religious Studies 369.
antireqs: Religious Studies 369.

name: Advanced Topics in Islam
desc: Thematic considerations of topics, such as Islamic philosophy, mysticism, theology, or contemporary trends, based on primary sources. Although no knowledge of Arabic is required, students with backgrounds in Arabic will have the option of working with texts in their original languages.
prereqs: Religious Studies 353 or 357.
antireqs: Religious Studies 353 or 357.

name: Advanced Topics in Religious Studies
desc: Topics may include an overview of a specific religious tradition, an examination of religious expressions in a particular context, a thematic study of a religion or religions, or a methodological approach to the study of religion.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.

name: Further Studies in the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament
desc: Selected readings, in English translation, from the three major divisions (Pentateuch, Prophets, and Writings) of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament. Covers topics such as creation, miracles in Egypt, ark of the covenant, sacrifice, prophecies of the Bible, and biblical views of death and immortality.
prereqs: Religious Studies 301.
antireqs: Religious Studies 301.

name: Contemporary Issues in Women and Religion
desc: A topical examination of developments in current research in such areas as: gender theory, post-colonialism, philosophy and religion, feminist theology, feminist evaluation of traditional religious structures, or interdisciplinary work in the reconstruction of women's religiosity.
prereqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.
antireqs: 3 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 300 level.

name: Advanced Topics in Christianity
desc: A seminar course examining topics, personalities and movements in Christianity from its origins to its modern and contemporary developments.
prereqs: 3 units from Religious Studies 383, 385, 387 or 389.
antireqs: 3 units from Religious Studies 383, 385, 387 or 389.

name: Topics: Reading Religious Texts in Primary Languages
desc: Study of religious texts in original languages such as Hebrew, Sanskrit, Tibetan, Chinese or Japanese.
prereqs: 3 units from Religious Studies 302, 312, 316 or 322.
antireqs: 3 units from Religious Studies 302, 312, 316 or 322.

name: Senior Project Seminar
desc: Students will complete an independent research project on a topic within their area of concentration in Religious Studies and present their research in a seminar setting.
prereqs: Religious Studies 377 and 6 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 400 or 500 level and admission to the Religious Studies major or minor.
antireqs: Religious Studies 377 and 6 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 400 or 500 level and admission to the Religious Studies major or minor.

name: Honours Thesis
desc: Students compose a major research paper under the close supervision of a member of the Department and defend the thesis before an examining committee.
prereqs: Religious Studies 377 and 6 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 400 or 500 level and admission to the Honours program in Religious Studies or Ancient and Medieval History.
antireqs: Religious Studies 377 and 6 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the 400 or 500 level and admission to the Honours program in Religious Studies or Ancient and Medieval History.

name: Directed Independent Study
desc: Advanced study of a particular topic under the direction of a faculty member. Qualified students will be supervised through a session of independent study.
prereqs: 9 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the senior level with at least 3 units at the 400 level or above and consent of the Department.
antireqs: 9 units of courses labelled Religious Studies at the senior level with at least 3 units at the 400 level or above and consent of the Department.

name: Studies in the Nature of Religion
Selected Topics on Critical Discourses in the Study of Religion
desc: Selected topics on critical discourses in the study of religion.

name: Specialized Studies in the Nature of Religion
Studies in the Nature of Religion
Advanced Topics on Critical Discourses in the Study of Religion
desc: Advanced topics on critical discourses in the study of religion.

name: Romance Culture
desc: Study of Mediterranean cultures: France, Italy and Spain.

name: Italian Literature of the Renaissance
desc: Major authors of the Italian Renaissance whose works have influenced artists and writers in England, France and Spain.

name: Topics in Romance Languages
desc: Topics in Romance Languages, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Advanced Topics in Language and Culture
desc: Discussion of selected topics dealing with Romance languages, literatures and cultures.
prereqs: 3 units from French 227, 317, Italian 303 or Spanish 303.
antireqs: 3 units from French 227, 317, Italian 303 or Spanish 303.

name: Introductory Russian I
desc: Introduction to Russian in its cultural context. Four-skills language learning (reading, listening, speaking, writing) covering the principal elements of modern Russian. Focuses on Russian pronunciation and intonation, the Cyrillic alphabet, the foundations of Russian grammar, as well as basic vocabulary.

name: Introductory Russian II
desc: A further introduction to the basics of the Russian language, including its differences from and similarities to English, within the cultural and historical context. Structured according to various aspects of everyday life, such as family, university, professions, etc.
prereqs: Russian 201 or placement form.
antireqs: Russian 201 or placement form.

name: Continuing Russian I
desc: Furthers acquisition of the basic level of the language, enabling function in a variety of everyday situations by building comprehensive knowledge of grammar, expanding active vocabulary, and providing cultural information.
prereqs: Russian 30, 30-3Y, 209.
antireqs: Russian 30, 30-3Y, 209.

name: Continuing Russian II
desc: Further strengthens knowledge of the basics of the language enabling advancement to a more advanced stage of language mastery.
prereqs: Russian 301.
antireqs: Russian 301.

name: Russian Urban Culture in Immersion Setting
desc: Introduction to contemporary urban Russian culture through research projects and life experience.
prereqs: Russian 303.
antireqs: Russian 303.

name: Russian Rural Culture in Immersion Setting
desc: Introduction to contemporary rural Russian culture through research projects and life experience.

name: Russian Language in Immersion Setting
desc: Further development of oral skills and writing proficiency.

name: Topics in Russian Civilization and Thought
desc: Distinctive features in the development of Russian civilization and thought.

name: The Russian Verbal System
desc: A systematic survey of the Russian verbal system leading to the development of a structural understanding of the Russian language.
prereqs: Russian 303.
antireqs: Russian 303.

name: The Russian Nominal System
desc: A systematic survey of the Russian nominal system leading to the development of a structural understanding of the Russian language.
prereqs: Russian 303.
antireqs: Russian 303.

name: Topics in Russian Literature in Translation
desc: Selected texts by author, genre or period designed to explore issues of significance in the context of Russian culture.

name: Inter-Cultural Immersion Experience I
desc: Independent study course. Project with inter-cultural theme, derived from an immersion experience, most likely abroad.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Topics in Advanced Russian
desc: Provides diverse contexts and relies on various media and techniques to generate active and sophisticated usage of the language. Equips students with skills and strategies for independent language learning.
prereqs: Russian 332 or 334.
antireqs: Russian 332 or 334.

name: Topics in Russian Literature
desc: Introduces and examines selected literary texts by author, genre, movement or period with attention to issues of particular significance in Russian literary culture. Exposure to various critical approaches and literary works.
prereqs: Russian 303.
antireqs: Russian 303.

name: Topics in Russian Language and Culture
desc: In-depth study, from a historical or a contemporary perspective, of selected linguistic and cultural issues aiming to develop students’ critical thinking and cultural understanding as well as their analytical and interpretive skills.
prereqs: Russian 303.
antireqs: Russian 303.

name: Inter-Cultural Immersion Experience II
desc: Independent study course. Project with inter-cultural theme, derived from an immersion experience at an advanced level, most likely abroad.
prereqs: Russian 397 and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Russian 397 and consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Independent Study
desc: An independent research project on a topic that is not normally a part of the program's course offerings.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures. Permission to enrol in this course depends on a faculty member's agreement to sponsor the project.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures. Permission to enrol in this course depends on a faculty member's agreement to sponsor the project.

name: Research Seminar
desc: Centred on a professor's current research project, the course will engage senior students as members of a collaborative research team. Independent research, discussion, group presentations, dissemination of results in an appropriate venue.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Honours Project
desc: A research paper or creative project for honours students in their final year on a topic chosen in consultation with their supervisor.
prereqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.
antireqs: Consent of the School of Languages, Linguistics, Literatures and Cultures.

name: Performing Arts Management
desc: Introduction to politics, strategies, and practices of marketing and fundraising as they apply to non-profit performing arts companies.
prereqs: 9 units in courses labelled Dance, Drama, Music, Music Performance or School of Creative and Performing Arts.
antireqs: 9 units in courses labelled Dance, Drama, Music, Music Performance or School of Creative and Performing Arts.

name: History and the Performing Arts
desc: The history of dance, drama and music through an inter-arts lens, focusing on works and ideas across time periods and art forms.
prereqs: Admission to BA Dance, BFA Dance, BFA Drama, BA Music, BA Honours Music, or BMus.
antireqs: Admission to BA Dance, BFA Dance, BFA Drama, BA Music, BA Honours Music, or BMus.

name: Approaching Interdisciplinarity
desc: An exploration of the challenges and opportunities of interdisciplinary exchange and collaboration in the arts.
prereqs: 48 units and admission to BA Dance, BFA Dance, BFA Drama, BA Music, BA Honours Music, or BMus.
antireqs: 48 units and admission to BA Dance, BFA Dance, BFA Drama, BA Music, BA Honours Music, or BMus.

name: Topics in Inter-Arts Collaborations
desc: Experiential or lecture-based work that crosses the disciplinary boundaries of Dance, Drama and Music.
prereqs: 6 units of courses labelled Dance, Drama or Music or consent of the School.
antireqs: 6 units of courses labelled Dance, Drama or Music or consent of the School.

name: Travel Study
desc: An international perspective on performance and culture that crosses the disciplinary boundaries of Dance, Drama and Music.
prereqs: Consent of the School.
antireqs: Consent of the School.

name: Interdisciplinary Creation
desc: Advanced development of creative inquiry and practice through interdisciplinary exchange and collaboration in the arts.
prereqs: School of Creative and Performing Arts 499.
antireqs: School of Creative and Performing Arts 499.

name: Topics in Inter-Arts Collaborations
desc: Experiential or lecture-based work that crosses the disciplinary boundaries of Dance, Drama and Music.
prereqs: Consent of the School.
antireqs: Consent of the School.

name: Travel Study
desc: An international perspective on performance and culture that crosses the disciplinary boundaries of Dance, Drama and Music.
prereqs: Consent of the School.
antireqs: Consent of the School.

name: Interdisciplinary Processes
desc: Concepts and principles of interdisciplinarity are examined through examples of artistic practice and research with opportunities for practical application in preparation for thesis work.

name: Topics in Perspectives on Eastern Europe
desc: Selected significant current issues in East-European cultures through the lens of literature, visual arts, drama, music, and film.

name: Introductory Sociology
desc: Sociology as a discipline examines how the society in which we live influences our thinking and behaviour. An introduction to sociology through the study of society, social institutions, group behaviour and social change.

name: Topics in Sociology
desc: A variety of sociological topics are explored at an introductory level.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Sociology of Gender
desc: A sociological exploration of the way genders are constructed and how they play-out at the level of individuals and institutions, and in diverse social contexts.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Sociology of Indigenous People in Canada
desc: The dynamics of Indigenous groups' relations with each other and the larger society. Topics include decolonization and relations with the state, demography, Indigenous organizations, Indigenous nationalism and nation-building, power, social class and public policy.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Alberta Society
desc: Sociological introduction to the ideology, composition, dynamics, and institutions of Albertan society, using external comparisons where relevant.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Introductory Social Statistics I
desc: Univariate and bivariate statistics for survey data. Topics include cross tabular analysis, the normal distribution, confidence intervals for means, hypothesis testing, Chi-squared and F distributions and bivariate linear regression analysis. In labs statistical software to analyze survey data will be used.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Introductory Social Research Methods
desc: Research processes including problem definition, data collection and analyses; quantitative and qualitative strategies.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Introductory Social Statistics II
desc: Multivariate statistics for survey data; and measurement issues in quantitative research. Topics include reliability, multivariate tabular analysis, multiple regression, dummy variable regression, statistical interaction and path analysis. In labs statistical software to test measurement and causal models will be used.
prereqs: Sociology 311.
antireqs: Sociology 311.

name: Sociology of Health and Illness
desc: Introduction to social factors influencing health, illness, and medicine. Topics covered may include the organization of medical institutions and occupations, the socialization of medical professionals, the social construction of illness, social determinants of health, and comparative health-care systems and policy.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Introduction to Deviance and Social Control
desc: The presentation and analysis of theories of criminality and of non-criminal deviance, methods to uncover the incidence of deviance and criminality, a survey of forms of deviant and criminal behaviours, and the social and institutional responses to them.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Introduction to Criminal Justice
desc: Introduction to the field of criminal justice in Canada from a sociological perspective. May include: examination of the definitions of crime; crime measurement; institutional responses to crime by the police, the courts and correctional services; and alternatives to the justice model.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: The Sociology of Law
desc: An introduction to sociological problems regarding the origin, impact and definition of law, dispute resolution, and the relationship between law and social change.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Classical Sociological Theory
desc: The development of sociological theory from the nineteenth century to the Second World War.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Contemporary Sociological Theory
desc: The development of sociological theory from the Second World War to the present.
prereqs: Sociology 331.
antireqs: Sociology 331.

name: Social Psychology
desc: A wide range of interdependent individual and social topics that influence our thinking, feeling, and behaviour. Topics may include social cognition, perception, social experience, group behaviour, social interaction, and emotions.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Mass Communication
desc: A critical, theoretically-informed look at what it means to live in a society in which the forms and content of mass media/mass communication – and our uses of them – shape our lives in significant ways.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Urban Sociology
desc: Discusses the impact of urbanization on social relationships by analyzing city living in historical and global perspective but also through local issues such as density and neighbourhoods.  Provides a sociological perspective on issues that cities are facing today.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Population and Society
desc: Introduction to social demography – the study of population structure (size, composition and distribution) and processes (fertility, mortality and migration). Focuses on both empirical and theoretical relationships between demography, social change and structured inequality.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Social Stratification
desc: Introduction to the sociological study of social inequalities and stratification and the major theoretical explanations of social inequalities.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Sociology of Families
desc: A sociological examination of family life in all its multiple and changing forms. Topics may include key transitions and common practices in family life; gender, sexuality and family life, and family life in cross-cultural context.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Sociology of Aging
desc: Social and institutional factors associated with aging in modern society.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Sociology of Ethnicity and Racialization
desc: Introduction to the forms of ethnic and racial dynamics in selected cases around the world. Such concepts as identity, ethnicity, race, racialization, racism, assimilation, integration, pluralism, colonialism, post-colonialism, transnationalism and diasporas are examined in theoretical and cross-national contexts.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Sociology of Religion
desc: An introduction to the theories and concepts utilized by sociologists to interpret religious behaviour and the organization of religion.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Sociology of Work
desc: A sociological perspective for gaining a better understanding of the meaning and nature of work. Provides an overview of core concepts and current topics fundamental to understanding work in society.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Sociology of Sport
desc: Organized around the theme of social problems in sport, examines sports-related behaviour, consumption, and sponsorship. A variety of approaches shows how sport is socially constructed and embodies different meanings for different groups of people.
prereqs: Sociology 201.
antireqs: Sociology 201.

name: Advanced Topics in Sociology
