Students investigate a series of simulated outbreaks, applying steps to determine whether an outbreak exists, establishing a case definition, describing the epidemiology of the disease, generating and testing hypotheses, and communicating their findings.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Foreign Animal Disease
desc: Students work through a simulation of an incursion of foreign animal disease into Canada. The simulation and background gives students experience working with disease surveillance, case identification, emergency preparedness, and the role of public practice veterinarians in maintaining the safety of Canadian livestock.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Career Options and Field Experiences in Veterinary Medicine
desc: Students are exposed to career options in clinical and non-clinical veterinary medicine.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Applied Nutrition
desc: Core concepts pertaining to nutritional requirements, feeding regimes, and nutritional disorders in production and companion animals are examined. Feeding management of exotic animals is also discussed. Emphasis is placed on practical application of nutritional concepts in production and companion animals.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Clinical Presentations III
desc: Building on Veterinary Medicine 300 and 400, students continue their development of diagnostic reasoning skills and problem management in veterinary medicine. Students synthesize comprehensive treatment plans that take into account therapeutic approaches, outcomes, feasibility, economics, client expectations, compliance, public health, regulations, and the environment.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Clinical Skills III
desc: Building on Veterinary Medicine 305 and 405, students gain experience in clinical evaluations, routine anaesthesia and surgery. Diagnostic and therapeutic skills, practical clinical intervention, case management, and disease prevention knowledge and skills are further developed.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Professional Skills III
desc: Building on Veterinary Medicine 307 and 407, students participate in a class research project, integrating research, informatics, communication, and clinical skills. Students will develop professional skills necessary for dealing with challenging issues in veterinary medicine. The concept of the healthy veterinarian and self-management will be expanded.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Equine Medicine and Surgery
desc: Prepares students for general equine practice by providing the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing and treating  common equine diseases using medical or surgical approaches. Emphasizes the importance of professional conduct in the context of equine practice and promotes life-long continuing education.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Small Animal Medicine and Surgery
desc: Prepares students for small animal practice by providing the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing and treating common diseases in cats and dogs using medical or surgical approaches. Promotes practices that comply with animal welfare professional conduct.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Anaesthesiology and Therapeutics
desc: Introduction to the principals and practice of veterinary anaesthesiology and therapeutics in production, companion and exotic animals, and the practical application of clinical pharmacology. Focus on local and general anaesthesia for low risk animals and on therapeutic decisions, drug selection, and drug delivery.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Advanced Health Management
desc: Provides an overview of diagnosing, managing, and preventing common disorders that occur at a population level. Emphasis is placed upon application of evidence-based medicine to make a herd diagnosis and control, and prevent the problem. Health programs and animal welfare assessment for production and companion animals are explored.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Selected Topics in Clinical Medicine
desc: Prepares students for clinical practice by providing the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing and treating oncologic, ophthalmic and dermatological diseases in production and companion animals.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Selected Topics in Small Ruminant, South American Camelid and Non-traditional Livestock Production
desc: Selected medical, surgical and reproductive diseases of small ruminants, South American camelids and non-traditional livestock.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Food Animal Medicine and Surgery
desc: Prepares students for general food animal practice by providing the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing, treating and preventing common diseases using medical or surgical approaches. Promotes practices that comply with animal welfare and professional conduct.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Theriogenology
desc: Provides knowledge and skills to develop clinical competence in managing the reproductive health of production and companion animals. Students integrate knowledge from various disciplines to diagnose and manage clinical issues pertaining to the reproductive health of animals on an individual animal or herd basis.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Emergency and Critical Care
desc: Veterinary emergency and critical care, with emphasis on how to recognize and implement therapy in the unstable patient.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Zoological Medicine
desc: Provides the foundational knowledge needed for diagnosing, treating and preventing common diseases in non-traditional companion animal and wildlife species.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Laboratory Animal Medicine
desc: Provides an introduction to laboratory animal medicine and disease, roles of the laboratory animal veterinarian and animal care committees, and the involvement of animals in research and teaching.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Ecosystem and Public Health Field Course
desc: Students will synthesize concepts learned in Veterinary Medicine 440 and 462. Provides experience in applying regulatory requirements and diagnostic testing performed as part of the Canadian Food Inspection Agency accredited veterinary duties.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Laboratory Diagnostics
desc: Required for entering general veterinary practice. Students must successfully complete rotations in laboratory diagnostics and diagnostic imaging at laboratories at the Clinical Skills Building on the Spy Hill campus.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: General Veterinary Practice
desc: Required for entering general veterinary practice. Students must successfully complete clinical rotations in general veterinary practice at sites located within the Distributed Veterinary Teaching Hospital.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Production Animal Health
desc: Students choose from a variety of rotations that enable concentration within Production Animal Health.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Ecosystem and Public Health
desc: Students choose from a variety of rotations that enable concentration within Ecosystem and Public Health.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Equine Health
desc: Students choose from a variety of rotations that enable concentration within Equine Health.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Investigative Medicine
desc: Students choose from a variety of rotations that enable concentration within Investigative Medicine.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Clinical Enrichment
desc: Students choose elective rotations from a range of practicum experiences in veterinary medicine in order to expand or deepen their knowledge and skills.
prereqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.
antireqs: Admission to the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM) Program.

name: Professional Skills in Health Science Research
desc: Includes a series of workshops focusing on skills essential for success in health science research. Topics include: Research Integrity; Ethics; Grants and Grant Writing; Verbal and Written Communication of Research Findings; Career Development; and Career Options in the Health Sciences.
prereqs: Consent of the Faculty.
antireqs: Consent of the Faculty.

name: Introduction to Biostastical Methods
desc: Analysis and design of research related to biological sciences. Emphasis is placed upon formulating good research questions, evaluating the appropriateness of different statistical methods for analyzing results, and performing and interpreting such statistical analyses. Statistical analyses will be carried out using modern statistical software.
prereqs: Consent of the Faculty.
antireqs: Consent of the Faculty.

name: Biostatistics I: Essentials of Biostatistics
desc: Introduces the fundamental concepts of summarizing data and statistical inference, including graphical displays, hypothesis testing, p-values, and confidence intervals. Specific topics include comparisons of means and proportions, non-parametric tests, correlation and regression, confounding, sample size determination, and power calculations. Additional topics include a brief introduction to analysis of variance and covariance, logistic regression, and analysis of time-to-event data. Students gain hands-on experience analysing data using STATA statistical software. Although this course uses STATA exclusively, much of the technical knowledge and some of the computing techniques are applicable to any statistical package.
prereqs: Admission to the Veterinary Medical Sciences graduate program.
antireqs: Admission to the Veterinary Medical Sciences graduate program.

name: Biostatistics II: Models for Health Outcomes
desc: Extends the fundamental concepts to modelling health outcomes using modern regression analysis techniques. Logistic and linear regressions, and their extensions, are covered in detail. The rationale, formulation, and statistical assumptions underlying each regression technique are discussed. Methods for selecting and assessing models are included. Additional topics include a brief introduction to models used in the analysis of repeated measures, longitudinal studies, and time-to-event data.
prereqs: Veterinary Medicine 610.
antireqs: Veterinary Medicine 610.

name: Fundamentals of Epidemiology
desc: Principles and methods of descriptive and analytic epidemiology. Emphasizes the underlying concepts and approaches of epidemiological research and critical appraisal of epidemiologic studies including: observational study designs and their vulnerabilities to bias, measures of frequency and association, basic methods for addressing sampling variability, confounding, and effect modification. Concepts related to causal judgment in epidemiology are also introduced.
prereqs: Admission to the Veterinary Medical Sciences graduate program or consent of the Faculty.
antireqs: Admission to the Veterinary Medical Sciences graduate program or consent of the Faculty.

name: Directed Study
desc: Lectures, seminars, term papers and/or other training directed to one or only a few students in theoretical and/or laboratory methods at the advanced level in veterinary medical sciences. These courses are offered when no other suitable alternatives are available.
prereqs: Consent of the Faculty.
antireqs: Consent of the Faculty.

name: Advanced Topics in Reproductive Health
desc: A series of topics, ranging from basic sciences to clinical topics (including ethical issues) to increase awareness and comprehension regarding current issues in reproductive health.
prereqs: Consent of course co-ordinator and student’s supervisor, if applicable.
antireqs: Consent of course co-ordinator and student’s supervisor, if applicable.

name: Advanced Topics in Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine
desc: Provides a comprehensive overview of stem cell biology in the context of embryonic development and adult tissue maintenance. Students will gain an appreciation for embryonic versus adult stem cells and how these pluripotent or multipotent cells may be utilized in regenerative medicine (i.e. treatment of congenital defects, diseases or injury).
prereqs: Admission to the VMS graduate program or consent of the instructor.
antireqs: Admission to the VMS graduate program or consent of the instructor.

name: Wildlife Parasitology: Principles and Techniques
desc: Students will learn about the ecology of parasites in wildlife populations with emphasis on impacts of parasitism, invasive species, and conservation issues. This is taught through a series of seminars, critical evaluation and discussion of the literature, and independent and group projects. Laboratory sessions include on parasitology techniques for surveillance and research.
prereqs: Consent of the instructor.
antireqs: Consent of the instructor.

name: Advanced Epidemiology
desc: An expansion on the understanding of causality and threats to validity in epidemiologic research. The focus will be on the assessment and control of bias, including selection, information and confounding. The concept of effect modification (interaction) will be appraised. Stratified analysis will be considered as a tool for the assessment and control of confounding and effect modification and will be applied to a variety of study designs including case-control, and cohort studies.
prereqs: Veterinary Medicine 640 or consent of the Faculty.
antireqs: Veterinary Medicine 640 or consent of the Faculty.

name: English Academic Success
desc: Students will relate their own life story and experiences to the wider human condition by reading a variety of literary texts and through writing in a variety of literary forms. Assignments will present opportunities for students to develop a critical understanding of literature in a personal context.
prereqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-based) program.
antireqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-based) program.

name: Introduction to Educational Studies
desc: An introduction to the breadth and complexity of educational studies. Unique among academic domains, educational studies not only arises in the intersections of many other fields – including psychology, sociology, anthropology, and a range of disciplinary domains – it must also be responsive to a rapidly changing world.
prereqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program or consent of the program.
antireqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program or consent of the program.

name: Reading Educational Research
desc: Focusing on students’ reading skills, this course continues to develop awareness of academic language genres, formal versus informal language use, and the development of critical thinking and logical argumentation skills. Continuing development of study skills and approaches that foster long-term academic success are integrated into course materials.
prereqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.
antireqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.

name: How Children Learn to Read
desc: Examines how young children learn to read through their world of daily experiences.
prereqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.
antireqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.

name: Supporting Children’s Reading
desc: Students will explore strategies for promoting reading development through integrated experiential learning opportunities.
prereqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.
antireqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.

name: Academic Writing in Education
desc: Focusing on students’ writing skills, this course develops awareness of academic language genres, formal versus informal language use, as well as the skills required for researching and referencing academic work in written texts. The development of study skills and approaches that foster long-term academic success are integrated with academic language skills development.
prereqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.
antireqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.

name: How Children Learn to Write
desc: Examines how young children learn to write through their world of daily experiences.
prereqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.
antireqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.

name: Supporting Children’s Writing
desc: Students will explore strategies for promoting writing development through integrated experiential learning opportunities.
prereqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.
antireqs: Admission to Bridging to Community-Based BEd stream in the Bachelor of Education (Community-Based) program, or consent of the program.

name: Inside Mathematics
desc: An exploration of the usually-tacit elements of mathematical concepts and processes, the course focuses on strategies for unpacking concepts and for sustained engagement in inquiry.
prereqs: 18 units at the 200 level, including Mathematics 211 or 213; and 271 or 273.
antireqs: 18 units at the 200 level, including Mathematics 211 or 213; and 271 or 273.

name: Integrating Arts Education
desc: Preparation for individuals interested in understanding effective learning through the arts. Specific knowledge and technique in arts-based processes will be acquired and applied through collaborative, creating learning tasks. In this course students will experience, reflect upon, and learn about the processes and practices of arts integration. Students will be exposed to and collectively explore a variety of contexts through the arts while acquiring knowledge, skills and abilities to plan and apply arts-based research methodologies in their practice.
prereqs: 18 units at the 200 level.
antireqs: 18 units at the 200 level.

name: Early Childhood Development
desc: An examination of the science of early childhood and early brain development that accounts for the physical, cognitive, emotional, and social development of young children from birth to age eight, and a consideration of the implications with respect to children’s healthy development and effective educational practices in the early school years.
prereqs: 18 units at the 200 level.
antireqs: 18 units at the 200 level.

name: Language and Literacy, Learning in the Classroom
desc: An introduction to perspectives on the way children and adolescents become “literate”, examining language and literacy from a development perspective and children’s literature from a genre perspective.
prereqs: 18 units at the 200 level.
antireqs: 18 units at the 200 level.

name: Starting with Story: Teaching and Learning with Indigenous Literatures
desc: With Indigenous literary arts as a doorway into engaging with Indigenous knowledge systems, languages, and communities, this course examines key texts, contexts, and theories to consider applications in educational settings.
prereqs: 18 units at the 200 level.
antireqs: 18 units at the 200 level.

name: Issues in Learning and Teaching
desc: Presents an overview of the central issues related to the nature of learning and teaching for those preparing for the teaching profession. Themes include: the nature of learning; current realities in society; patterns of growth and development; and the changing dynamics of the teaching profession.
prereqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM)
desc: An introduction to key elements of STEM Education, including curriculum, pedagogy, standards and assessment. Participants will learn how to engage students and integrate STEM topics across all subject areas.427.01 STEM Early Childhood Education 427.02 STEM Elementary Route427.03 STEM Secondary Route427.04 STEM K-12 (Community-Based pathways only)
prereqs: Admission to the corresponding route in the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Admission to the corresponding route in the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Pragmatics of Learning and Teaching
desc: Examines the concomitant requirements within which teachers operate. The major components that will be addressed include the ways in which teachers work within the parameters of prescribed curricula and assessment requirements, follow system and school policies, participate in team teaching and school culture, and reflect one’s work, values and goals.
prereqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Literacy, Language and Culture
desc: The orienting principle is that every teacher is a teacher of reading. Includes a focus on the necessity for teachers across all disciplines and grades to attend to dimensions of language development, linguistic diversity, and literacy learning in their classrooms.
prereqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Field Experience I
desc: Students will participate in Educational Rounds in school settings within and outside of their areas of specializations under the guidance of their university field instructor and the partner school leadership team. They will explore the organization of learning in the school and the perspective of the learner and the teacher.
prereqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Admission to the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Individual Learning: Theories and Applications
desc: Covers contemporary theories regarding the nature of individual learning. Students will examine the ways educators guide and support learning, design effective learning experiences, and understand underpinning factors related to individual learning. The application of these theories will be examined using examples that demonstrate and exemplify individual learning.
prereqs: Education 440 and admission to the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Education 440 and admission to the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Diversity in Learning
desc: Includes key topics in inclusive education from an interdisciplinary perspective. The development and conception of diversity of learning will be examined from historical and contemporary perspectives. Building upon this foundation, students will consider the multiple and contested ways in which diversity of learning has been conceived, implemented and evaluated in schools.
prereqs: Education 440 and admission to the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Education 440 and admission to the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Assessment
desc: An array of topics related to assessment to help students develop professional competencies in relation to the philosophy, theory and pedagogical application of assessment practices for K-12 education.
prereqs: Education 440 and admission to the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Education 440 and admission to the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Specialization I
desc:
Introduction on enacting pedagogy in each of the teachable subject areas in the program and pedagogical content knowledge in each area. Includes disciplinary ways of knowing, doing and being; understanding the Alberta Programs of Study; designing for deep understanding of learners. 
460.01 Specialization I Elementary Early Childhood Education 460.02 Specialization I Elementary English Language Learners460.03 Specialization I Elementary English Language Arts 460.04 Specialization I Elementary Fine Arts 460.05 Specialization I Elementary French 460.06 Specialization I Elementary Inclusive Education 460.07 Specialization I Elementary Mathematics 460.08 Specialization I Elementary Physical Education 460.09 Specialization I Elementary Science 460.10 Specialization I Elementary Second Languages 460.11 Specialization I Elementary Social Studies 460.12 Specialization I Secondary English Language Arts 460.13 Specialization I Secondary Fine Arts 460.14 Specialization I Secondary French 460.15 Specialization I Secondary Mathematics 460.16 Specialization I Secondary Physical Education 460.17 Specialization I Secondary Science 460.18 Specialization I Secondary Second Languages 460.19 Specialization I Secondary Social Studies460.20 Specialization I K-12 Social Studies (Community-Based pathways only)460.21 Specialization I K-12 English Language Arts (Community-Based pathways only)460.22 Specialization I K-12 Mathematics (Community-Based pathways only)460.23 Specialization I K-12 Science (Community-Based pathways only)460.24 Specialization I K-12 Early Childhood Education (Community-Based pathways only)
prereqs: Education 440 and admission to the corresponding teachable subject area in the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Education 440 and admission to the corresponding teachable subject area in the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Field Experience II
desc: This block field experience will have major focus on the complexities of individual learning. Prospective teachers will have the opportunity to follow individual students through various classrooms within their assigned schools under the guidance of their university field instructors and partner school leadership teams.
prereqs: Education 440 and admission to the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Education 440 and admission to the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Interdisciplinary Learning
desc: Students will be introduced to new knowledge building experiences that deepen their understanding of the interdisciplinary nature of learning and practice in schools and societies. Particular attention will address how teachers integrate ideas to connect learning and knowledge between subject specializations in attending to complex forms of learning and understanding, and how teachers understand their agency and leadership roles in concert with the responsibility that accompanies it.
prereqs: Education 465.
antireqs: Education 465.

name: Ethics and Law in Education
desc: An introduction to the historical genesis and institutional structure of Alberta's system of education; an understanding of its legal underpinnings; an opportunity for dialogue; on current major issues in education; and discussion involving ethical decision-making surrounding educational issues.
prereqs: Education 465.
antireqs: Education 465.

name: Indigenous Education
desc: Students will be introduced to the national and international experiences and advances of Indigenous peoples as related to education. Particular attention will be given to understanding the histories and diversity of the First Nations, Métis and Inuit peoples of Canada and the concomitant implications that this has for education policy and practice.
prereqs: Education 465.
antireqs: Education 465.

name: Specialization II
desc:
Deepens students’ knowledge on enacting pedagogy in each of the specialization in the program and their pedagogical content knowledge in each specialization.
535.01 Specialization II Elementary Early Childhood Education 535.02 Specialization II Elementary English Language Learners535.03 Specialization II Elementary English Language Arts 535.04 Specialization II Elementary Fine Arts 535.05 Specialization II Elementary French 535.06 Specialization II Elementary Inclusive Education 535.07 Specialization II Elementary Mathematics 535.08 Specialization II Elementary Physical Education 535.09 Specialization II Elementary Science Specialization535.10 Specialization II Elementary Second Languages 535.11 Specialization II Elementary Social Studies 535.12 Specialization II Secondary English Language Arts 535.13 Specialization II Secondary Fine Arts Specialization535.14 Specialization II Secondary French Specialization535.15 Specialization II Secondary Mathematics 535.16 Specialization II Secondary Physical Education 535.17 Specialization II Secondary Science Specialization535.18 Specialization II Secondary Second Languages 535.19 Specialization II Secondary Social Studies 535.20 Specialization II K-12 Social Studies (Community-Based pathways only)535.21 Specialization II K-12 English Language Arts (Community-Based pathways only)535.22 Specialization II K-12 Mathematics (Community-Based pathways only)535.23 Specialization II K-12 Science (Community-Based pathways only)535.24 Specialization II K-12 Early Childhood Education (Community-Based pathways only)
prereqs: Education 465 and admission to the corresponding teachable subject area in the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Education 465 and admission to the corresponding teachable subject area in the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Field Experience III
desc: This team-oriented block practicum is founded upon the principles of collaborative learning. It includes structures and supports that promote positive interdependence, individual accountability, equal participation, and simultaneous interaction.
prereqs: Education 465.
antireqs: Education 465.

name: Design-based Thinking
desc:
An exploration of key design processes in Education. Topics covered include production pedagogy, user-centered design, and principles of design thinking. The course offers tools to incorporate elements of design thinking into effective classroom teaching in a variety of subject areas
546.01 Design-based Thinking Early Childhood Education546.02 Design-based Thinking Elementary Route546.03 Design-based Thinking Secondary Route546.04 Design-based Thinking K-12 (Community-Based pathways only)
prereqs: Education 540 and admission to the corresponding route in the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Education 540 and admission to the corresponding route in the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Comprehensive School Health and Wellness
desc:
A healthy school community supports the wellness of all its members and healthy students make better learners. Within the broader evidence-based comprehensive school health framework, this course provides the theoretical foundations, research base, community resources, and experiential learning to create the capacity for future teachers to be health champions.
551.01 Comprehensive School Health and Wellness Early Childhood Education551.02 Comprehensive School Health and Wellness Elementary Route551.03 Comprehensive School Health and Wellness Secondary Route551.04 Comprehensive School Health and Wellness K-12 (Community-Based pathways only)
prereqs: Education 540 and admission to the corresponding route in the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Education 540 and admission to the corresponding route in the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Professional Learning
desc:
Focuses on adult education perspectives on lifelong learning and the teaching profession. It emphasizes how novice teachers understand and encourage their learning, and the impacts of that learning on their teaching practice. Theoretical frameworks, philosophical underpinnings and reflections on experiences of adult learning will be explored.
556.01 Professional Learning Early Childhood Education556.02 Professional Learning Elementary Route556.03 Professional Learning Secondary Route556.04 Professional Learning K-12 (Community-Based pathways only)
prereqs: Education 540 and admission to the corresponding route in the Bachelor of Education program.
antireqs: Education 540 and admission to the corresponding route in the Bachelor of Education program.

name: Field Experience IV
desc: In this extended block field experience, students will have an opportunity to work one-on-one to lead a class with a mentor teacher. They will be under the guidance of their university advisors and partner school leadership teams.
prereqs: Education 540.
antireqs: Education 540.

name: Field Experience for Certification
desc: An extended block field experience to lead a class with a mentor teacher. Students will be supervised by their University field instructors and partner teachers.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Indigenous Literacy Arts as a Doorway to Decolonizing Pedagogy and Practice: Starting with Story
desc: Build competencies in engaging with Indigenous knowledge systems and communities in teaching and learning. Educators will explore Indigenous literary arts along with relevant theories, contextual knowledge, and personal-professional reflexivity.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Emerging Digital Pedagogies
desc: Provides educators with increased understanding of digital pedagogies and the literacies that can be implemented to support digital learning.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Teaching Diversity in the Inclusive Classroom
desc: Provides educators with a strong foundational understanding of the role of diversity in K-12 education and will provide practical ideas for teaching about diversity in an inclusive classroom context.
prereqs: Consent of the Department.
antireqs: Consent of the Department.

name: Contemporary Education
desc: Examination of philosophical, historical and curricular constructions of contemporary Canadian and Albertan education.
prereqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Teaching in Alberta I
desc: Exploration of the core beliefs, values, and practices in contemporary educational environments, and how students can bridge from their own understanding to what is aimed for in Alberta learning environments.
prereqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Practicum Support Seminar I
desc: Examination of how to integrate previous teaching expertise and new learning with practicum experiences in Alberta.
prereqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Learning with Technology
desc: Examination of ways to create authentic and meaningful learning experiences through the implementation of digital technologies in classroom settings.
prereqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Teaching in Alberta II
desc: Further examination of teaching and learning in Alberta classrooms.
prereqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Practicum Support Seminar II
desc: Further examination of how to integrate previous teaching expertise and new learning with practicum experiences in Alberta.
prereqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to the Bridge to Teaching program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Theories, Conceptualizations, and Interventions in Counselling Psychology I
desc: Theoretical foundations and practice frameworks for the major schools of counselling psychology.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Theories, Conceptualizations, and Interventions in Counselling Psychology II
desc: A continuation of theoretical foundations and practice frameworks for the major schools of counselling psychology.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Counselling Theories and Professional Practice
desc: Engages students in a critical evaluation of a range of contemporary counselling theories and helps them begin to develop a description of their own emerging theory.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Research Methods in School Psychology
desc: Advanced study of research methods for use in applied psychology and education.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Professional Ethics in Applied Psychology
desc: Ethical, legal and professional knowledge to inform practice in educational, counselling and mental health contexts.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Psychological Measurement and Statistics
desc: Advanced study of measurement and quantitative research methods for use in applied psychology and education.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Practice Evaluation in School Psychology
desc: Introduction to basic concepts related to the assessment of the quality and effectiveness of educational programs and environments.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Fundamentals of Measurement
desc: Survey course on educational research methodologies which addresses issues of research design, methods, and interpretation of research findings, including a focus on test construction and psychometrics as they pertain to the development of assessment tools.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or the consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Introduction to Statistical Analyses
desc: An introductory course on descriptive and inferential statistics designed to give students with minimal statistical background sufficient competence to conduct basic statistical procedures. Topics will include: displaying data; measures of central tendency, variability, and correlation; regression analysis and prediction; probability; parameter estimation; and analysis of variance. Emphasis will be on understanding basic concepts, using software to conduct analyses, and interpretation of results.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Research Design in Statistics II
desc: Research design and statistics, including methods for research in  psychology and related laboratory instruction.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Research Methodology in Counselling
desc: Survey course on research methodologies in counselling, which addresses issues of research design, methods and interpretation of research findings.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Qualitative Research Methodologies
desc: Advanced study of qualitative research methods for use in applied psychology and education.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Research Methods in School Psychology
desc: Advanced study of research methods for use in applied psychology and education.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Ethics in Professional Psychology
desc: Ethical, legal, and professional knowledge to inform practice in professional psychology.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Theoretical and Clinical Foundations of Assessment
desc: In-depth review of theoretical and clinical foundations of psycho-educational assessment. Focus is on processes of assessment, properties of tests, use and interpretation of tests and clinical diagnosis.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Assessment Theory and Practices
desc: Combines a theoretical and practical focus to develop a framework from which to approach the assessment of client change in a variety of contexts.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 602, 622 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 602, 622 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Psychological Assessment of Adults
desc: Focuses on the knowledge and skills necessary to select, administer, score and interpret formal psychological tests and other assessment instruments commonly used with adults within counselling contexts.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 615 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 615 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Multivariate Design and Analysis
desc: Research design and statistics in psychology, with special reference to large sample techniques.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 609 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology, or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 609 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology, or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Counselling Girls and Women
desc: Sex role development; stereotyping and social roles; counselling theories; counselling approaches.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Psychological Assessment of Children and Youth
desc: Focuses on the knowledge and skills necessary to select, administer, score, and interpret formal psychological tests and other assessment instruments commonly used with children and youth within counselling psychology contexts.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Creating a Working Alliance
desc: Theory and practice in developing skills contributing to working alliance and problem clarification. Ethical, legal and professional issues are the context for the application of generic counselling skills in laboratory experiences.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Developing and Sustaining a Working Alliance with Clients
desc: Focuses on the understanding and acquisition of skills that are essential for the development of working alliances in counselling contexts. Introduces a theoretical framework for the application of counselling skills in addition to providing the opportunity for skill practice.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Theory in Counselling
desc: History and systems involved in counselling psychology and client change.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Cultural and Social Justice Issues in Professional Practice
desc: A critical examination of cultural and equity issues related to the lives of clients and the psychological professionals serving them.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Cultural Influences on Professional Practice
desc: An examination of cultural influences on theory and practice in applied psychology.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Group Interventions and Processes
desc: Examines theoretical, research, and experiential knowledge helpful in facilitating diverse educational and psychological groups.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Group Processes in Applied Psychology
desc: Theory of group practice in applied psychology, with experiential laboratory.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Theories and Applications of Child and Youth Therapy
desc: Review of the theoretical foundations and associated clinical strategies of psychosocial intervention with children and youth by drawing on common approaches to contemporary practice.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 600 and 601 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 600 and 601 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Theory and Applications: Selected Topics
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Foundations of Career Counselling
desc: Review and application of theoretical and research literatures relevant to counselling clients with career concerns.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Theories of Career Development
desc: Study of career development theory and related research; implications for the applied field.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Career Development and Services for Organizational Settings
desc: Designed to combine theoretical and practical concerns regarding applications of career development concepts to human resources contexts in organizations. Concepts will be relevant to counselling and human resources development professionals.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 602, 603, 622, 625 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 602, 603, 622, 625 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Career Counselling
desc: Laboratory and field experiences in career counselling.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 631 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 631 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Multicultural Career Development and Counselling
desc: Increasing cultural diversity requires career development practitioners to examine the ways that their services are designed and delivered. Designed to enable students to deliver culturally responsive career counselling services to diverse populations.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 636, 646 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 636, 646 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Advanced History, Theory, and Practice in Psychology
desc: Course examines the history of psychological concepts in Western culture, major theoretical systems and research approaches, and the foundational assumptions of contemporary perspectives in psychology.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or Educational Research.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or Educational Research.

name: Systemic Approaches to Community Change
desc: Provides students with a theoretical and practical basis to work as effective community change agents in a broad range of sectors. An examination of comprehensive guidance in schools provides a foundation for exploring key concepts pertinent to developing and implementing comprehensive services in a variety of contexts, and in the process, gaining a better understanding of communities, and building their strengths and capacities.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Relationship Counselling
desc: Study of theories and intervention strategies of the most common approaches to contemporary practice in couples and family therapy.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 600 and 601 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 600 and 601 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Counselling Interventions for Client Change
desc: Combines a theoretical and practical focus to develop a framework from which to plan and implement client change interventions in a variety of contexts.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 602, 622 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 602, 622 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Counselling Interventions
desc: Theory and practice in planning and implementing client change interventions; the application of counselling interventions in laboratory experiences.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 621, 623 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 621, 623 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Practicum in Counselling Psychology II
desc: Supervised counselling experience and related seminars.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 621, 625 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 621, 625 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Development, Learning and Cognition - Child and Adolescent
desc: The interactions of development, learning and cognition in childhood and adolescence.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Counselling Practicum I
desc: Provides an opportunity for professional development and supervised practice in a general counselling setting. Students will be involved in direct work with clients under the supervision of a qualified professional.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 604, 616, 622, 624, 638 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 604, 616, 622, 624, 638 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Development, Learning and Cognition - Adult
desc: The interactions of development, learning and cognition in childhood and adulthood.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Counselling Practicum II
desc: Provides an opportunity for professional development and supervised practice in a specialized counselling context. Students will be involved in direct work with clients under the supervision of a qualified professional. The practicum allows students to actively explore issues encountered in working with a specialized client population or area of practice.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 616, 638, 642 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 616, 638, 642 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Indigenous Approaches to Therapy
desc: Focuses on integrating Indigenous ways of knowing, being, and doing into therapeutic practice, including case conceptualization, the therapeutic alliance, treatment planning, interventions, and ethics. Addresses Indigenous approaches to therapy with individuals, families, and groups.

name: Processes of Learning
desc: Addresses the essential features of major theories of learning and presents current research in each area of learning. Students will discover how the principles of learning relate to their own learning and behaviour, and how the principles can be used to understand the behaviour of others and enhance counselling practice.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Practicum in Counselling Psychology I
desc: Supervised counselling psychology field experience. Increases conceptual understanding of counselling psychology and develops counselling and consulting skills.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Lifespan Human Development
desc: Introduces a comprehensive view of human development across the lifespan, drawing on the major theoretical positions. Developmental themes are discussed in terms of their application to typical and atypical human development in children, adolescents and adults.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Family and Social Bases of Behaviour
desc: Using developmental systems theory and current research, the focus will be on understanding how significant ecological systems foster both positive and negative psychosocial development in children and adolescents in applied health and school settings.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Disorders of Learning and Behaviour
desc: Focuses on childhood and adolescent disorders through an examination of theories, diagnostic and associated features and disorders, prevalence, developmental course, cultural and gender context, and familial patterns.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Academic and Language Assessment
desc: Course provides a broad understanding of the standards that guide assessment practices through an examination of assessment of academic areas and language skills.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Professional Practice of School Psychology
desc: A focus on the preparation, roles, functions, and employment of school psychologists as well as the regulation, evaluation, and accountability of school psychologists.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Neurobiological and Developmental Bases of Learning and Behaviour
desc: Examines the field of cognitive neuroscience from an assessment framework. It explores the evolving understanding of neurobehavioural disorders and new testing techniques and practices now available to assess neuropsychological characteristics in both clinical and research settings.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Advanced Child Development
desc: Explores the theory and research supporting recent advances in select areas of child development. Topics include: parent/peer relations; personality, self and self-concept; language and thought; emotion and motivation; and pro-social, antisocial, and moral development.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Practicum in Academic and Language Assessment and Intervention
desc: This 200-hour practicum provides opportunities to develop competencies in academic and language assessment and interventions within an approved setting.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Cognitive and Neuropsychological Assessment
desc: Focuses on the theory and practice of intellectual/cognitive, memory, and neuropsychological assessment primarily through the use of individually administered standardized tests.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Interventions to Promote Cognitive, Academic, and Neuropsychological Well-Being
desc: Focuses on evidence-based interventions aimed at promoting cognitive, academic, and neuropsychological development in children and youth.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Academic Assessment and Intervention
desc: Academic and language assessment and intervention primarily through the use of individually administered standardized tests and evidence-based interventions aimed at promoting academic and language development in children and youth.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 665 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 665 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Social, Emotional, and Behavioural Assessment
desc: Grounded in bioecological systems perspective and developmental and resiliency frameworks, course focuses on the comprehensive assessment of children and youth referred for social, emotional, and behavioural concerns.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Psychological Foundations of Student Exceptionality
desc: Major trends, developments, theoretical foundations, and current practices and challenges relative to the education of students with diverse learning needs.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: School Psychology Practicum I
desc: Provides supervised experience to develop competencies aligned with the practice of school psychology, including consultation, assessment, and intervention. Adherence to all provincial and national ethical and professional guidelines is expected.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 614, 665, 659, 669 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 614, 665, 659, 669 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: School Psychology Practicum II
desc: Provides supervised experience to further develop and refine school psychologist competencies. Administration of evidenced–based intervention strategies will be also required. Adherence to all provincial and national ethical and professional guidelines is expected.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 662 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 662 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Psychological Approaches to Health
desc: Focuses on how human psychology and human health intersect and is organized according to core principles and skills that guide the practice of health psychology. Will orient students to contemporary theories and models of health, illness, and health promotion, and their relevance in a variety of settings.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 602, 624, 610 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 602, 624, 610 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Cognitive Assessment and Intervention
desc: The theory and practice of intellectual/cognitive, and memory assessment primarily through the use of individually administered standardized tests and evidence-based interventions aimed at promoting cognitive, academic, and neuropsychological development in children and youth.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Assessment of Students with Exceptional Learning Needs
desc: Theory and practice in school-based academic and social-emotional assessment techniques and strategies for use with students with diverse learning needs. Laboratory and field experiences.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Theory and Practice of Clinical Supervision
desc: Intended for students to learn the process of clinical supervision and as a result become better consumers of supervision, more effective supervisors, and more able to evaluate their current and future development and involvement in supervisory roles.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Social-Emotional Assessment and Intervention
desc: Focuses on the theory and practice of social, emotional, and behavioural assessment and on evidence-based interventions to enhance the mental health and behavioural well-being of children and youth.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 665 and admission to a graduate program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 665 and admission to a graduate program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Final Project Portfolio
desc: Students complete a culminating independent project in their area of specialization to satisfy the degree requirements.

name: Practicum in School-based Interventions for Children and Youth with Exceptional Learning Needs: I
desc: Practicum in educational interventions for children and adolescents with special learning needs. Focus on general assessment, analysis, intervention, and strategies in applied settings.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 661 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 661 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Counselling Exceptional Children
desc: Intended to help students enhance their awareness and understanding of major trends, developments, theoretical foundations, and current practices and challenges in counselling and providing consultation for special needs children and adolescents.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Practicum in School-based Interventions for Children and Youth with Exceptional Learning Needs: II
desc: Advanced practicum in educational interventions for children and adolescents with special learning needs. Focus on specialized assessment, analysis, interventions, and strategies in applied settings.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 671 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 671 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Interventions to Promote Socio-emotional and Behavioural Well-Being
desc: Focus on strategies to enhance the socio-emotional and behavioural well-being of children and youth who exhibit significant emotional and behavioural needs in school and community settings.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 660 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 660 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Practicum in Cognitive and Neuropsychological Assessment and Intervention
desc: This 200-hour practicum provides opportunities to develop competencies in cognitive and neuropsychological assessment and interventions within an approved setting.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 651, 654, 657 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 651, 654, 657 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Practicum in Social, Emotional, and Behavioural Assessment
desc: A supervised practicum in social, emotional, and behavioural assessment. Students will undertake comprehensive social, emotional, and behavioural assessment with children and youth presenting with various developmental disorders. Students will undertake this practicum experience within the Werklund School of Education's Integrated Educational Services office (ISE).
prereqs: Educational Psychology 696 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 696 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Play Therapy Theory and Process
desc: The theoretical foundations and basic orientation necessary to understand and use play as therapy are outlined, along with the developmental underpinnings of play in children and the basic principles upon which child-centred play therapy is built.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Art Therapy History
desc: Art therapy is examined from a broad perspective, from its beginnings as a treatment for mentally or emotionally disturbed people, to its development as a distinct profession in North America and Europe. The works of key authors are covered, along with their theoretical approaches and current trends in the field. Students will learn how the foundations of art therapy are incorporated by many disciplines, with applications in many settings.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 642, 616, 638 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 642, 616, 638 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Fundamentals of Solution-Oriented Therapy
desc: Provides a working knowledge of the theory and practice of solution-oriented therapy and related models.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Counselling Graduate Practicum: Selected Topics
desc: Graduate Practicum: Selected Topics.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Theories and Skills of Counselling
desc: An introduction to the major theories of counselling as well as counselling micro-skills and interviewing skills.
prereqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Special Topics: Counselling
desc: Graduate Seminar: Special Topics.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Consultation in School Psychology
desc: Examines the purpose and skills of consultation, evaluation issues, and strategies in consultation as well as the role of school psychologists relative to multidisciplinary school teams, school-based problems solving, and student development and learning.
prereqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Advanced Seminar in the Domains of School Psychology Leadership and Function in the Schools
desc: Provides an advanced study of the domains and functions of school and applied child psychologists. Constituting the final course within the MEd program, students are required to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of and competency in the ten domains identified by the National Association of School Psychologists as central to the school psychology profession. For each of the ten domains, students will complete a case study requiring the integration of theory, research, and skills.
prereqs: Admission to the MEd program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to the MEd program with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Child and Adolescent Counselling
desc: Introduces the theory and practice of counselling in school-based settings and fosters student development of rudimentary counselling and psychotherapy skills for school-based service delivery.
prereqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Counselling Graduate Seminar: Selected Topics
desc: Graduate Seminar: Selected Topics.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Developmental Psychopathology
desc: An examination of the history of psychopathology and abnormal psychology, and the DSM-V. An empirical and theoretical scope will be used to approach childhood disorders including issues with classification, etiology, and developmental course.
prereqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Cognitive and Affective Bases of Behaviour
desc: A survey of cognitive development in the first two decades of life. Topics may include biological bases of cognition, perception, memory, motivation, emotion, learning, language and motor.
prereqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.
antireqs: Admission to Educational Psychology graduate program or consent of Graduate Programs in Education.

name: Cognitive Assessment
desc: A focus on the history, theory and practice of cognitive assessment. This course also focuses on report writing and multicultural assessment within the context of cognitive evaluation.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 653 and admission to the School and Applied Child Psychology graduate program.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 653 and admission to the School and Applied Child Psychology graduate program.

name: School-based Intervention and Consultation
desc: An exploration of school systems, evidence-based interventions, and theories of consultation.
prereqs: Admission to the School and Applied Child Psychology graduate program.
antireqs: Admission to the School and Applied Child Psychology graduate program.

name: Graduate Seminar: Selected Topics
desc: Applied course in program planning, design, and evaluation for counselling contexts.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Graduate Seminar: Selected Topics
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Graduate Seminar: Selected Topics
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or Educational Research.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology or Educational Research.

name: Graduate Practicum: Selected Topics
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology.

name: Graduate Practicum: Selected Topics
desc: Supervised counselling field experience.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in Counselling Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in Counselling Psychology.

name: Social, Emotional, and Behavioural Assessment and Intervention
desc: A focus on the assessment and intervention of children and youth who exhibit significant social, emotional, and behavioural needs in school and community settings.
prereqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Practicum in Academic and Cognitive Assessment
desc: With a focus on academic and cognitive functioning, this practicum provides supervised experience to develop competencies aligned with the practice of school psychology including consultation, assessment, and intervention.
prereqs: Educational Psychology 689 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 689 and admission to a graduate program in Educational Psychology with specialization in School and Applied Child Psychology.

name: Pre-Master's Internship in School and Applied Child Psychology
desc: Within this 1200 hour full-time internship, Masters level interns will have opportunities to demonstrate under supervision their ability to apply their knowledge to develop specific skills needed for effective school psychological service delivery and integrate competencies that address various domains of professional preparation and practice in school psychology.
prereqs: Admission to the MEd program with specialization in School and Applied Psychology and consent of the Training Director.
antireqs: Admission to the MEd program with specialization in School and Applied Psychology and consent of the Training Director.

name: Advanced Research Design, Psychometrics and Statistics in Applied Psychology
desc: Provides intensive exposure to sophisticated quantitative techniques relevant to research design, psychometrics, and statistics such as structural equation modelling (SEM), item-response theory (IRT), and hierarchical linear modelling (HLM).
prereqs: Educational Psychology 618 and admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.
antireqs: Educational Psychology 618 and admission to a doctoral program in Educational Psychology.

name: Advanced Theories in Measurement
